DOC.HEAD: Court Weighs in Against 350-Pound Man
DOC.TEXT: The scales of justice tipped against a 350-pound man who had claimed he was fired from his fast-food restaurant job for being too fat. A U.S. District judge on Thursday rejected Ted S. Mounts' claim of discrimination by Long John Silver's Inc. and his request for $205,000 in damages. Mounts, 37, said his obesity was a medical problem and therefore a physical handicap. Federal and state laws prohibit employment discrimination on the basis of race, sex, nationality, religion and physical handicaps. But Judge Charles Haden said it ``would require some quantum leaps'' of logic to accept the discrimination argument. Attorneys for the restaurant, where Mounts worked for 12 years, said he was fired in 1987 for incompetence, not size. Mounts claimed that company officials ``harassed, embarrassed and humiliated'' him because of his weight. He was never reprimanded for his job performance, but every written evaluation he received from 1980 to 1986 mentioned his size, he said. ``It was always an unwritten rule there that being big was bad,'' Mounts said. ``They say I don't look professional being overweight.'' Mounts said he is unemployed and receives Social Security and state workers' compensation benefits. ``I'm not really happy about the decision, but maybe it will encourage others in my situation to stand up and not be afraid of the big guy,'' Mounts said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Dissident Celebrates Crumbling of Communism
DOC.TEXT: The crumbling of communism is sweet vindication for Soviet dissident Natan Sharansky, who was whisked through the Berlin Wall in a 1986 prisoner exchange after languishing for nine years in the gulags. ``The events of the last year were the realization of our wildest dreams. There is such a hole in this iron wall that nobody can ever rebuild it again,'' Sharansky said. ``There is no question communist ideology has failed, and some of the most fascinating changes are happening in our lifetime.'' Sharansky, 41, personifies the struggle of Soviet Jews for human rights and freer emigration. He begins his first U.S. lecture tour with a speech Tuesday at the University of California at Davis. In an hour-long interview here, Sharansky said dissidents should get credit for forcing President Mikhail Gorbachev to restructure the Soviet system. He also said anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union is getting stronger as communism's grip weakens, and is fueling an exodus of Jews to Israel. For Sharansky, the breakdown of the old order in the Soviet bloc was the most exciting moment since his release from prison after serving nine years of a 13-year sentence for spying, a charge that he denied. ``We dissidents had such deep beliefs in our hearts that sooner or later this system had to become bankrupt, morally, socially, economically and politically. Nobody could expect it to go so quickly,'' he said. ``I told my wife that that by the time our youngest daughter grew one tooth, two more dictators in Eastern Europe had fallen down,'' said Sharansky, who lives in Israel with his wife and two daughters. Sharansky was at first denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, although his wife, Avital, was allowed to leave a day after they were married in 1974. She worked tirelessly for his freedom, meeting with President Reagan to plead his case. Reagan and Gorbachev arranged for his release at a summit meeting, and Sharansky passed to freedom across Glienicke Bridge to West Berlin on a frozen Feb. 11, 1986. Sharansky recounted the horrors of Soviet prisons in his 1988 book ``Fear No Evil,'' published by Random House. He plans about 10 lectures a year to talk about who is responsible for Soviet restructuring. ``The Soviet dissidents and their supporters in the West are the midwives of glasnost and perestroika,'' Sharansky said, cautioning against the lionization of Gorbachev as a champion of democracy. ``Gorbachev is a loyal communist. His aim was to save the communist system by changing it. He deserves credit for one thing: he was the first Soviet leader to say that communism would lose to capitalism if urgent changes weren't made in the economy.'' Sharansky also said: ``There are dissidents still in Soviet prisons who were jailed for saying the same things as Gorbachev.'' Sharansky was a comrade of Soviet dissident and Nobel Prize-winning physicist Andrei Sakharov, but was denied permission to visit the Soviet Union for Sakharov's funeral in December. Sharansky, who has a street marker in New York named after him, dropped his Soviet name, Anatoly, to use his Hebrew name, Natan, when he entered Israel. As chairman of the Soviet Jewry Zionist Forum, he helps Soviet Jews find housing and jobs. ``We are seeing the biggest exodus of Jews in modern history. They are afraid to stay in the Soviet Union because of anti-Semitism. It's absolutely inevitable this exodus will continue,'' Sharansky said. ``There is practically no place for Jews in the Soviet Union in the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Kidnapping Charges Against Parents Who Deprogrammed Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday threw out all charges against a couple accused of kidnapping their adult daughter in a failed deprogramming attempt, saying a jury never would be able to reach any kind of verdict. Superior Court Judge David Moon Jr.'s ruling came a day after he declared a mistrial because a jury had been deadlocked on kidnap, false imprisonment and battery charges against Earle and Dorothy Brown, both 58, of Santa Cruz. The Browns and three co-defendants were charged with abducting Ginger Brown from a northern San Diego County parking lot in May 1988 and holding her for five days in an attempt to deprogram her. Ginger Brown, then 22, had joined a small religious group called Great Among Nations, which her parents say is a cult whose leader, Benjamin Altschul, brainwashes his followers. Also charged in the case were the Browns' other daughter, Holly Brown, 25, of San Francisco; Los Angeles deprogrammer Cliff Daniels, 35; and his accomplice, Hank Erler, 23, of Escondido. A jury on Wednesday had returned seven acquittals against the defendants but deadlocked on remaining charges. The judge said that any further court proceedings would not be worth the time and expense. He said the jury was unwilling to convict the defendants even though some of them incriminated themselves during testimony. ``This judge is not going to let the people's courtroom be used to titillate the public's fascination with unusual religious groups,'' he said. Earle Brown said he was delighted by the rulings and said he now wanted his daughter back. ``We've since forgiven her. If there is animosity toward us on her part we might apologize, but I don't know what we might apologize for to the group. We will still continue to pray for her,'' he said. Ginger Brown, who remains a part of the religious group, said she was not disappointed with the ruling and planned to drop a $2.5 million civil suit against her parents and the other defendants. ``I didn't lose anything other than the strong binding I had with my family that (deprogrammer) Cliff Daniels has been successful in wedging apart,'' she said. ``I hope they come to me and apologize, come to all the members of my church and apologize and especially to my pastor and apologize for this slanderous way in which they have portrayed our ministry,'' she said. Altschul has described his group as a television ministry that hopes to produce and sell programs to television stations worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Allow Public Role in Planning Weapons Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department, under pressure from environmental critics, will give the public a chance to review how its plans to clean up and rebuild the nation's nuclear weapons complex will affect the environment. The announcement Friday by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins came nearly seven months after 22 environmental and arms control groups sued the department to force such a review. ``The significance of it is that it would be the first comprehensive and public analysis of the whole weapons program,'' said Dan Reicher, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the environmental groups that sued. Reicher said allowing the public to participate in the planning could lead to significant changes in the future emphasis of the multi-billion dollar weapons program. ``It could very well shift the direction of the program away from modernization and toward cleanup,'' he said. Watkins also won applause from Capitol Hill. ``The department's decision today may mean that the bomb factories' iron curtain of secrecy is lifting,'' said Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore., one of several members of Congress who 13 months ago requested the environmental reviews. Many environmental groups, including Reicher's, have argued the government should spend more to clean up the trail of hazardous and radioactive wastes generated by weapons plants. Many of the 17 major plants and laboratories in 12 states were built in the late 1940s or early 1950s and operated for decades in a dome of secrecy that permitted environmental abuses. Watkins also announced Friday he was sending independent teams of environmental specialists to five weapons plants or laboratories to study their compliance with federal and state environmental laws as well as health and safety rules. The five plants are the Savannah River Site near Aiken, S.C., which makes materials for nuclear warheads; the Pinellas weapons components plant near Largo, Fla.; the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory at Livermore, Calif., which performs research and testing of weapons designs; the Brookhaven nuclear research laboratory at Upton, N.Y.; and the Sandia nuclear weapons laboratory at Livermore. Watkins has been trying to reassure the public his department is committed to developing a long-range plan for cleaning up nuclear wastes, but he also wants to spend billions of dollars rebuilding key parts of the weapons complex. In his announcement, Watkins said the department would prepare an environmental impact statement on its recently published five-year plan for cleaning up the weapons plants. He said the report will evaluate alternative approaches to resolving the waste problem, including treatment, storage and disposal options. He said an environmental impact statement on long-term plans for modernizing the weapons production system also is planned, although the department has not released details of a modernization plan. Catherine Kaliniak, a department spokeswoman, said an internal assessment of modernization priorities will be completed in a few months. Watkins said public hearings would be held as part of the environmental studies, and the results would be used as a ``planning tool to guide decision making.'' ``Preparation of these major environmental documents, with opportunities for full public participation in the process, will assure environmentally informed decision making,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Computer Makers Drop Joint Plan to Manufacture Chips
DOC.TEXT: U.S. computer companies are dropping plans for a cooperative venture to challenge Japanese leadership in the making of computer memory chips, according to published reports. The proposed venture, U.S. Memories, failed to attract enough investors, according to reports in Saturday's editions of The New York Times and The Washington Post citing sources in the computer industry. The plan called for building a $1 billion factory to make computer memory chips, using money donated by at least seven computer and semiconductor companies. Sanford L. Kane, the president of U.S. Memories, told the Times that he was frustrated by his failure to persuade computer companies to sign up for the venture. ``One can only bang their head against the wall for so long. Sooner or later you get a headache,'' he told the Times. He refused to comment directly on the reports that the cooperative venture was dead. U.S. Memories was announced in June as a project to restore American strength in production of the common computer memory chips known as dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAMs. By November, however, several major computer companies _ including Sun Microsystems Inc., Unisys Corp., Apple Computer Inc. and Tandy Corp. _ had said they would not join as investors. Japanese firms supply a majority of the memory chips now available. Most American chip manufacturers dropped out of the market several years ago. Computer industry officials told the Times that the end of U.S. Memories was decided Wednesday at a meeting in Dallas attended by the seven firms that had signed up and other firms still considering entering the venture. The Times said the project failed in part because the memory chips have become more widely available as Samsung of South Korea, Siemens A.G. of West Germany and Motorola Inc. of the United States have begun manufacturing the chips.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Subway gunman Bernhard Goetz, wearing blue jeans and an open white shirt, defended himself in court against a $50 million lawsuit filed by one of the four youths he shot on a train five years ago. ``It could have been better, it could have been worse,'' Goetz, 42, said after his legal debut Friday in a 30-minute session before state Supreme Court Judge Barry Salman. Attorney William Kunstler, who is representing shooting victim Darrell Cabey in the civil lawsuit, said ``time will tell'' if Goetz can become a competent counselor. The judge ordered Kunstler to have a lawyer examine Cabey to determine whether the plaintiff is competent to be questioned by Goetz. Cabey, now 24, was paralyzed from the waist down in the Dec. 22, 1984, shooting. Goetz, a self-employed electrical calibrator, has filed a $40 million libel action against Cabey, his mother, and attorneys Ronald Kuby and Kunstler. Again acting as his own attorney, Goetz said the two lawyers libeled him when they described him as a ``walking time bomb and a racist.'' Goetz served 8{ months in jail on a weapons conviction stemming from the subway shooting after a legal battle that reached the U.S. Supreme Court.

An offer of a cigarette and a job from Paterson Mayor Frank X. Graves may have saved a man from jumping from a sixth-floor ledge. Saying he wanted to shake hands to clinch the job offer, Graves clutched Robert Hamway's right hand and held on for dear life. Two firefighters lunged forward, grabbed the 24-year-old man's arms and pulled him to safety. After the incident Thursday, Graves said he was trying ``to open a door'' of opportunity for Hamway. He said the job offer was legitimate, but carries no guarantees if Hamway fails to perform. Authorities said Hamway told them while on the ledge that he had an outstanding arrest warrant and had recently missed an appointment at a cocaine detoxification center.

DOC.TEXT: Arsenio Hall will present a special program in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. to celebrate the slain civil rights leader's birthday. Joining comedian Hall on his nationally syndicated talk show Monday night will be the Grammy-nominated gospel group The Winans, Christian singer Amy Grant and 1960s folk singer Dion, performing his tribute ``Abraham, Martin and John.'' Music producer Quincy Jones will conduct a children's choir led by 12-year-old Tevan Cambell. Also appearing on the one-hour program will be former state Sen. Georgia Powers of Kentucky, a friend of King's.

Christian Slater, a 20-year-old actor who appeared in ``Heathers'' and ``The Wizard,'' has been charged with drunkenly crashing his car, trying to flee and kicking a deputy. The actor, a Van Nuys resident, is free on $3,000 bail. He is to be arraigned Jan. 19 in Beverly Hills Municipal Court on charges of drunken driving, battery on a police officer, resisting arrest and evading arrest. Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies spotted Slater's Saab Turbo 900 traveling more than 50 mph in a 35 mph zone on Santa Monica Boulevard in West Hollywood at about 1 a.m. on Dec. 29, authorities said. They said they tried to pull it over, but the car turned onto side streets and smashed into two telephone poles. Slater jumped out, ran, and was climbing a chain-link fence when Deputy Vincent Moultrie dragged him down, getting Slater's cowboy boots in his face in the process, said Deputy District Attorney Hugh Bobys. Tests showed the actor's blood was .16 percent alcohol, far over the legal limit of .08, Bobys said. Slater also starred in a skateboard movie, ``Gleaming the Cube,'' and had roles in ``Tucker: The Man and His Dream,'' ``The Name of the Rose,'' and ``The Legend of Billie Jean.''

Garry Shandling may end his popular comedy series ``It's Garry Shandling's Show'' on Showtime and Fox Broadcasting at the end of the current season, said Brad Grey, his manager and executive producer. ``It's up in the air right now,'' Grey said Friday. ``Garry and I are talking about what the plan will be for next year. Garry's really trying to sort out whether he wants to continue or move onto something new and different.'' In the series, Shandling plays himself at home. In the manner of the old Jack Benny shows he spoofs television and frequently talks directly to the audience. ``Garry's intrigued with the idea of doing more acting, maybe in motion pictures, or maybe in a different series,'' said Grey.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Agency Announces Tougher Ethics Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service is toughening rules of conduct for senior employees following highly publicized allegations of misconduct by some field managers. The aim, said IRS Commissioner Fred Goldberg, is to protect ``what is the bedrock of our tax system, and that is the real and perceived integrity of this institution.'' ``What we need is ongoing attention and adherence to the kinds of issues of conduct, ethics and appearance that are essential to tax administration,'' Goldberg said Friday in announcing the ethics initiative. Goldberg acted after congressional hearings last summer in which managers and other top officials of some field offices were accused of abusing power, favoring friends and operating almost independently of directives from the agency's Washington headquarters. ``This is an agency of 120,000 employees and we will rise or fall on the kinds of procedures ... the kinds of controls we have in place that minimize to the absolute extent possible incidents that create either the appearance or reality of illegality, misjudgment or misconduct,'' Goldberg said. The initiative was hailed by Rep. Douglas Barnard, D-Ga., chairman of the House Government Operations consumer subcommittee, which conducted a two-year investigation of the allegations and held public hearings last year. ``If that plan is properly implemented, it will go a long way toward solving some extremely serious employee misconduct and morale problems at the service,'' Barnard said. ``In order for our self-assessment tax system to work properly, the public must be confident that senior IRS employees are respectful of taxpayer rights and educated to exercising their responsibilities fairly as well as effectively,'' Barnard said. In announcing the plan, Goldberg disclosed the IRS has suspended at least temporarily a ``lockbox'' setup, roundly criticized during Barnard's hearings, that some have interpreted as an amnesty program for tax cheats. The IRS ``will be trying to clarify what if anything we want to do with'' the lockbox procedure, Goldberg said. He denied that the procedure is necessarily an amnesty but acknowledged it could be interpreted as such. The procedure was authorized by Ronald Saranow, then head of the IRS criminal investigation division in Los Angeles. Delinquent taxpayers represented by a lawyer friend of Saranow could, while keeping their identities secret, make cash payments to a lockbox and receive an IRS letter saying they would not be the subject of a criminal investigation unless their evasion arose from illegal activities. In discussing the ethics initiative, Goldberg refused to answer questions about the most widely publicized allegation at the Barnard hearings: a charge that an IRS executive launched an investigation of the manufacturers of Jordache jeans because of his relationship with the competing makers of Guess? jeans. In that probe, the IRS raided Jordache's New York offices and seized one million documents. The company has not been charged. The new ethics program announced by Goldberg includes: _An agreement under which the Treasury Department inspector general will investigate allegations against senior IRS managers and all employees of the IRS inspection division. Employees in that division operate as the internal affairs branch of IRS. _An ``inspection hotline'' to give IRS field employees a direct line to Washington headquarters when they don't feel comfortable complaining to local officials. _Reversal of an earlier decision under which local office managers can approve their own travel vouchers. _Removing any ambiguity from regulations on investments by IRS employees. _Ensuring that every training program for IRS employees includes emphasis on ethics and conduct.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Panama Invasion Shows U.S. Needs Strong Military
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, described as ``pretty broken up'' by a meeting with the family of a soldier slain in Panama, is using the invasion to argue that the United States must keep a high state of military readiness. ``This is not a time when we should naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture,'' Bush said Friday in a speech aimed at Congress, which reconvenes Jan. 23 after its winter recess. Bush cautioned that despite a relaxation of military tensions in Eastern Europe, lawmakers should not expect a ``peace dividend'' in which defense savings could be funnelled into domestic programs. ``Unfortunately, what is being packaged as a `dividend' is not money in the bank. It is more like a possible future inheritance,'' Bush said in his speech to the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce. ``Whenever a potential inheritance looms, there are those eager to rush out and squander it _ to buy new things, to spend, spend, spend _ spending funds they don't yet have,'' he said. Bush went to Camp David after the Ohio trip and planned to spend a three-day weekend at the presidential retreat in Maryland. He told the business audience the Dec. 20 U.S. intervention in Panama was a ``beautifully coordinated'' operation. If a rationale for keeping a strong defense is ``ever needed, we saw it last month in the courage of our troops in Panama,'' he said. But later, Bush was brought close to tears in a meeting with the Cincinnati parents of a Army Pfc. James Markwell, a Ranger medic killed in the invasion, aides said. Markwell, who had been in the Army 18 months, died of gunfire after his arrival by parachute in a ``drop zone'' on the day of the U.S. invasion. Bush met after the speech with Mr. and Mrs. William Rouse, Markwell's mother and stepfather. Markwell's brother, Brandon, 17, and his sister Dawn, 15, were also present, said Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. It was a ``pretty emotional meeting,'' said Fitzwater, who was present at the session, along with deputy chief of staff Andrew Card Jr. and several Secret Service agents. He said Bush was touched when Mrs. Rouse produced a poem her son wrote at age 15 about his desire to be a solider. ``It was very sad,'' Fitzwater said. Then the mother produced a ``death letter'' her son wrote before entering combat. Each Ranger writes such a letter and it is delivered only if the soldier is killed, Fitzwater said. In the letter ``he talked about how he was proud of what he was doing,'' Fitzwater said. It also contained ``a little message for each of the people he knew in life,'' the aide said. ``All of us were pretty broken up at that point,'' Fitzwater said. Bush has written personal letters to the families of all 23 U.S. soldiers killed in the invasion, but it was his first face-to-face meeting with one of the families, Fitzwater said. Bush visited U.S. servicemen wounded in the invasion on New Year's Eve in two military hospitals in San Antonio, Texas. He mentioned that visit in his Chamber of Commerce speech, saying ``I will never, ever forget their spirit.'' ``The Panamanian operation was conducted by highly trained troops _ the best trained troops in the world. But it is not simply training, it is patriotism and dedication,'' he said. Bush said he welcomed the ``dynamic changes in Eastern Europe'' and strongly supported Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts at political reform. The president also told his audience of about 1,500 people that key parts of his domestic agenda _ including a cut in the capital gains tax, stronger clean air standards and education and anti-crime programs _ were ``bogged down in the jungles of Capitol Hill.'' ``The clock is running and America's patience is running out,'' he said. At Cincinnati's predominantly black Taft High School, Bush also hailed a program of business leaders, government officials and educators to reduce dropouts and improve academic performance. And, borrowing a line from 1988 Democratic presidential contender Jesse Jackson, Bush told the students: ``I don't think you can design a curriculum to lift the self-esteem of a kid. It's got to come from peers, from family, from dedicated volunteers -who are saying `you are somebody.'''

DOC.HEAD: Ballet Dancers' Threat To Step Out On Picket Line
DOC.TEXT: Britain's best ballet dancers are threatening to strike over pay and working conditions, raising the prospect of a picket line outside the venerable Royal Opera House in Covent Garden. The dispute had dragged on since July and now threatens the cancellation of three ballets. It also has disrupted the first joint production of the Royal Opera and Royal Ballet, the Russian opera ``Prince Igor,'' which has a 25-minute ballet. Richard Wright, the Royal Opera administrator, said Friday that after two days' talks with Equity, the performers' labor union, a revised offer would be made Monday to the 136 dancers of the Royal Ballet and the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet. Both share the Royal Opera House with the Royal Opera. The opera house at first offered a 10 percent pay increase to the dancers' demand for 15 percent. The house gradually raised its offer to 15 percent, but only in return for more hours of work and agreement to allow two productions a year to be shown on a screen to non-paying crowds in the Covent Garden piazza. The dancers are likely to go on saying no. The dispute broke Friday into front-page caricature. Cartoonist Matt of the conservative Daily Telegraph, playing on a pay dispute at Ford of Britain auto plants, showed one Ford assembly-line worker saying to another: `I hope we don't go on strike. I don't want people thinking I'm a ballet dancer.'' The dancers want salaries that would close the gap with the higher pay of the choristers and musicians at the Royal Opera House. The 15 percent offer would take the pay of senior principal dancers from $860 a week to $988. Pay for first-year members of the corps de ballet would go up from $278 to $322 for a 33-hour week. The dance dispute is really a rebellion at the 132-year-old state-supported opera house, where ballet dancers feel they have always been treated as poor cousins. Opera is definitely king at Covent Garden. Jeremy Isaacs, the opera house director, struggling with a $5 million deficit this year, has pleaded for a quick settlement. Rebecca Holmes, 21, a Royal Ballet dancer of first-artist rank, making $410 a week, told a reporter her day usually runs from 7 a.m. to midnight, with subway travel and having to use rehearsal rooms nearly six miles away from Covent Garden. She said Sunday is her one day off, when all she does is sleep and eat. The dancers say their work is tough and demanding, with grueling rehearsals followed by evening performances. Their dancing careers will end in their mid-30s. Friday also was a bad day for the Royal Ballet on another front. Anthony Dowell, the director, said it had been forced to abandon talks with New York's Metropolitan Opera Association for a long-planned tour to the United States in July because it could not find sponsors. ``I am very disappointed that the tour will not take place,'' Dowell said. ``We were eagerly looking forward to a return visit to the Metropolitan Opera and to our American public.''

DOC.HEAD: Zipper Said to Block Bullet in Store Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Even New York police are having trouble believing this one: the trouser zipper that stopped a bullet. Angel Santana, 51, was reportedly shot with a .357-caliber Magnum pistol Friday during a struggle with one of three men holding up the store where he worked. The robbers were so shocked to see the bullet lodged in Santana's zipper that they fled, and dropped their gun, said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman. ``Maybe they thought they were outnumbered by the zipper,'' Weiner said, adding that while the story was ``kind of hard to believe'' it was doublechecked by officers. The gun and the spent bullet were found in the store, he said. Santana was treated for trauma at Lincoln Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Complain About Great Lakes Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: People and wildlife in the Great Lakes region are exposed to a growing health threat because the U.S. and Canadian governments move too slowly in carrying out an anti-pollution plan, environmentalists contend. In a letter to Secretary of State James Baker III and EPA Administrator William Reilly, a coalition of 10 environmental groups said failure to carry out the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement also is undermining U.S. credibility in international environmental negotiations. Without action soon, ``women in the Great Lakes basin may never be able to safely eat a fish dinner or nurse their children without fear of deadly PCB poisoning,'' Melanie Griffin, a Sierra Club official, said at a news conference Friday. ``It's as though the folks over there in the EPA building don't even know that we have this treaty with Canada,'' said Mark Van Putten, director of the National Wildlife Federation's Great Lakes Natural Resources Center. An EPA official said the Bush administration shares the environmentalists' goals but added that implementing the agreement will take time. ``Because the problem is so big and complex and there are so many players involved, things do not move with the speed of light,'' said Frank Covington, deputy administrator in the agency's Chicago office, headquarters of the EPA's Great Lakes program. Covington said EPA has focused its attention on provisions added to the agreement in 1987, when the emphasis shifted to 40 ``hot spots'' where toxic pollution is especially severe. The agency has been helping states develop plans for cleaning those areas, he said. Signed in 1972, renewed in 1978 and updated two years ago, the bilateral accord pledges the U.S. and Canadian governments to cooperate with each other in ridding the Great Lakes of toxic substances. Central to the pact is a pledge that toxic discharges into the waters be ``virtually eliminated.'' There have been improvements since 1972, including cutbacks in the discharge of pollutants directly into the lakes, Ms. Griffin said. But little has been done about toxins such as contaminated rainwater and runoff from farms, city streets, hazardous waste dumps and contaminated sediments, she said. Numerous scientific studies have concluded the lake pollution is entering the food chain, posing a health threat, the environmentalists' letter said. Researchers believe the atmosphere is the source of 25 percent of all toxins in the lakes, Ms. Griffin said. Yet the EPA has regulated only seven of hundreds of toxic air pollutants, she complained. Pesticides and phosphorus flow into the lakes from farm runoff and urban runoff contains heavy metals such as copper and lead, said Diane Cameron, an environmental engineer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. The agreement calls for programs to collect and treat runoff, which neither country has done adequately, Ms. Cameron said. They also are failing to protect wetlands and continue to allow developers to construct buildings too close to lake shores, worsening the runoff problem, she said. Van Putten said state and local governments in the Great Lakes region have added top the problem by engaging in a ``conspiracy of silence'' on covering up violations of regulations. ``Michigan is unwilling to publicly criticize Wisconsin because Wisconsin might later criticize Michigan, and EPA ... has been unwilling to step in and force the states to make the progress required under the agreement,'' he said. DOC.HEAD: Four Suspected IRA Members Arrested in Stinger Missile Purchase
Laserphoto FTB1 of Jan. 12
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities used a Stinger to lure four suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas into a sting operation in which they offered $50,000 for the missile that can shoot an airliner out of the sky. The four men were arrested Friday after going to a warehouse in the West Palm Beach area to buy the heat-seeking missile from agents posing as arms dealers who told the suspects the weaponry was stolen from the U.S. military, said William Gavin, who heads the FBI in south Florida. ``They made it very clear they were interested in procuring Stinger missiles and high explosives _ and they intended to ship them out of the country,'' Gavin said at a news conference. Kevin Joseph McKinley, 33, Seamus Moley, 30, and Joseph McColgan, 39, all Irish nationals, and Sean John McCann, 34, of Canada, are believed to be members of the Provisional IRA, or ``Provos,'' the guerrilla arm of the nationalist group fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Each suspect was charged with conspiracy to possess destructive arms, possession of a destructive device and violations of the Arms Export Control Act and the Neutrality Law. Each faces up to 25 years in prison and $750,000 in fines if convicted, the FBI said. The suspects denied the charges as they were led in handcuffs from the federal courthouse to the Palm Beach County Jail, where they were being held without bond pending a hearing Tuesday. ``I'm just a poor Irishman here on holiday, and I was entrapped by certain people here,'' McColgan said in a thick Irish accent. ``They were going to sell equipment for the Irish Republican struggle,'' McColgan added with a smile. ``They wanted to sell us missiles. Imagine that.'' Their capture concluded a two-month joint undercover investigation by the FBI, the U.S. Customs Service and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. The investigation began after the FBI received intelligence that the men, who had been staying in a Riviera Beach trailer park, were looking to buy weapons, agents said. In a series of meetings, the suspects told the agents about terrorist activities to persuade them that they were serious about buying the Stinger, officials said. ``When they met with our undercover agents, they described in detail events which occurred outside of the country _ which did occur _ and we believed absolutely they were involved,'' said Special Agent Robert Creighton, regional ATF supervisor. He provided no details about the events discussed by the men. The suspected guerrillas went to the undisclosed warehouse Friday to inspect the Stinger, which was on loan from the U.S. military, and allegedly paid $50,000 for its purchase, Creighton said. ``If this was fired at an airliner it could blow it right out of the sky,'' said Timothy Wagner, head of the U.S. Customs Service in Florida. The Stinger uses an infrared homing device to target the heat generated by the engine of an attacking plane or helicopter. It has proved highly effective against low-flying aircraft. Stingers that the United States provided to the Afghan rebels reportedly caused heavy losses to Soviet warplanes and helicopters. Fired from a tube held on the shoulder, the Stinger vaguely resembles the World War II bazooka. It has a range of about three miles, is about 5 feet long, weighs 34.5 pounds and carries a fragmentation warhead. In a previous operation against IRA arms procurements in the United States, authorities arrested three IRA ``technical experts'' in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Pennyslvania on July 12 and seized radar and missile parts. A federal grand jury in Boston indicted five people in the case on charges of violating federal arms export regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Physicists Oppose Scaling Back Super Collider
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to drop extraneous words.
DOC.TEXT: A group of prominent scientists, including five Nobel Prize winners, wants the ``super collider'' built as originally envisioned even though the cost of the giant particle accelerator could rise by more than $1 billion. The Energy Department's High Energy Physics Advisory Panel agreed Friday with a subcommittee's findings that significantly reducing the size or power of the collider to contain costs would ``unacceptably increase the risk of missing important new physics.'' The panel said it was told that keeping the Texas project as originally envisioned, however, could increase the $5.9 billion pricetag by 20 percent to 30 percent. As designed, the super collider will smash beams of protons into each other in a 53-mile circular tunnel at 20 times the energy possible with the most powerful existing accelerators. It would take a reduction of beam energy of 25 percent to hold costs to the original figure, the advisory panel's report said. But it said the project's mission to learn more about ``such issues as the origin of mass,'' the best efforts of theoretical physicists indicate the original energy ``is about the minimum energy needed to have confidence that these phenomena, in whatever form they may take, will be seen.'' A 25 percent reduction in beam energy means ``broad agreement that this confidence would be lost,'' the report said. A decision on collider spending recommendations is expected from Energy Secretary James Watkins later this month, officials said. The collider is expected to be completed by 1998. Congress last year approved $225 million to begin initial construction and President Bush is expected to request about $393 million for the next fiscal year. The department is reviewing cost estimates by SSC Laboratory in DeSoto, Texas, on how various design changes would affect the price. Officials of the SSC Lab, which contracted to build the accelerator at a site south of Dallas, recommend an increase of about $1 billion to keep the project essentially as it was envisioned in 1986. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, said he believes a compromise would be reached but would not speculate on the new cost estimate. ``It's important that we try not to build a Cadillac,'' Gramm said. ``We don't have the money, and to attempt to do that would put us in a position where we would have no machine at all.'' The subpanel said the cost increases would give new ammunition to Capitol Hill opponents of the giant machine, which if completed will be the largest, most complicated scientific instrument ever built. Congressional opponents of the collider fear it will draw resources from other scientific projects that would deliver more immediate payouts benefitting the nation's economy and international competitive position. The additional costs would have to be absorbed by U.S. taxpayers or could come from foreign sources. While some members of Congress favor letting foreign sources provide in-kind equipment and services, others fear those countries would gain immediate technological benefits for their industries, at U.S. expense. James F. Decker, acting director of the department's office of energy research, said the collider should ``provide a substantial new physics capability when it comes on line. ``The United States should not spend this large amount of money for a facility that would be only marginally better than some other existing facility,'' Decker said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Eric James Nightlinger decided he'd had enough of his moody motorcycle, so he dumped the bike off a bridge for the fun of watching it tumble 75 feet into the San Francisco Bay. Nightlinger became frustrated when his 175cc Yamaha broke down Thursday morning in heavy traffic on the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. Highway Patrol Officer Manny Matias, who arrived at the scene after several passing motorists reported seeing a man struggling to push a motorcycle over the railing, found Nightlinger walking toward the toll plaza. The 19-year-old told Matias he had no money to fix the broken-down bike so had pushed it off the bridge. Since no witnesses could be located afterward, no charges were filed.

Lawmakers rejected a proposal to create a group of FOOLS _ Finders of Outlawed Legislative Styrofoam _ to help enforce a ban on plastic foam cups in the legislative chamber. Foam cup in hand, Sen. Ernie Chambers of Omaha introduced his resolution Friday in response to one adopted the day before barring lawmakers and their staffs from using such cups. Saying the resolution to ban the cups was ``environmental posturing,'' Chambers responded with his own bill. Chambers said the ban was unenforceable without adoption of his proposal, which would have required the Legislature's Executive Board to gather 100 Finders of Outlawed Legislative Styrofoam, FOOLS, to find and report suspected violators of LR231. The measure failed on a 4-5 vote.

What a difference a day makes. On Thursday, City Councilman Wendell Foster issued a press release stating he would not run for the Bronx Congressional seat left vacant by Democrat Robert Garcia. On Friday, Foster issued a press release stating he would run. ``They just put a `not' in there,'' Foster said. ``The person who typed it didn't do the proper job.'' Actually, whoever typed it put three ``nots'' in there, in three separate sentences. ``You know how you give things to someone and don't stay around to proofread?'' Foster said. The first release ended with the underlined words ``at this time I am not a candidate for the 18th Congressional District. Again, I repeat, at this time I am not a candidate.'' The second release omitted the ``nots.'' Garcia resigned after being convicted of extortion and conspiracy in the Wedtech scandal.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Sues Exxon; New York Holds Off
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey has sued Exxon Corp. over a 567,000-gallon oil spill, but New York officials decided not to sue because the company agreed to pay for an environmental study and damages. Federal officals, meanwhile, said they were prepared to fine the company $10,000 a day starting Wednesday unless they received a detailed explanation of the Jan. 2 spill of home heating oil in the Arthur Kill shipping channel between New Jersey and the New York City borough of Staten Island. New York officials said the spill contaminated a sensitive bird sanctuary and the cleanup will cost millions. By Friday, the Coast Guard's tally of dead birds had risen to at least 317, with 48 oil-covered live birds being treated. New Jersey Attorney General Peter Perretti Jr. filed a civil lawsuit Friday in Elizabeth, charging Exxon violated the New Jersey Spill Act, the state's Water Pollution Control Act and state common law. If Exxon is found liable, it could be hit with fines of $50,000 per day, per violation. The number of alleged violations has not been determined, Perretti's office said. The lawsuit also seeks to force Exxon to pay any of the ``substantial'' expenses the state is incurring because of the spill, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. ``We haven't been able to put a price tag on our environment yet,'' Hagerty said. Exxon spokesman Phil Wetz said the company could not respond to the lawsuit because its attorneys have not reviewed it. Meetings between New York and Exxon officials led to a last-minute agreement to try to settle differences out of court. In a letter to Exxon officials Wednesday, New York Attorney General Robert Abrams threatened to sue unless the company admitted its liability and paid for the cleanup. Abrams charged that Exxon had created a ``mini-Alaska'' in the Arthur Kill. Exxon has been criticized for its handling of the March 28 spill of about 10 million gallons of crude oil from the grounded Exxon Valdez tanker in Alaska, the nation's largest oil spill. Abrams also said the Arthur Kill spill has contaminated ``critical waterfowl feeding and wetland areas of the environmentally sensitive Pralls Island bird sanctuary.'' In response to Abrams' letter, Exxon said it will pay for ``appropriate'' environmental studies of its oil spill, but that it has accepted responsibility only for ``damages for which it is liable.'' Carol Ash, regional director of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, said cleanup and restoration of the area will run into the millions of dollars. Ash said Exxon agreed that New York's environmental agency will oversee damage assessment and the company will not participate in determining the extent of the damage. In New Jersey, Hagerty said Exxon has neither agreed nor refused to pay the bill. The federal Environmental Protection Agency, meanwhile, has given Exxon until Wednesday to explain how the spill occurred, what the company's response was to protect the environment and what is being done to restore the environment. The agency threatened fines of $10,000 a day. ``The response from Exxon wasn't what we would have liked,'' said EPA spokeswoman Kim Helper in New York. Helper said her agency was particularly concerned that Exxon initially estimated only 5,000 gallons of oil had spilled. ``When you hear about a 5,000-gallon spill you respond one way. When you hear about a 500,000-gallon spill you react another way,'' she said. Wetz, the Exxon spokesman, said the company would have no comment on the threatened fines.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Face Big Task of Rescuing Their Country From Economic Ruin
DOC.TEXT: Romanians, flush with the success of their uprising against Nicolae Ceausescu, now face the formidable task of repairing the ravaged economy that is the former Communist dictator's legacy. Romanian economists and Western experts say Ceausescu severely restrained the economy by exporting goods needed at home and blocking imports that could have modernized the country's antiquated industries. The harsh program managed to pay off a $10.5 billion foreign debt, but it also left Romanian homes cold and people with only basic staples to eat. ``How could one man do more than an economic tornado?'' asked Mircea Pirjol, spokesman for the provisional government's Economy Ministry. For one, Romania's once healthy export trade in lathes has disappeared because the makers could not import modern calibration equipment, said Eugen Dijmarescu, a researcher at Bucharest's Institute for World Economy. Ironically, the lack of foreign debt and the low production costs fostered by Ceausescu's policies could help revive the economy. The dictator, ousted Dec. 22 and executed three days later, was replaced by an interim government headed by the National Salvation Front, which plans to hold free elections as early as April. The country's immediate need is for help in providing food and heating for Romania's 23 million people during the long harsh winter. The Soviet Union already has promised fuel oil, and the United States and France have said they are working on aid programs. Pirjol says economists trying to solve long-range problems must first find out exactly where the country stands since most economic statistics from Ceausescu's 24 years in power cannot be trusted. Asked about production figures, Pirjol replied: ``God knows. All the economic data was falsified.'' One example is grain production. Before Ceausescu was toppled Dec. 22, the government reported a 1989 harvest of 60 million tons. The provisional government recently said the real figure was 16.9 million tons. Dijmarescu said industrial production figures were just as uncertain. ``Last year Ceausescu said that one-third of industrial capacity was not properly employed. If he said that, you can imagine the problem is much greater,'' said Dijmarescu, whose private institute has been hired by the goverment to help plan Romania's economic future. A Western diplomatic source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, estimated that less than 5 percent of Romania's industry was working at capacity. Dijmarescu said that not all Romania's economic problems could be blamed on Ceausescu. Communist policies before his time devastated the once-rich farm economy by driving peasants into cities for jobs in industry and collectivizing what had been profitable small farms. But Ceausescu held to his policy of expanding heavy industry and developing grandiose projects when other East Bloc countries recognized the need for new trade policies. For the past five years, 60 percent of the country's meat was sent abroad. Homes and factories were kept cold and dimly lighted so petroleum products could be exported. At the same time, virtually all imports were blocked. This did more than leave consumers crying for Western goods. It denied modern technology to factories and meant Romanian goods were without the imported components that could have made them saleable. Ceausescu announced last April that Romania had succeeded in wiping out the 1982 foreign debt of $10.5 billion, but he did not withdraw austerity measures, perhaps raising the public anger that brought his downfall. In fact, food rationing was expanded in October. Dijmarescu says the first needs are to revive agriculture and upgrade industrial technology. ``For years people in this county have been in a black hole in terms of knowledge,'' he said. ``We need an inflow of economic and scientific information. We need to train people to manage a market economy.'' The Western diplomatic source said it will not be possible to privatize some of Romania's huge heavy industries for years. One of the country's assets could be its agriculture, already being pushed by a decision of the interim government to give land to peasants. Another plus could be light industry _ such as textiles and shoes _ if technology in factories can be upgraded quickly. Dijmarescu warned that Romania will have to avoid economic shocks that could lead to social tensions. He noted that one dated heavy equipment factory has 20,000 workers and added: ``You can't just close down a factory with that many employees.''

DOC.HEAD: Following the Trail of a Cult Accused of Human Sacrifice
DOC.TEXT: Police in three states knew about the nomadic life in tents, the code words, camouflage clothing and cultish worship services of Jeffrey Lundgren and his followers. But they could find no reason to arrest anyone until it was too late _ nine months after a family of five had been killed, possibly as a sacrifice in a misbegotten reading of Mormon teachings. For more than a year, agents in Missouri, Ohio and West Virginia exchanged information about the cult, authorities said, but they were hard-pressed to build a case. In fact, Lundgren and his clan seemd like good neighbors, making improvements on the farm they rented near this northeast Ohio town, 25 miles east of Cleveland, said Kirtland Police Chief Dennis Yarborough. ``The family had started adding things like siding,'' Yarborough said. ``They were acting and appearing like good citizens. It was kind of a paradox.'' On Jan. 3 and 4, acting on an anonymous tip, federal and local officials dug under a barn on the farm and found the bodies of Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their three daughters, Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7. The Lake County coroner's office said all five had been bound hand and foot with duct tape, with tape covering their mouths and eyes, and shot one at a time. Investigators said the Averys, who lived nearby, had been members of the cult but were not as fervent as some of the other followers. Last week, the 39-year-old Lundgren, a former lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, was arrested with his wife, teen-age son and 10 other followers in scattered cities, mostly around San Diego. Yarborough said Friday there was speculation that Lundgren felt people had to die ``as part of a cleansing ritual'' so the cult could relocate in the wilderness. The Rev. Dale Luffman, pastor of Kirtland's Reorganized Church, has theorized the killings stemmed from fights over money, sex or the possibility the Averys would leave the cult. Lundgren came to Kirtland from the Independence, Mo., area in 1984 to work as a tour guide at a Mormon temple used by the Reorganized Church. The Reorganized Church, based in Independence, split in the last century from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the Mormon Church, which is based in Salt Lake City. Both churches remain rooted in the Book of Mormon and in the writings of founder Joseph Smith. Luffman said Lundgren at first seemed devoted enough in his tours and his Sunday-school teachings but later became menacing. ``He apparently felt the leaders of the church were part of the unrighteous around the temple and needed to be eradicated _ that was the term he used,'' Luffman said. Lundgren began seeing himself as a prophet, using his lay ministry and tour job as forums to recruit followers, Luffman said. The church defrocked him in January 1988, but he was able to find a dozen or more people who listened. Some came to Kirtland, at his urging, from the Independence church he had attended. The followers quit jobs and sold their belongings cheap to make the move, bewildered friends said. The followers moved in with Lundgren on the farm, living commune style, turning over their paychecks from outside employment and letting him read their mail and listen in on their telephone calls, police said. The group fit the classic description of a cult, Luffman said. ``They acknowledge and take their direction and allegiance to a leader with an authorized message. Second, there takes place a separation from all other groups ... friends and family,'' he said. The Kansas City office of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms at one point warned Kirtland authorities that Lundgren had spoken of a Sword of Laban that would be used to decapitate people while ``taking over'' the temple in Kirtland. There is mention of a Sword of Laban in the Book of Mormon. Eventually, male cult members started wearing camouflage clothing and paramilitary gear, practicing with guns and other weapons, and adopting code names such as ``Eagle Eye'' and ``Talon-1,'' authorities said. Yarborough said that in April 1988 he heard reports of paramilitary activities and threats against other people. Authorities investigated the reports, but pressed no charges. The group left the Kirtland area in April 1989 and showed up in Davis, W.Va., a rugged, coal-mining area, where they camped out in tents until mid-October. They planted a large garden and built a 15-foot wooden bridge across a stream. ``I thought, `Gee, they're not doing anything worse than a Boy Scout group would do,''' Davis conservation officer Harold Spencer told The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer. Lundgren and his followers next traveled to Chilhowee, Mo., where they lived in a barn, said Yarborough. Then they disbanded, probably sometime in December, investigators said.

DOC.HEAD: US Praises Rebel Readiness To Talk
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of a visit to the United States by Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani, both his government and the leftist rebels are showing signs of moderating their policies with an eye on the U.S. Congress. The State Department on Friday welcomed as a ``positive development'' a rebel announcement that they are willing to renew peace negotiations with the U.S.-backed government under United Nations auspices. The rebels proposed a meeting within 30 days and the government accepted the offer but U.S. officials noted that previous attempts since 1984 to negotiate a settlement have all failed. The timing of the rebel announcement suggested an interest in generating good will with Congress, where there is some sentiment for scaling back on U.S. aid commitment to the government. Some lawmakers called the aid commitment into question following the massacre of six Jesuit priests two months ago. Cristiani blunted that criticism somewhat last weekend when he said ``elements of the armed forces'' were responsible for the killings. This indicated Salvadoran authorities were serious about their investigation. Nonetheless, Cristiani, whose government is heavily dependent on U.S. military and economic aid for its survival, is expected to face tough questions from members of Congress when he visits Washington next week. Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., said Friday Cristiani has predicted the investigation into the murders of the priests will be completed within a week. Moakley, chairman of a House task force on El Salvador, said the probe has made ``substantial progress but I worry that the possibility of a coverup remains.'' ``Those who ordered or otherwise consented to the crime must also be brought to justice,'' he said. Meanwhile, representatives of international organizations said Friday that relief workers in El Salvador are being harassed and even tortured by the military. But they said Cristiani seemed willing to end those abuses. ``Churches, social welfare organizations, trade unions and associations of cooperatives have had staff detained and offices raided, ransacked and sometimes destroyed or occupied by the military,'' said a statement from a six-member delegation of the International Council for Voluntary Agencies. ``Files and office equipment have been confiscated and international staff colleagues expelled,'' said the delegation, which just completed a three-day tour of El Salvador and a visit to Capitol Hill and the State Department. The council, based in Geneva, represents organizations involved in humanitarian relief and development cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Says Individual, Not Group, May Be Behind Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Some investigators are leaning toward the theory that an elderly loner, rather than an organized racist group, is behind mail bomb attacks in three states that left a judge and an attorney dead. ``We feel he is 50 or older, is a loner and someone not known to associate with any of the white hate groups,'' said FBI special agent Charles Archer of Mobile, Ala. ``We have no information that the (Ku Klux) Klan or any similar groups are involved in any of the bombings.'' But in Atlanta, the man who is coordinating the federal investigation of the bombs said the case has not yet been narrowed to a single suspect. ``There are suspects all over the place,'' said FBI Special Agent William Hinshaw of Atlanta. Early in the investigation of the December mail bombings, authorities said it appeared an organized white supremacist group could be responsible. A letter claimed responsibility for the attacks in the name of the previously unknown ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System.'' Al Adams, a spokesman for the Postal Inspection Service in Atlanta, which also is involved in the investigation, said authorities are not close enough yet to solving the case that anyone can be ruled out. But he said he believed that if a large group were involved in the plot, at least one member by now would have come forward. ``Even though a white supremacist group is subject to do this, someone would disagree with murdering a federal judge,'' Adams said. Adams said the large number of leads in the case have been divided among the FBI, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and his office. The FBI, meanwhile, confirmed that threatening letters have been sent to five judges or courts in Ohio, including the Supreme Court. Douglass Ogden, senior supervisor in charge of the FBI's Columbus, Ohio, office, would not say whether the letters contained death threats or disclose further details. He said threats against judges are not unusual. ``But attention is being a little more focused because of what is going on down South,'' he said. The bombs killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance near Birmingham, Ala., and Savannah, Ga., civil rights attorney Robert Robinson. Bombs delivered to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court offices in Atlanta and to an NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla., were safely intercepted.

DOC.HEAD: Four Cities, Southwest Border Targeted in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials plan to send extra money and resources to New York City, Miami, Houston, Los Angeles and almost the entire Southwest border to fight drug trafficking, according to administration sources. The sources, speaking to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said the metropolitan areas and border region are to be designated high-intensity drug trafficking areas, qualifying them for the new federal assistance. It is unclear how much help those areas will get because of the designation. In the current fiscal year, only $25 million has been allocated for high-intensity localities. However, that could increase by up to $21 million with money coming from assets seized from drug traffickers, Reggie Walton, associate director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said last month. An administration official, who spoke Friday on condition of anonymity, said the total federal effort in the designated areas ``probably will be over $1 billion,'' when such things as temporarily reassigned federal agents and military efforts along the border are figured in. An updated National Drug Control Strategy _ required by Congress _ is expected to be announced at the end of January. The original version was announced by President Bush last September. Sources contacted by the AP Friday had seen drafts of the new strategy, which went to the White House Domestic Policy Council on Thursday and to Bush on Friday. One source said the strategy calls for the areas around the actual cities to be including in the strategy to fight drugs. When William J. Bennett, director of the drug control office, designated Washington, D.C., as a test case for future high-intensity drug trafficking areas last spring, leaders of surrounding cities and counties protested that the problems don't end at the capital's borders. They suggested that problems could simply be pushed into the surrounding areas. In addition to the metropolitan areas, the new strategy designates 34 counties along the Southwest border as high-intensity drug-trafficking areas. The strategy also outlines broader federal drug crimes for which the death penalty can be imposed, in line with the changes Bush said he wanted to make last year. Under the proposals, the death penalty could be imposed on drug kingpins even when they or their organizations have not killed anyone. The death penalty could be imposed if the attorney general approves the indictment and if, on conviction, the jury found serious aggravating factors, a source said. ``This is basically following through on implementing the president's agenda vis a vis nasty, felonious drug traffickers,'' the source said. Interdiction efforts by the Customs Service and the Coast Guard will not get more money under the strategy. But military expenditures on border control will increase from some $313 million in 1990 to about $1.2 billion in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Meets With Noriega Attorneys; Co-Defendant's Bail Set
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's attorneys met with his trial judge amid speculation the government would move the ousted Panamanian dictator from the courthouse basement to a more secure federal facility. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler met with Noriega's attorneys in a closed-door session Friday, reportedly to discuss the government's interest in moving him to federal prisons in Atlanta or Marion, Ill. Noriega attorney Frank Rubino said he would fight any effort to move Noriega from south Florida on the grounds that it would make it difficult for him to meet with his client. Hoeveler refused to comment on the meeting. Noriega is accused in a February 1988 federal indictment of using Panama to protect cocaine shipments heading north and southbound drug-processing chemicals and drug money. Rubino said he and co-counsel Steven Kollin have been joined on the defense team by David Lewis of New York. Lewis, an attorney in the ``Pizza Connection'' mob case, is considered an expert on the federal Classified Information Protection Act, expertise needed because of Noriega's longtime association with the CIA. The New York office of attorney Barry Slotnick, who represented subway gunman Bernhard Goetz, issued a statement Friday saying the firm ``has decided it does not wish to be part of the (Noriega) defense effort.'' Houston attorney Richard ``Racehorse'' Haynes also was reported to have expressed interest in the Noriega case. But Rubino told The Associated Press Friday that when he mentioned Slotnick and Haynes to Noriega, the deposed dictator said he had not contacted them. ``He told me that he is satisfied with our representation and whoever we get,'' Rubino said. ``David Lewis is the first we've added, but we're going to get four or six more from all over the country _ the best in their fields, in their specialties.'' U.S. Magistrate Peter Palermo on Friday set bail at $1 million for Noriega co-defendant Daniel Miranda, 36, who is charged with flying $800,000 in drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. Miranda's attorney, Michael O'Kane, said they would be able to post the bond. But prosecutors immediately filed an appeal of the ruling and temporarily blocked his client's release. O'Kane appeared in court with a bandaged head and explained that he had been attacked by a masked man with a crowbar in front of his home. Police later said they had a suspect in the attack in custody, and identified him as a person hired by a former client of the attorney's.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at the Long Duration Exposure Facility
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the Long Duration Exposure Facility satellite which has been in space for nearly six years: _ LDEF carries coating and thermal systems experiments; five power and propulsion experiments; 17 science experiments; 14 electronics and optics experiments and 21 materials used in space flight, including metals, graphite epoxies, polymers, resins and thermal coatings. Scientists want to know if materials' strength properties changed and if mechanical systems still work. _ Experts will also study the satellite's frame, bolts, batteries and electric motors to see how it survived the long space trip. _ Experiments on LDEF have been subjected to space's environment _ extreme temperatures, a near-vacuum, microgravity, micrometeoroids, cosmic radiation, corrosive atomic oxygen, and other things from outer space. _ Some other experiments aboard include one designed to collect interplanetary dust that could reveal information about the sun and planets. Also aboard are 12.5 million tomato seeds for student experiments and research into such things as germination rates, chromosome and population genetics studies and full tomato growth. _ The satellite will be taken to an extremely clean building at the Kennedy Space Center for examination by teams expert in materials, spacecraft systems, radiation and space debris. The experiments will then be distributed to their individual investigators.

DOC.HEAD: Joint U.S.-Soivet Bering Strait Park Planned
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Soviet Union are expanding their environmental cooperation, including plans for an international park spanning the Bering Strait. Acting under a 1972 agreement, the Environmental Protection Agency and its Soviet counterpart are expanding cooperation into 45 areas, including the exchange of information on scientific and regulatory issues, officials from the two agencies said Friday. Taking their cue from the United States, for example, the Soviets are ``developing a program in which leaded gas would be banned'' by 1996 or 1998, said Valentin G. Sokolovskiy, deputy chairman of the State Committee on Environmental Protection. William K. Reilly, the EPA administrator, said cooperation would include preparation for a conference on global warming proposed by President Bush at the superpower summit in Malta last month. ``We began the week with 37 projects and we ended with about 45,'' Reilly told the news conference. Areas of cooperation included: _Remote sensing of atmospheric pollutants. _Wetlands management. _Historic preservation. _Seismological monitoring, along the lines of an exchange of scientists that took place after the 1988 earthquake in Soviet Armenia and the tremor that shook San Francisco last October. By the end of 1991 the U.S. and Soviet governments hope to form a jointly managed preserve on both sides of the Bering Strait that separates Alaska and Siberia, said an EPA spokesman, Sean McElheny. The plan stems from talks the two nations held last September, he said. For years, Soviet officials denied they had significant environmental problems, but the issue has been widely discussed under the reforms of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The greater Soviet emphasis on environmental problems has lent new energy to official U.S.-Soviet meetings on the issue, of which the four-day session this week was the 12th. Moscow's new interest in the environment has created some stress in the official relationship, however, because, unlike the American delegate, the Soviet entourage included a representative from a recently formed non-government group. The private Soviet delegate was Maria V. Cherkasova, of the Social-Ecological Union, formed in December 1988 as a consortium of some 120 groups in 260 cities and towns. The Soviet environment is in a disastrous state requiring ``urgent attention,'' she said, stressing problems with children's health. ``I feel that great movement has been made in the past year'' by the Soviet government to protect the environment, she told reporters after the news conference. ``But it seems that the American side does not realize the full extent'' of Soviet environmental problems, she said. During her stay, she said she formed contacts with several private U.S. environmental groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, Greenpeace International, the Audubon Society and the Sierra Club. David Wirth, an attorney from the Natural Resources Defense Council, complained in a statement read at a bilateral session on Wednesday that the original 1972 agreement was ``underutilized.'' Wirth proposed U.S.-Soviet cooperation to curb emissions of carbon dioxide, which are widely blamed for a perceived global warming trend. And he said the two governments should monitor joint business ventures to ensure that U.S. pollutants, such as some pesticides, are not sold to the Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Wife To Return Voluntarily To Answer Ohio Charges
With PM-Cult-Massacre, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The wife of the cult leader charged in the murders of five members of a family will waive extradition procedures and return voluntarily to Ohio, reversing an earlier decision, her attorney said. Alice Lundgren, 38, who has been jailed at the Las Colinas Women's Detention Facility since she being captured with her husband and son last Sunday, will appear in court Tuesday to sign the extradition waiver, attorney Kay Sunday said. ``I happen to believe she's innocent,'' Sunday said Friday night. ``She wants to go back and start working on her case and so it can come out that she's innocent. She has nothing to hide.'' Mrs. Lundgren last Tuesday joined her husband, Jeffrey Lundgren, 39, and son, Damon, in refusing at a court hearing to waive extradition procedures. The three have been indicted, along with 10 others, in the alleged ritualistic slayings of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three young daughters. The refusals by the Lundgrens triggered formal extradition proceedings that could take 90 days to bring about the fugitives' forced return. Sunday said Mrs. Lundgren had nothing do with the killings. She declined to elaborate. ``I probably will have more to say after her extradition on Tuesday but I can't say anything right now,'' Sunday said. ``What I can say is she's in the safest place she's been in a long time and she doesn't have anything to fear, now.'' Mrs. Lundgren's husband and son are jailed without bail at a separate facility. Lundgren, a self-proclaimed prophet, was a lay minister in the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Ohio before being ousted for radical teachings. He persuaded other members to follow him after his ouster and the splinter group went to live on a 15-acre farm near Kirtland, Ohio, where the Averys' bodies were unearthed last week. They apparently were slain in April.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Finishes Radiation Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush is finished with the radiation treatments for a stubborn eye ailment that has impaired her vision but will not know for at least two months how effective the treatments have been. The first lady underwent the last of 10 radiation treatments on Friday, said Anna Perez, Mrs. Bush's press secretary. After receiving the 10-minute radiation dose at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Mrs. Bush returned to the White House and took her daily swim in the outdoor, heated swimming pool, said Ms. Perez. She also attended a briefing on the Head Start education program, hosting volunteers from the organization. ``She feels great,'' said Ms. Perez. Doctors will not know for at least two months, and maybe as long as four, whether the radiation was effective in treating the symptoms of Graves' disease, an immune system disorder that earlier affected Mrs. Bush's thyroid as well, said Ms. Perez. Mrs. Bush began the radiation treatments after the steroid drug prednisone failed to improve her eyes. She suffers eye irritation, double vision and bulging eyes as a result of the Graves' disease, which was diagnosed early last year. The disease initially caused her thyroid to be overproductive, but a one-time radioactive treatment rendered the thyroid inactive and cured that effect of the disease. The low-level radiation treatments were intended to decrease swelling behind the eyes, in the small muscles that control eye movement. Although suffering from eye irritation, Mrs. Bush has maintained a schedule of public appearances, both with her husband and by herself. Should the radiation fail, surgery would be an option, experts say.
