DOC.HEAD: Mr. Z Sets Washington, Academe Abuzz
INSERTS 3 grafs after 16th graf pvs, ``The West..., to UPDATE with report that William Odom is `Z;' picks up 17th pvs, `Much of...
DOC.TEXT: Even before the article was published, the foreign policy establishment and the academic world were abuzz. When it appeared, copies of a high-brow journal with a slender circulation were suddenly in high demand. The article in Daedalus was about U.S.-Soviet relations and it was signed with the provocative pseudonym ``Z,'' a clear allusion to the 1947 article, signed ``X,'' that laid the theoretical framework for the Cold War policy of containment. X's article, published in the journal Foreign Affairs, later was acknowledged to be the work of George F. Kennan, a State Department official who later became ambassador to the Soviet Union and one of the nation's leading diplomats. Speculation about the identity of Z began last Thursday, when excerpts from the Daedalus article appeared on the opinion page of The New York Times. Washington was soon alive with rumors that the author was a well-placed government official _ perhaps even a well-placed Soviet government official. The article takes a dim view of Mikhail Gorbachev's chances of making the Soviet system economically efficient and politically democratic while maintaining the primacy of the Communist Party. ``The fundamental structures of the Leninist system reached an inextricable impasse at the end of the 1970s, and the mounting contradictions of perestroika indicate that the system cannot be restructured or reformed, but can only stagnate or be dismantled and replaced by market institutions over a long period of time,'' Z wrote. Daedalus, a literary and philosophical quarterly published by the 210-year-old American Academy of Arts and Sciences in Cambridge, Mass., printed 23,000 copies of today's edition _ 3,000 more than usual _ and expects to issue many reprints, said its editor, Stephen Graubard. Graubard, however, was hardly ecstatic about his publishing coup. Instead, the 65-year-old editor was ruminating about the ``frivolity'' of the American media _ and fuming about allegations that the pseudonym was hype. ``I want people to read it and say whether they agree or disagree,'' Graubard said in a telephone interview. ``This is a very serious subject, and so far I have yet to see an analysis of what was said _ as opposed to a guessing game about who said it.'' Graubard refused to name the author or explain why a pseudonym was used, except to say that there were ``compelling reasons'' to protect the writer's identity. As to the allegation by columnist Patrick Buchanan that the Z byline was ``just clever hype,'' Graubard was indignant. ``All you have to do is read Daedalus to know we don't go in for hype,'' he said. Z argues that it is futile for the United States to try to help Gorbachev succeed in his avowed aims of democratizing the communist system and revitalizing the Soviet economy. But the article contends the West can play a constructive role, primarily by investing in the Soviet Union's emerging private sector _ ``without triumphalism about capitalism's superiority, and with due sensitivity to Soviet national pride.'' ``The West's aim should be to encourage the change of Soviet realities while leaving the old labels intact,'' the article says. The Arkansas Democrat reported today that it had determined Z was retired Lt. Gen. William Odom, the former director of the National Security Agency. The newspaper quoted William E. Jackson Jr., an international relations professor at the University of Arkansas as saying Odom, a close friend, was Z. Odom, reached Friday in Middlebury, Vt., gave a cryptic response. He denied that he was Z, but said the newspaper's reporter would be correct in quoting Jackson. ``You can write what he says,'' said Odom, who in September was quoted as warning that it was unlikely a liberal democracy would be established in the Soviet Union, and that reforms there could lead to chaos. Much of the speculation about Z's identity has focused on Robert M. Gates, President Bush's deputy national security adviser. Gates had planned to give a speech late last year expressing pessimism about Gorbachev's chances of success, but was blocked by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who reportedly felt such sentiments were inappropriate about the time of the Malta summit. Gates denied through the White House press office on Friday that he is Z. Another possible author is Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser under President Carter. Brzezinski declined to discuss the article, but did not expressly deny writing it. New York Times writer Flora Lewis suggested in her column today that Z was Dennis Ross, head of the State Department's policy planning staff. After the original ``X'' article appeared in July 1947, Kennan was identified as the author within a matter of days. Now a historian at the Institute for Advanced Studies in Princeton, N.J., Kennan declined to discuss the Z article. Graubard said he believes Z's article is ``infinitely more provocative'' than the Mr. X article was in its day, but not all scholars agreed. ``The sense of it is that we should help the Russians right now, but whether Gorbachev succeeds or fails is going to be decided inside the Soviet Union,'' said Adam Ulam, director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University. ``It's a sensible but not terribly original point of view.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Could Cut Minuteman 2 Missiles
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force is proposing to retire all 450 Minuteman 2 intercontinental ballistic missiles at a savings of $400 million a year, a newspaper reported today. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has tentatively accepted the proposal, The Washington Post said, and will discuss it with congressional leaders next week before making a final decision. A Defense Department spokesman, Air Force Lt. Col. Richard Oborn, said late Friday that he had no information on the matter. The newspaper quoted unnamed officials who cautioned that President Bush might withdraw the proposal before he presents his fiscal year 1991 budget to Congress on Jan. 29. Meanwhile, Cheney on Friday ordered a freeze on hiring civilians at the Defense Department for the rest of this fiscal year. Cheney said in a statement he took the step to cut costs and because of sweeping international changes. The release announcing the step cautioned that ``department officials do not know how much the work force will be reduced by the freeze.'' In effect until Sept. 30, the hiring freeze applies to all Department of Defense civilians worldwide, including part-time and temporary employees. The department currently employs 927,000 civilians full-time and another 123,000 on a temporary or part-time. As many as 80,000 workers normally retire or otherwise leave that work force each year, the Pentagon said. The Minuteman 2, based at Malmstrom Air Force Base, Mont.; Ellsworth Air Force Base, S.D., and Whiteman Air Force Base, Mo., carries a single warhead with an explosive force estimated at 1.2 megatons, or the equivalent of 1.2 million tons of TNT. That is 80 times the power of the atomic bomb that destroyed the Japanese city of Hiroshima in 1945. These are the last warheads in the U.S. arsenal greater than one megaton in destructive power. Compared with later missiles, the Minuteman 2 is relatively inaccurate. Published estimates say half the missiles launched would land within 1,200 feet to 2,000 feet of the point of aim. Similar estimates for the 550 deployed Minuteman 3 missiles, which carry three smaller warheads, are from 600 feet to 700 feet. In addition to the Minuteman, the nation's land-based missiles include 50 MX ``Peacekeeper'' missiles with 10 warheads each. Counting other missiles and bombs, the Minuteman 2 force represents about 3.5 percent of the nation's strategic nuclear warheads. The Bush administration has proposed building a new ``Midgetman'' single-warhead missile that could be moved about on giant trucks, much more difficult to hit than known, fixed positions such as current Minuteman silos. Because they are so old and inaccurate, the Minuteman 2 missiles have been candidates for retirement for some time. The administration told Congress last summer that a likely strategic nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union would mean significant reductions in missiles on both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Disneyland to be Expanded, Second Theme Park Considered
DOC.TEXT: A 1990s Disneyland expansion that will draw on the power of Hollywood and the charm of Disney's cartoon characters has been unveiled along with plans for a second Southern California park. Walt Disney Co. Chairman Michael Eisner on Friday detailed plans for more than a dozen new rides, shows and films in two new Disneyland theme areas and an updated Tomorrowland section. Eisner dubbed the '90s the ``Disney decade,'' citing the scheduled opening of a $2.5 billion European Disneyland, expansion of Disney World in Florida and growing attendance at the Tokyo Disneyland. He said negotiations for construction of a second theme park are under way with city officials in Anaheim and Long Beach, where Disney already owns the historic Queen Mary ocean liner and Spruce Goose wooden seaplane attractions. The original Disney theme park in Anaheim, 30 miles south of Los Angeles, is celebrating its 35th anniversary this year. An expansion billed as the most ambitious in the park's history will begin in 1991, with themes based on the films of George Lucas, Steven Spielberg and others. A new theme area to be completed in early 1999 will recreate the '30s and '40s movie era, with an ``idealized Hollywood Boulevard'' offering shops and restaurants. Hollywoodland also will include ``Toontown Trolley'' and ``Baby Herman's Runaway Baby Buggy Ride'' attractions based on the Spielberg-produced movie ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' Also planned is a ``Great Movie Ride,'' which debuted at the Disney-MGM Studios at Walt Disney World last year and which puts parkgoers in the middle of classic movie scenes. Disney operates theme parks and resorts in Anaheim, Orlando, Fla., Tokyo and the one under construction in Paris. The Burbank-based company has pumped an estimated $1.5 billion into its expanding parks during the past five years.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Friend To Appeal Ruling Of Liability In Murder Of Regime Foes
DOC.TEXT: Two allies of former Philippines ruler Ferdinand Marcos were found liable in the murders of two cannery union members and ordered to pay their survivors at least $8.4 million. U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein found conclusive evidence Friday that Constantine ``Tony'' Baruso and Leonilo Malabed drew from a fund established to battle Marcos opponents in the United States to arrange the deaths of Silme Domingo and Gene Viernes, slain in the Seattle offices of the Alaska Cannery Workers Union in 1981. ``This is wonderful,'' said Jeff Robinson, one of the attorneys for the families. Rothstein's ruling awarded $6,669,000 to the estate of Domingo and $1,727,800 to Viernes' survivors, with a ``pain and suffering'' portion to be decided later. Malabed's attorney, Kate Alfieri of San Francisco, said she would appeal the ruling. Baruso's attorney, Anthony Savage of Seattle, could not be reached for comment. Baruso was president of the union when the killings occurred. Although his gun was used in the shootings, he was never criminally charged. Malabed allegedly ran Marcos' West Coast intelligence operation and controlled a slush fund for ``security projects'' against Marcos opponents. His testimony ``vacillated between a total lack of memory and outright fabrication,'' said Rothstein, who concluded Malabed's fund provided Baruso $15,000 for the murders. Baruso was found liable for conspiracy to monitor, harass, intimidate and operate against Marcos opponents while Malabed was found liable for the conspiracy charge and for negligence for not keeping the intelligence operations in check. The late Marcos and his wife, Imelda, were found liable on Dec. 15 for running an intelligence network that spied on foes of his regime. They were ordered to pay $15 million to the families of Domingo and Viernes. Marcos was ousted as president of the Philippines in 1986 and fled to Hawaii, where he died in September. Michael Withey, lead attorney for the plaintiffs, said he would meet Monday with King County Prosecutor Norm Maleng about reopening a criminal investigation of the case. Three men were convicted in 1981 and 1982 of murdering Domingo and Viernes but those trials did not conclude the existence of a Marcos-linked conspiracy, although testimony indicated Baruso traveled to San Francisco and picked up $15,000 from a Philippines intelligence fund to pay for the killings. Malabed, in depositions, admitted he maintained a fund through the Mabuhay Corp. from which he made payments to a Philippines official for ``broadcast projects'' in this country. He maintained that he did not know specifically where that money went. Malabed also admitted he signed a Mabuhay expense account that listed several ``special security projects,'' including a May 17, 1981, entry for $15,000 that plaintiffs claimed was used to pay for the murders. Baruso denied he knew Malabed, but Rothstein said she found the plaintiffs presented overwhelming evidence that Baruso was directly involved in the murders of Domingo and Viernes. She said Baruso promised to pay $5,000 to the killers and that the murder weapon was Baruso's. The civil trial had a lower standard of proof than the ``beyond a reasonable doubt'' proof required in criminal trials. The conspiracy count required a showing of ``clear, cogent and convincing'' evidence, and the negligence count a showing of a ``preponderance'' of evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Secretary Pledges to Push for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today that a timetable for direct elections in Hong Kong would be set in the next few weeks, despite worsening ties with China. Arriving in Hong Kong, Hurd also said the colony will continue its forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people even though the move has prompted widespread international condemnation. Hurd said he expected ground rules to be set soon for elections in Hong Kong next year. China, which takes over the colony in 1997, has called efforts to speed up the democratization of the territory a plot ``to bring the Chinese government to its knees.'' Hurd said that while Britain would consider Beijing's views, it would decide by itself how to proceed with the voting. ``We are not going to sit back as the British government passively and let the clock tick on,'' he told reporters at Hong Kong's international airport. ``Cool and considered'' was how he described the way decisions will be made that will critically effect the lives of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people. Communist China takes over Hong Kong in 1997 and has promised to preserve Hong Kong's free-wheeling economic and social system for at least 50 years. But confidence in China's promise evaporated after the bloody crackdown June 3-4 on the movement for democracy in Beijing. Relations between Hong Kong and the mainland have sunk to their lowest level since the ultra-leftist Cultural Revolution of the 1960s. A series of disagreements between London and Beijing and pro-democracy agitation in Hong Kong have further worsened ties. To complicate the issue, many in Hong Kong feel Britain has abandoned the colony and is kowtowing to the Beijing government. Protests are expected during Hurd's visit and security will be tight. His visit, his first to Hong Kong as foreign secretary, follows unproductive meetings between Hong Kong's governor, Sir David Wilson, and Chinese leaders in Beijing. Wilson returned Friday and will confer with Hurd. The governor had sharp exchanges with several Chinese leaders over the pace of democratic change in Hong Kong. Wilson called the talks ``frank,'' and Hurd described them as ``workman-like,'' diplomatic buzzwords for unsuccessful. Time is running out for determining the future of the colony. A committee of Chinese-appointed officials is expected to complete by March the Basic Law, the blueprint for the territory after 1997. The main point of contention concerns the pace and extent of democraticization in this colony, one of Asia's economic successes. China wants only 30 percent of the legislature, or 18 seats, elected after 1997 but Britain has been pushing for about 50 percent. The executive and legislative branches of Hong Kong's current government have called for at least 20 seats to be put up for election in 1991. British and Hong Kong activists say a quicker transition to democracy would create a political system better able to withstand an unstable government in Beijing. But with hard-liners firmly in power, China's leadership views talk of more democracy in Hong Kong as a threat. Hong Kong's economy and society have far greater influence on China's 1 billion people than its comparatively small population would suggest. Hurd said the ground rules for the 1991 elections would be the ``first step on a new path for Hong Kong, direct elections.'' Hurd also pledged that Britain would continue sending Vietnamese boat people home against their will. ``We have set the policy,'' he said. ``We have decided.'' United Nations talks on the boat people question, originally scheduled for next week, were postponed Friday in Geneva. The United States, which opposes Britain's policy, reportedly asked for the delay. More than 40,000 Vietnamese are languishing in squalid detention centers and will be sent back to Vietnam unless they can prove they face political persecution in their Communist homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler with Transplanted Liver, Donor Mother, Return To Texas
LaserPhotos SA2
DOC.TEXT: Greeted by a cheering homecoming crowd, Teresa Smith said she had no regrets about giving part of her liver to help save her daughter Alyssa. ``I feel real good. She's doing super,'' Mrs. Smith said Friday night, after she and her 23-month-old daughter stepped off a jet that brought them home from Chicago. ``We feel like we did what was best in the medical interest of our child, of Alyssa.'' About 200 friends, family and city leaders from the Smiths' hometown of Schertz, a San Antonio suburb, were present to shower the puzzled-looking toddler and her mother with gifts. Her mother said Alyssa was ``sedate'' on the plane ride home. But Mrs. Smith, her husband John Smith and relieved relatives did plenty of celebrating. ``It's exciting,'' John Smith said. ``They're home _ home for good.'' Added his wife: ``It's just good to be home ... This is overwhelming.'' Mrs. Smith gave about 40 percent of her liver to her daughter in November during the nation's first living-donor liver transplant, at the University of Chicago Medical Center. Alyssa suffered from biliary atresia, a congenital disorder that could have been fatal without the transplant, doctors said. The girl must visit her San Antonio physicians each week for checkups and continue taking drugs to prevent her body from rejecting the new liver. ``We've received letters from all over the nation, not only from parents whose children are in a similar situation, but also from Alyssa Smiths all over the country,'' her mother said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders Hallmark-TV Deal Re-Examined
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court is ordering the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider its approval of the 1986 sale of six Spanish-language television stations to a division of Hallmark Cards. A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington said Friday the commission apparently violated its own rules for license transfers when it allowed the sale to take place before completing an investigation into claims that foreigners had excessive influence over the stations. Spanish International Communications Corp. and Bahia de San Francisco sold the stations to Univision Holdings, a subsidiary of Kansas City, Mo.-based Hallmark, in 1986 for $309.6 million after an FCC administrative law judge denied SICC and Bahia's license renewal applications. Hallmark spokesman Charles Hucker on Friday said the case was a procedural matter and ``We anticipate no impact on us. Univision continues to operate the stations.'' Univision paid $286 million for SICC stations KMEX-TV, Los Angeles; WLTV, Miami; KWEX-TV, San Antonio; WXTV, Paterson, N.J.; and KFTV, Hanford, Calif. The company paid $23.6 million for Bahia's KDTV, San Francisco.
DOC.HEAD: GAO Probe of FDA, Milk Hormone Sought
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee wants congressional auditors to investigate the Food and Drug Administration's approval of a genetically engineered hormone to boost cows' milk production. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., asked the General Accounting Office to investigate a complaint by a fired FDA veterinarian, Dr. Richard Burroughs, that the agency ignored flaws in a safety study of a genetically engineered version of bovine somatotropin. ``Congress is being asked with increasing frequency to reach conclusions about whether particular products of biotechnology have been adequately reviewed and whether use of these products may present unacceptable risks ...,'' Leahy said in a letter to the GAO. A copy of the letter was provided to The Associated Press on Friday. Burroughs told Leahy's staff that he noticed problems with reproduction and mastitis _ inflamed udders _ in cows injected with the genetically engineered version of the hormone when he was assigned in 1986 through 1988 to review private research on it. He said FDA toned down his criticism of the research at the request of chemical companies seeking approval to market the hormone commercially. Richard Lehmann, director of the division of production drugs at FDA, said milk from cows injected with the genetically engineered hormone contained no more than normal amounts of bovine somatotropin and is safe to drink.
DOC.HEAD: Precautions on Travel to China Lifted
DOC.TEXT: U.S. travelers in China can feel free again to go out after dark in Beijing as a result of lifting martial law there, according to the State Department. Responding to China's lifting of marital law on Thursday, U.S. officials said precautions recommended beforehand are no longer in effect. Prior to China's announcement Thursday, the department had warned travelers to exercise caution in sections of Beijing where there was a significant presence of armed security forces because of martial law. Visitors also were advised to refrain from photographing troops or military installations. The new advisory deletes these references to the need for precautions in Beijing but notes the travelers should still be aware that visits to certain areas of the country are prohibited without permission. It also notes that there are special restrictions on travel to the Tibetan capital of Lhasa. Chinese authorities imposed martial law on sections of central Beijing last June as part of an effort to quell anti-government demonstrations.

DOC.HEAD: Unrest Reported; Albanian Leader Denies It
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrations and gunfire were reported in Albania, but a senior Albanian Communist denied the accounts and others that emergency security measures had been imposed. The Yugoslav news agency Tanjug and Belgrade television said Friday that ``something is apparently happening'' over the border in hard-line Albania and that authorities had taken ``brutal'' measures against dissent. The reports did not elaborate. Tanjug said the new security measures ``can be termed a state of emergency,'' but did not say when they were imposed. The news agency did not attribute its information. Belgrade television cited unconfirmed reports from diplomats and travelers from Albania, who are rare. Milisav Milic, a reporter for Belgrade TV in Yugoslavia's southern Kosovo province that borders Albania, told The Associated Press the ``frequent sound of firearms'' was heard Friday from the direction of Albania. Milic, in a telephone interview, quoted an ethnic Albanian returning home to Kosovo from Albania as saying demonstrations took place in the towns of Durres, Shkoder and Korcha ``the last couple of days.'' The witness also was quoted as saying leaflets by ``dissatisfied Albanian military officers'' appeared in Tirana, the capital. No details of their contents were available. The Yugoslav newspaper Politika said Thursday a state of emergency was declared in Shkoder. It said Shkoder, about 60 miles northwest of Tirana on the Yugoslav border, is the center of Albanian dissent. Foto Cami, a member of Albania's ruling Communist Party Politburo, rejected recent reports in Yugoslav, Greek and other foreign media of unrest in his country as ``slander'' and ``anti-Albanian inventions.'' His remarks came in an interview with Albanian state radio and television, carried by the official Albanian news agency ATA and monitored in Vienna, Austria. Most of the East bloc's hard-line leaders lost power last year and Albania is viewed as the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe. Some Western analysts see it as the next country to undergo radical change, but its isolation and small population of 3 million are among the factors that make Albania different from other communist countries in the region. Relations between Albania and Yugoslavia have long been strained over unrest in Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians make up 85 percent of the Yugoslav province's population.

DOC.HEAD: Comatose Woman who had Abortion Improving
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion activists said they were pleased by the recovery of a New York woman who had an abortion while she was in a coma after a long fight by her husband to counter their efforts to save the fetus. Doctors of Nancy Klein initially believed her recovery prospects were slim, and her physician said Friday that the gradual improvement she has made would have been impossible if she remained pregnant. Doctors performed the operation 11 months ago, after her husband Martin Klein fought abortion foes all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, eventually becoming his wife's legal guardian and gaining the authority to approve the abortion. Dr. Caroline O. McCagg said the woman's recovery has been spurred by her determination to get home to her husband and their 4-year-old daughter, Arielle, in Upper Brookville, N.Y. ``She likes seeing Arielle. That really perks her up,'' said McCagg. McCagg said Mrs. Klein doesn't remember the Dec. 13, 1988 car collision that put her in a coma when she was 18 weeks pregnant. She also knows nothing about the controversy surrounding her case, the doctor said. But she can now recall some things from before the accident, and has recovered her speech, the ability to feed herself and learned to use a wheelchair to get around the Robert Wood Johnson Jr. Rehabilitation Institute. McCagg said Mrs. Klein's pregnancy would have ruled out the use of antibiotics and anti-seizure medicines that have contributed to the woman's recovery. ``The abortion has facilitated her rehabilitation,'' the doctor said. Because of it, she said, ``we could be more vigorous with her physical therapy.'' John Short, one of the activists who tried in court to stop the abortion, said from his Farmingdale, N.Y., home, ``Naturally, I'm happy for Nancy Klein. I just feel sad the child won't be there to help her in her recovery.'' ``I hope she doesn't have to go through the trauma of asking, `Where is my child,' and having to be told it was killed,'' he said. Mrs. Klein was admitted to the institute in March. She began to communicate last summer, answering yes-and-no questions by pressing a button, and learned to spell out words on a letter board shortly after that. McCagg, medical director of the institute's Center for Head Injuries, said Mrs. Klein is able to make it through the tough therapeutic program when hospital workers tell her, ``This is going to get you home.'' Three months ago she began using a wheelchair, and began talking about two months ago, McCagg said. Mrs. Klein's mother, Anne Zusselman of Delray Beach, Fla., termed the recovery ``a miracle.'' Zusselman said her daughter has made two weekend visits to her Long Island home and has visited her sister, who lives in New Jersey about a 40-minute drive from the hospital. ``We are pleased about Nancy's recovery up 'til now,'' Martin Klein said. ``We remain hopeful that she will continue to recover as well in the days ahead.'' McCagg said complete recovery is unusual in cases involving such severe head injuries. He said Mrs. Klein is expected to remain in the hospital for at least six more months. Mrs. Klein's treatment has cost at least $250,000, according to a hospital spokesman, and ``she still has a long way to go. It's been very slow, very persistent progress,'' McCagg said.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Says Police Forced Him to Incriminate Black in Stuart Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dereck cq in 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager said police threatened him with a 20-year prison sentence to pressure him into implicating a black man in the shooting death of pregnant Carole Stuart and the wounding of her husband. Blacks in Boston have criticized police for not initially considering Stuart a suspect in the Oct. 23 shooting of his wife. Stuart, who had blamed the attack on a black mugger, committed suicide Jan. 4 when police got new information that he had shot his wife and himself. The case drew widespread attention because of a dramatic conversation between Charles Stuart, using his car telephone, and a police dispatcher in which Stuart eventually directed police to him and his wife. Dereck Jackson, 17, told reporters for two newspapers Friday that Boston police investigators intimidated him into saying he had heard William Bennett, 39, confess to shooting the Stuarts in a car in the city's Mission Hill neighborhood. Bennett, who was arrested on an unrelated charge, was never charged in the Stuart shootings, but was frequently named in police leaks to reporters in the Stuart case. The Boston Globe and Boston Herald today quoted Jackson saying the only true information he gave authorities was relating a comment made to him by a friend, Bennett's 15-year-old nephew, Joey Bennett. Jackson said he asked if William Bennett was involved in the Stuart shootings and Joey replied, ``Yeah,'' and laughed. He said that when he initially refused to go beyond that statement, Boston Police Detective Peter J. O'Malley called him a liar and told him he could go to the state's maximum security prison at Walpole for 20 years. Jackson said he then told police he heard Bennett confess to the shootings. Jackson said he went to police to recant his false statements one day later, but eventually went back to saying Bennett confessed. Boston police reached for comment today referred questions to Suffolk County District Attorney Newman Flanagan. The telephone at his office went unanswered early this morning; spokesman John Julian told the Herald on Friday that Flanagan would have no comment. Jackson said he told the same false story Nov. 21 before a grand jury convened to hear evidence against Bennett, an ex-convict with a record dating to 1964. He said he returned to the grand jury the next day and recanted his testimony, even though his lawyer warned him he could be charged with perjury. ``I wanted to do the right thing,'' Jackson told the Herald. ``I didn't want this guy to go to jail. He was my friend's uncle and I don't care what he did in the past. He did his time for that.'' Another grand jury began hearing testimony Friday as it searches for missing links in what police say was Stuart's plot to kill his pregnant wife. Carol Stuart, 30, who was seven months pregnant, died hours after the shooting, and her premature baby, Christopher, died 17 days later. Affidavits police released to The Associated Press on Friday said Carol Stuart was shot in the left side of the head, which would be consistent with the current police theory that Charles Stuart, sitting in the driver's seat, shot his wife and himself. The affidavit was part of search-warrant applications filed in Roxbury District Court by police investigating Bennett as a suspect in the shootings. The affidavits also say that on Nov. 1, Bennett took it on his own to flag down a patrol car and tell an officer he knew he was a suspect but that he had been out of town at the time of the shooting. Investigators learned of the apparent hoax when a younger brother, Matthew Stuart, 23, told authorities Jan. 3 that he met Charles at the murder scene and retrieved Mrs. Stuart's handbag, which contained a gun and some personal items. Matthew Stuart has said he was not aware Mrs. Stuart was shot when his brother passed him the bag. Prosecutors have declined to say whether he or anyone else might face charges.

DOC.HEAD: Record Attendance at Yosemite
DOC.TEXT: A record number of tourists visited Yosemite National Park last year while nearby Kings Canyon and Sequoia parks came close to their best years ever. Yosemite attracted 3,429,619 visitors, a 3 percent increase from 1988, said Michael V. Finley, the park's new superintendent, who said 70 percent of the visitors come from California, 20 percent from abroad and the remaining 10 percent from other states. Both Kings Canyon and Sequoia national parks, south of Yosemite in the central Sierra Nevada, topped 1 million visitors in 1989 for the fourth straight year, the parks' statistics showed.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in West; Warmer in Plains; Snow in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A Pacific cold front brought rain, colder temperatures and the threat of snow to the Western states today. Milder air spread from Montana to western Kansas, and strong winds buffeted the Northeast with snow. A winter storm warning was posted for California's northern Sierra Nevada. Snow advisories were posted today for the rest of the Sierra Nevada, the Mount Shasta and Siskiyou mountain region and northwestern Nevada. A winter storm watch was in effect today and tonight in northern Nevada. Rain extended from western Oregon across northern and central California. Gale warnings extended over much of the Great Lakes and strong winds continued to bring snow across the Ohio Valley into the central Appalachians. Snow squalls were expected in New York state's eastern Finger Lakes area and for Osewgo County and northern Cayuga County near Lake Ontario. Syracuse braced for 6 inches or more of snow, and heavy snow was also forecast for northwestern Pennsylvania. Advisories for snow and blowing snow were posted for northern Lower Michigan, northeastern Ohio, West Virginia's northern mountains and the western part of Maryland's panhandle. The northern Plains expected low pressure to bring warmer weather for the remainder of the weekend. Cool, dry weather in the South was to continue today and Sunday. More fog was forecast for the lower Rio Grande Valley. Snow fell Friday in the Great Lakes region, central Plains, mid-Atlantic states and in central Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. Reno, Nev., tied a 52-year-old record with a reading of 58 degrees. Tucson, Ariz.'s 80 degrees also tied its high for the date, set in 1942. The nation's hot spots Friday were Gila Bend and Yuma, Ariz., with 81 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Accord Between Communists, Nationalists, Opposition Aims To End Ethnic Strife
DOC.TEXT: Bulgarian nationalists provisionally agreed not to stage demonstrations against the granting of rights to ethnic Turks after the Communist government guaranteed that Bulgarian is still the official language. The guarantee came in a declaration Friday by representatives from the nationalist, Communist and opposition camps, aimed at defusing ethnic tensions that have swept Bulgaria for two weeks. The draft document upheld a Dec. 29 decision of the Communist leadership restoring religious and other rights to minority ethnic Turks. It also reaffirmed Bulgarian as the official language and guaranteed this Balkan nation's ``sovereignty'' and ``territorial integrity.'' The provisional declaration was issued by a 19-member commission of representatives on the last day of weeklong negotiations and must still be submitted to Parliament for final approval. Parliament meets Monday. Nationalist Mincho Minchev, spokesman for the Commission for the Protection of National Interests, told reporters Friday the declaration had his ``unreserved support.'' He said his movement will not push for strikes or demonstrations over the weekend. Bulgarian protesters and strikers originally urged that the decree be revoked pending a national referendum, and threatened more unrest if their demands were not met. The Dec. 29 decision allowed ethnic Turks and Moslems here to reassume their own names and practice their religion without restrictions. It reversed an assimilation policy pursued by ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov that forced ethnic Turks to assume Bulgarian names and restricted their practicing Islam or using their native language. An exodus to neighboring Turkey began last summer and about 300,000 of Bulgaria's estimated 1.5 million ethnic Turks still are in that country. The forum was convened after thousands of nationalists converged on the capital last week to protest changing the assimilation policy. Many expressed concern that Bulgarian national unity would be imperiled. Officials said a parliamentary commission will be formed to work out a final national program based on the declaration. It will be headed by Communist Party chief Petar Mladenov, who replaced Zhivkov on Nov. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Ranch Couple's Suit Against Jet Noise in Judge's Hands
DOC.TEXT: A couple who sued the Navy over the loss of their cattle ranch have found it difficult to prove that the thousands of jets screaming overhead are what caused their cows to lose their enthusiasm for breeding. Don and Barbara Nonella sued the Navy for $8.7 million, claiming flights out of the Fallon Naval Air Station ruined their business and drove them off the land, which they couldn't sell and the Navy wouldn't buy. Don Nonella now drives trucks out of Elko, in eastern Nevada. The couple claims that increased jet training activity over their ranch, 60 miles east of the naval air station, killed some of their cattle and caused other cows to reproduce less. But the Navy's laywer, Lt. Mike Quinn, said Friday the couple had failed to prove their claim. ``Things happen that only God can explain,'' Quinn said. ``Fluctuations in production are normal and to be expected. There's no evidence to suggest that noise did it.'' Bob Alexander, who represents the couple, said he had proved the cattle were not diseased and were fed properly, ruling out everything but stress from the ear-popping sonic booms caused by the jets to explain why the cows were not reproducing. Closing arguments in the five-day trial ended Friday and it was left in the hands of U.S. District Judge Bruce Thompson. Quinn said the Nonella's ranch lay beneath both a military operations area and a supersonic flight range, and with more than 64,000 flights out of the naval air station each year in the late 1980s, it was logical there would be noise. ``The pilots must train somewhere and that somewhere is central Nevada. Clearly our operation at times affects the people of central Nevada. They bear part of the burden of making sure our nation is prepared,'' he said. Alexander argued that the Nonellas would have had $1 million in livestock sales each year from 1985 to 1988 if production hadn't dropped off, but Quinn said the couple bought the ranch when cattle prices were high and interest rates were low, then lost it as livestock prices declined and interest rates rose. The couple said the conception rate of cows on their property was more than 90 percent from 1979 when they bought the ranch but fell to about 67 percent after 1984. They left the land in May 1988. James Cothern, an agricultural economics professor at the University of California in Fresno and Davis, testified that a computer analysis he performed showed the ranch was just accumulating debt and would have failed no matter what. Nonella, 58, disputed that outside the courtroom. ``You don't run a ranch by computer, you run it by the seat of your pants,'' he said, patting the bottom of his blue jeans. A government expert testified that cattle might become startled and even run a bit when faster-than-sound military jets fly overhead to set off sonic booms, but the animals aren't adversely affected by the noise. James Bond, a retired noise expert for the U.S. Department of Agriculture, said he conducted and reviewed several studies during the 1960s and early 1970s that concluded animals quickly get used to sonic booms and military overflights. ``Humans are definitely affected by sonic booms, but beef cattle get used to it,'' Quinn said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I'm just a poor Irishman here on holiday, and I was entrapped by certain people here.'' _ Joseph McColgan, one of four suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas facing charges in Miami of trying to buy a heat-seeking Stinger missile capable of shooting a plane out of the sky from three miles away.

``The Soviet dissidents and their supporters in the West are the midwives of glasnost and perestroika.'' _ Natan Sharansky, Soviet dissident, cautioning against the lionization of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a champion of democracy.

``We haven't been able to put a price tag on our environment yet.'' _ John Hagerty, spokesman for New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection, on the state suing Exxon Corp. for the still undetermined sum to cover damages and cleanup costs associated with a 567,000-gallon oil spill on Jan. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say Accused Woman Was `Cold, Emotioness' Toward Daughters
DOC.TEXT: Nurses said a woman who is charged with killing one daughter and implicated in the death of another was ``cold and emotionless'' toward the infant girls but ``thrilled and adoring'' of her son. Nurse Bernice Stupperich, testifying Friday in the trial of Paula Marie Sims, recalled her ``cold, blank stare'' when she saw newborn Heather. Mrs. Sims is accused of suffocating the 6-week-old girl in April. Her first child, Loralei Marie, died after two weeks of life in 1986. Mrs. Sims in both cases told authorities a masked gunman had entered her home and snatched the babies, later discovered dead. She is charged with first-degree murder in the death of Heather, and could face the death penalty if convicted. She faces trial later for obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in the death of Loralei in June 1986. No one has been charged in Loralei's slaying. Defense attorney Donald Groshong spent hours Friday attacking the testimony of Stephanie Werner Cook, who shared a hospital room with Mrs. Sims in March when Heather was born. Mrs. Cook said Mrs. Sims described what she said was the 1986 kidnapping of Loralei to her, using details of the story Mrs. Sims later told police when Heather disappeared. Madison County prosecutor Donald Weber said Mrs. Sims was groggy from her Caesarean section and slipped up in describing Loralei's death to Mrs. Cook, providing proof that Mrs. Sims already was planning to kill Heather. Groshong accused Mrs. Cook of fabricating the story, implying that she could not be believed because she was suffering complications from her own childbirth. He also got Mrs. Cook to admit that Mrs. Sims was affectionate toward Heather, often talking and singing to the baby and kissing her. Mrs. Sims told police she was taking out the trash when a masked gunman knocked her out and kidnapped Heather from their home in Alton on April 29. Mrs. Sims said in 1986 that a masked gunman entered their rural home in Brighton, a few miles north of Alton where the couple lived at the time, and threatened to kill her before taking Loralei. Her husband, Robert Sims, 37, was at work on both occasions and has not been charged in either case. He has custody of their 2-year-old son, Randy. ``When Randy was born, they were very excited,'' said Pam Colley, a nurse at the Alton Memorial Hospital. ``They cried, they were so happy. But their attitude toward Loralei's birth was different. They were quiet and reserved.'' Michael Graham, chief medical examiner in St. Louis, testified Friday that he believed both girls died of ``homicidal violence'' and rejected theories proposed by Groshong that they could have been accidents. The trial resumes Tuesday. It was moved to Peoria because of pretrial publicity in the Alton area.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BANGKOK
Japanese Return From Malaysian Jungles After 45 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with arrival, comments from news conference; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Two Japanese men who fought for their country in World War II and then with Communist guerrillas for 45 years in the jungles of Malaysia returned to Japan today, saying they had looked forward to coming home the entire time. Shigeyuki Hashimoto, 71, and Kiyoaki Tanaka, 77, were greeted by a group of about 20 relatives and friends bearing flowers and candy at Tokyo's airport. It was their first time home since they left in 1944 to work in a wartime Japanese iron factory in Malaysia. They later joined Japan's Imperial Army and then took up arms with the Communist Party of Malaya, now called Malaysia, when Japan surrendered at the end of World War II in 1945. They wanted to help the country gain independence from Britain, Japan's former enemy. ``We're Japanese, so we never forgot about Japan, even for one day,'' Tanaka told a crowd of about 70 reporters at the airport. ``We looked forward greatly to returning to Japan, but as Japanese we couldn't leave behind the people we were fighting alongside for all those years until this opportunity.'' The two appeared on Wednesday in Hat Yai, a town in southern Thailand near the jungled Malaysian border where they and their comrades in the Communist insurgency had fought for 45 years. Six weeks ago, the insurgency was disbanded. ``We fought for a long time,'' Hashimoto said. ``We lost touch with all of our old friends. Now only the two of us are still alive.'' Several of their relatives, including Tanaka's 51-year-old daughter, had earlier flown to Thailand to meet them, and accompanied the men back to Japan. Doctors in Bangkok had pronounced the two in satisfactory condition, but Hashimoto, who suffers from high blood pressure, traveled from the plane in a wheelchair with a nurse at his side. In a weak voice, Hashimoto explained his years away from home to reporters and photographers who jammed a small airport conference room. In 1957, when Malaysia, then called Malaya, gained independence from Britain, ``we could have returned to Japan but it would have required our surrender to the Malaya government and we chose not to do so,'' he said. They decided to fight until the insurgency was over. ``Last year, a peace accord was reached and we became finally free so we could come back to Japan,'' Hashimoto said in a barely audible voice. His account was interrupted by doctors who cautioned him against further efforts to speak. ``I never doubted he was still alive but I did not hear from him or about him for nearly 50 years so of course I was worried,'' said Hashimoto's sister, Kikuko Ishiwatari, 74. Hashimoto, from Kanagawa prefecture, near Tokyo, and Tanaka were scheduled to undergo tests at a hospital in Tokyo before returning home. Tanaka, whose wife is still alive, is from Kumamoto prefecture in the south. While in the jungle, the two men reportedly learned of the enormous changes in Japan since World War II from a shortwave radio. British Commonwealth forces fought bloody battles with the Communist insurgents during what was known as the 1948-1960 ``emergency.'' Fighting continued on a lesser scale, but Thai-Malaysian military strikes and a Thai amnesty badly hurt the guerrilla movement in more recent years. In December, leaders of the party and Thai and Malaysian government officials agreed to end the insurgency.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Ambassador to U.S. Resigns
DOC.TEXT: India's ambassador to the United States has resigned, seven months after he was appointed by the previous government of Rajiv Gandhi, according to news reports today. Karan Singh, appointed June 15, said in a letter to the government that he was quitting on the advice of Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral, India's two national news agencies reported. Singh has been in New Delhi since Dec. 27. United News of India and Press Trust of India said he met Gujral on Thursday after he failed to get an appointment to meet Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Karan Singh, 58, a scion of the family that once ruled the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir, was Gandhi's third political appointee. Gandhi resgined Nov. 29 when his Congress Party failed to get majority in the November elections.

DOC.HEAD: Three Bombs Kill One Person, Wound 10
DOC.TEXT: Three bombs exploded in the northern port of Tripoli during the morning rush hour today, killing one person and wounding 10, hours after an explosive charge went off near the Saudi Arabian embassy in Beirut. Police said the Tripoli bombs detonated at five-minute intervals, causing panic and traffic jams in Lebanon's second-largest city, 50 miles north of the capital. The bombs, each containing an estimated 6{ pounds of TNT, were planted on sidewalks in Tripoli's central business center. The explosions shattered windows within a two-mile radius, leaving streets carpeted with glass shards, and damaged 14 cars, police said. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said a 65-year-old electrical tools peddler was killed in the first blast and that the injured were pedestrians. Tripoli's 850,000 inhabitants are predominantly Sunni Moslem. The city has been policed by Syrian troops since dissident Syrian-backed Palestinian factions drove out Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat and his loyalists in 1983. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for today's bombings. Few such attacks throughout Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war have ever been claimed by the feuding factions. But Tripoli's Coordination Committee, which oversees the city's day-to-day administrative affairs, blamed the bombings on the forces of rebel Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun, who is opposed to the Syrian presence in Lebanon. ``This is the way the outlaw general sees fit to carry on his so-called war of liberation,'' the committee declared in a statement. The bomb in Beirut exploded late Friday night under a car parked 80 yards from the abandoned Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Manara residential district of the capital's Moslem sector, setting several other cars afire. The embassy was closed in 1985 after it was ransacked and burned by militants of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, protesting Saudi restrictions on the number of Iranians allowed to make the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, Islam's holiest city. Christian army units and Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen clashed with automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades before dawn across the Green Line that divides Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors. Police said no casualties were reported in the one-hour flare-up that underscored the deterioration of a civil war cease-fire called by the Arab League Sept. 22. At least four people have been killed and 12 wounded in clashes along the three-mile demarcation line in the last week. The hostilities reflect the deepening political crisis resulting from Aoun's defiance of Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi's government, formed in November to try to end the civil war. Hrawi has dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister. But the 54-year-old general is holding out with 20,000 men in the Christian enclave north of Beirut and refuses to quit the presidential palace that he has occupied since last March. Aoun has rejected an Arab League peace plan that gives Moslems an equal share of power with the Christians. He insists the plan include a timetable for a complete Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. The Syrian Army moved into Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Aoun claims the Syrians abrogated that mandate by openly siding with the Moslems against the Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Outlawed, Crowd Demands ``Death for Death''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with army takeover in Timisoara, demonstrations in Brasov, details; Picks up 6th graf, `Victory, Victory! ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania, Bjt
LaserPhotos XBUC2, 3
DOC.TEXT: The army took over Timisoara, the cradle of Romania's revolution, after its interim leaders resigned in apparent response to anti-Communist demonstrations, the state news agency Rompres reported today. The army takeover apparently was an administrative measure and does not mean the region is under martial law. The army's support of anti-government demonstrators was crucial to the success of Romania's revolution. On Friday, the nation's interim government outlawed the Communist Party, whose four-decade rule ended with last month's ouster of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The developments followed massive street demonstrations in Bucharest, Timisoara and Brasov to protest the participation of former Communists in the leadership of the National Salvation Front, which has been running Romania since Ceausescu's fall. Thousands also demanded the death penalty for Ceausescu's hated security police. In Timisoara, the provisional leader of the region stepped down Friday night along with other members of the local National Salvation Front Council, Rompres and the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported. Maj. Gen. Gheorghe Popescu, the commander of the armed forces in Timis county, whose chief city is Timisoara, said elections for a new provisional leadership would be held within about a week, Rompres reported. Popescu said that until then he would administer the county, the scene of demonstrations Dec. 16-17 which spawned the popular revolt that overthrew Ceausescu. Many Romanians attended church services Friday, declared a day of mourning for the thousands of people who died in the army-backed popular revolution that toppled Ceausescu. Interim President Ion Iliescu, himself a former Communist, announced that this old party had been banned. ``The Romanian Communist Party is outlawed, considering that it is against the national spirit,'' he told a crowd of 5,000 from the window of a Bucharest building where the interim government has its headquarters on Victoria Square. ``Victory, Victory!'' the crowded chanted at the news, broadcast live over government radio and television. ``The Front is with us!'' they yelled, referring to the National Salvation Front, the country's interim leadership. Iliescu did not say what the decision would mean for current members of the party. Much of Romania's new leadership is composed of Communists. The announcement came hours after the crowd shouted down Iliescu and other leaders who tried to speak. Demonstrators yelled ``Down with communism! Kill the Communists!'' They also burned a Romanian Communist flag and Communist identification papers. ``Death to the Securitate!'' and ``Death for Death!'' the crowd chanted, referring to the estimated 10,000 Romanians who died in the clashes between security forces and the army during the revolution. Iliescu told the crowd that a national referendum would be held Jan. 28 on whether the death sentence should be reinstated for members of the security police, who helped Ceausescu maintain his 24-year reign of terror. Ceausescu was executed with his wife, Elena, considered No. 2 in the party, on Dec. 25, three days after they fled the palace in Bucharest. The Front then abolished the death penalty and said members of the security forces convicted by military tribunals would be sentenced to lengthy prison terms. Romania's newly appointed General Prosecutor Gheorghe Robu told Romanian TV Friday that all leading members of the Communist Party were under arrest and their role in the Ceausescu regime was under investigation. He said the trials would begin within 10 days. He said Ceausescu's children and brothers, arrested in the first days of the revolt, also would be brought to trial soon. Friday's demonstration in Bucharest was the largest anti-Communist protest since Ceausescu was ousted. Under his iron-fisted rule, any form of protest or criticism of the leadership or Communist Party was nipped in the bud. The Front comprises former party members, former dissidents and intellectuals. It says its main purpose is to lead the country until the elections, promised as early as April. Premier Petre Roman, addressing the crowd Friday, said ``It is still a question if the ... Front will participate in the elections.'' Iliescu and other leaders went out to speak with the protesters after attending a solemn service at the Patriarhie Orthodox Cathedral in downtown Bucharest for victims of the uprising. The service was conducted by Patriarch Teoctist, spiritual leader of the Romanian Orthodox Church. Under Ceausescu, religious practices were greatly suppressed.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Suggests Communists Leave Coalition Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with papers calling for Communists to leave the coalition government, panic buying reported. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Communist Party newspaper today criticized the Communist-dominated coalition government for adopting reforms too slowly and said the Communists should consider becoming an opposition party. Only by quitting the coalition and acting as a opposition force, the paper said, does the Communist Party stand a chance of regaining its credibility and showing what it can accomplish in East Germany. Ever since it was formed in December, the coalition government led by Communist Premier Hans Modrow has been criticized by opposition groups and allied political parties for its approach to democratic reform. The coalition took power after a popular revolution ousted hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker, touching off a wave of reforms that opened the Berlin Wall, lifted travel restrictions and began an exodus to the West. The coalition will govern the nation until multiparty elections can be held. On Friday, Modrow bowed to yet another opposition demand and announced that his government will not create the internal security agency before a democratically elected government takes office after the May 6 elections. He also set a June 30 deadline for disbanding the Stasi, the old state security agency, which the government said it would abolish last month. Modrow had argued previously that a new security agency was needed right away to guard against a purported threat by neo-Nazi groups in East Germany. The opposition has threatened to hold general strikes in cities around East Germany if the hated Stasi is not disbanded soon. Secret police agents and informers in all areas of life were the Communists' preferred tool of repressing dissent and spying on citizens during their 40 years of unchallenged rule before the revolution late last year. Two of Modrow's coalition partners, the Liberal Democrats and Christian Democrats, also expressed opposition on Friday to the proposed election law, which would forbid campaign aid from abroad. Heated debate on those issues is likely at talks on Monday between the government and opposition. If Modrow's efforts at conciliation fail, workers could expand warning strikes into major walkouts to show solidarity with the opposition. In another problem for the government, tens of thousands of frantic buyers jammed stores Friday after the coalition announced limited price increases for Monday, and speculation was rampant that further increases were imminent. A commentary today in Neues Deutschland, the official Communist Party newspaper, suggested the Communists should consider becoming an opposition force as one way to regain credibility. ``Maybe the SED-PDS (Communist Party) should march out of the government coalition and into opposition ranks, with clear eyes and an upright walk,'' the paper said. Opposition groups then could ``show what they can do.'' Neues Deutschland criticized the Communist-dominated government's efforts to use an alleged neo-Nazi threat as a campaign issue and voiced concern about the slow dissolution of the dreaded secret police. Berliner Zeitung, another Communist paper, suggested that East Germany's drive toward democratic reform is slowing down. ``Nothing is changing anymore. Whoever exercised power before still does so and makes sure he stays in power,'' the paper said. In another concession to the opposition, Modrow said late Friday that he may name opposition members to deputy ministerial posts in the government to oversee areas such as health or the environment. His remarks, in an interview on West Germany's ZDF television network, elaborated on a broadly worded offer Thursday to bring reform groups into a government coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Washington, Oregon Assess Flood Damage
DOC.TEXT: A state of emergency was declared and federal officials today planned to tour areas of Washington state hit hard by flooding and high winds from three back-to-back Pacific storms. Oregon officials also continued assessing destruction from the storms, which killed at least six people in the two states, closed interstate highways and rail lines and drove hundreds from homes damaged by toppling trees and flooding. Washington Gov. Booth Gardner on Friday declared a state of emergency in 13 counties. Today's tour by Federal Emergency Management Agency officials was planned in anticipation of Gardner's asking President Bush to declare the counties a disaster area and release federal aid. In Oregon, Gov. Neil Goldschmidt on Friday flew over two northern coastal counties, Clatsop and Tillamook, that he had declared emergency areas as the last of three storms rolled through on Tuesday. He compared damage from the storms to that from the 1962 Columbus Day storm, which left 35 people dead and caused $170 million in damage. ``I think we just had another one,'' Goldschmidt said. ``We're no place close to a total estimate of damage, but we'll know a lot more by the end of next week,'' Goldschmidt said. ``We'd like to see that everybody who deserves assistance finds some way to get it.'' Insurance officials in Oregon said earlier this week they had received damage claims totaling at least $12.5 million; Washington officials estimated damage at more than $7 million. The American Red Cross was keeping disaster service centers open during the weekend in all 13 Washington counties where Gardner declared emergencies. ``The citizens of our state face millions of dollars in damages,'' Gardner said. ``Many people's entire lives have been turned upside down. We need access to every resource available to make repairs and to return life to normal.'' Many residents in the hardest-hit areas, along the Chehalis River in Lewis, Thurston and Grays Harbor counties, were just starting to return home Friday. An estimated 4,000 people in Lewis County alone were affected by the flooding, with 400 evacuated. Kate Heimbach, state emergency management director, said early damage estimates total at least $7.2 million. Interstate 5 was reopened Friday at Chehalis, about 85 miles south of Seattle, after the river flooded the freeway Tuesday. The north-south Burlington Northern main line between Seattle and Portland was reopened Friday after washing out Tuesday near Vader, railroad spokesman Howard Kallio said. In Lewis County, about 175 people still remained in shelters or motels Friday, state officials said. The airport remained flooded, with 32 planes damaged, the state said. King County, where mudslides and water damaged homes, roads and an apartment house, estimated its damage at more than $5 million. Pierce County, where roads, bridges and more than 150 homes were damaged, pegged its losses at $1.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Anti-Government Rallies in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired tear gas to break up anti-government rallies by hundreds of radical students at two universities in the opposition stronghold of Kwangju city today, a news agency said. About 700 radical students and dissidents fought police with rocks and firebombs inside Chonam University in the southern city, the Yonhap News Agency said. Police arrested six protesters in the 90-minute clash, the report said. The fighting began after 1,000 riot police, supported by two armored vans with tear-gas launchers, marched into the campus to break up the rally. The students shouted slogans calling for the punishment of President Roh Tae-woo and his predecessor, Chun Doo-hwan. Radicals have long held both responsible for a government crackdown on a civil uprising in Kwangju in 1980 that left at least 200 people dead and 1,500 wounded. Opposition parties have been powerful in Kwangju ever since, but radical students who have repeatedly staged anti-demonstrations since South Korea adopted democratic reforms in 1988 do not enjoy much popular support. A police helicopter hovered overhead today as riot police fired tear gas and swept through the sprawling campus to stop the protest, the agency said. No injuries were immediately reported. The clash followed a 30-minute demonstration at nearby Chosun University earlier in the day. Police fired tear gas to disperse 200 radical students occupying a rail crossing in front of their school, Yonhap said. The clash forced a passenger train to screech to a halt. No injuries or arrests were immediately reported. The protesters at Chonam denounced a recent political compromise between the governing and opposition political parties to end a long dispute over investigations into alleged corruption during the autocratic Chun regime. Under the Dec. 15 compromise, Chun testified in parliament on alleged misdeeds during his seven-year rule, which ended in 1988. The testimony on Dec. 31 was marred by repeated shouting matches and a melee among legislators. Roh was also criticized today because of his close ties with Chun. Roh helped Chun seize power with military backing in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in West Belfast Shootout
DOC.TEXT: Three men who allegedly were holding up a betting shop were shot to death by soldiers in plainclothes today in West Belfast, police said. A fourth man, apparently a passerby, was injured by gunfire, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the legal political wing of the Irish Republican Army, accused the security forces of ``the cold blooded and savage murder of three young men.'' However, Sinn Fein denied that any of the three dead men were members of the IRA. They were not immediately identified. The constabulary issued a statement saying that two soldiers who were on duty but not in uniform interrupted a robbery at a betting shop on the Falls Road in West Belfast. ``Shots were fired and three persons were killed _ one man in a car and the others, both of whom had been hooded, outside a stolen vehicle. A fourth person, believed to be a passerby, was injured.'' Police said the car used by the suspects had been stolen from a hospital parking lot the previous night. A spokesman for the constabulary, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not know who initiated the shooting. He also declined to comment on reports in Belfast that the soldiers were members of the elite Special Air Service unit of the British army. Such reports, he said, were ``rumor and speculation.'' A man interviewed by Independent Television News, who claimed to have witnessed the shooting, said the soldiers fired at two men as they lay wounded on the sidewalk. The man was not identified in the ITN report. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, quoted a witness as saying: ``Two fellows with rifles or machine guns _ they were unhooded and had civilian clothes _ shot these two fellows who were hooded.'' He said the third victim was sitting, without a hood, in the nearby car. ``When I looked into the car he was slumped over on to the passenger side. All three were definitely dead,'' said the man, who declined to give his name.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in the Soviet Bloc
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES Lithuanian portion of the Soviet entry. Here are the latest developments in the Soviet Union and East bloc nations:
DOC.HEAD: THE SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Communists today rejected President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeal to restore ties they severed with Moscow and said to do so ``would mean death'' for the local party. Gorbachev, winding up a three-day visit to the restive Baltic republic, argued that it would suffer economically if it broke with the Soviet Union. But he failed to head off the drive for independence. Elsewhere, more scattered clashes were reported today in the troubled southern Caucasus region, which has been racked by strikes, blockades and attacks on government offices. Ethnic Armenians tried to surround several mostly Azerbaijani villages in the Azerbaijani enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. Armenia and Azerbaijan claim the enclave in the ethnically charged conflict.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA:
DOC.TEXT: The army took over Timisoara, the cradle of Romania's revolution, after its interim leaders resigned in apparent response to anti-Communist demonstrations, official media reported today. The army takeover apparently was an administrative measure and does not mean the region is under martial law. The army played a key role in the popular revolt that overthrew Nicolae Ceausescu.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: A Communist Party newspaper today criticized the Communist-dominated coalition government for adopting reforms too slowly and said the Communists should consider becoming an opposition party. Only by quitting the coalition and acting as a opposition force, the paper said, can the Communist Party regain its credibility and show what it can accomplish in East Germany.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA:
DOC.TEXT: A tentative agreement was reached to end unrest that began after the new government granted rights to ethnic Turks. Bulgarian nationalists agreed to stop protesting the concessions to the Turks after the government guaranteed on Friday that Bulgarian will remain the nation's official language.
DOC.HEAD: ALBANIA:
DOC.TEXT: Official Yugoslav media reported Friday that demonstrations and gunfire were occurring in Albania, the last hard-line Stalinist nation in the Soviet bloc. But a senior Albanian Communist denied the accounts and others that said emergency security measures had been imposed in Albania.

DOC.HEAD: With Space Lab Stowed, Astronauts Pursue Their Experiments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with astronaut news conference; picks up 7th graf, `With the...'. SUBS 11-12th grafs pvs, `Brandenstein and...', to DELETE now-redundant first references to Wetherbee, Dunbar, Ivins, Low, picking up 13th graf pvs, `Bill Kinard...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4; other upcoming
DOC.TEXT: The recovery of a huge science lab by space shuttle Columbia will help engineers design spaceships of the future, the shuttle's commander said today. Astronaut Dan Brandenstein said all the various types of materials that have been exposed to space on the Long Duration Exposure Facility for more than five years ``will now be studied and that will give us the capability to design better and more durable spacecraft and space stations.'' Brandenstein and his four crew members discussed their flight in a 20-minute news conference from their distant orbit, answering questions beamed up from reporters at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar, who snared LDEF Friday with the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, said that although some of the experiments were beaten up by the long exposure to micrometeoroids and other space debris, they will serve as invaluable research tools. ``It was the intent of this payload to find out which materials we should be building space stations and spacecraft out of,'' she said. Mission specialist David Low said the astronauts planned to spend the final days of the flight before their planned landing next Friday working on experiments. ``This is the second longest space shuttle mission, and we can do some good materials sciences work and also get some good medical data,'' he said. Pilot Jim Wetherbee said as a rookie space flier it took him a couple of days to get used to weightlessness. He and the two other first-time space travelers, Low and Marsha Ivins, sometimes bumped into one another until they got acclimated. ``It's pretty neat to be floating around up here,'' Ivins commented. The space travelers and ground controllers remained on an emotional high today after the retrieval of the satellite, with Mission Control waking the crew with its version of ``Hello Dolly.'' ``Hello, LDEF, it's so nice to have you back where you belong . .. You're looking swell, LDEF, we can tell, LDEF...'' ``Your music this morning is courtesy of the LDEF project who are obviously very happy,'' the control center told the astronauts. ``We enjoyed doing it and are equally happy,'' Brandenstein responded. With the most dramatic part of the trip behind them, the astronauts settled in for six days of experiments, concentrating on materials processing and tests on how well the human body adapts to weightless space. The planned 10-day mission, which began Tuesday, is the second longest in 33 shuttle flights and is a stepping stone to even longer shuttle missions and to months-long trips aboard space station Freedom in the mid-1990s. Columbia is to return to Earth Friday, with a landing scheduled for 2:57 a.m. PST at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. ``The rendezvous just went famously,'' flight director Al Pennington said Friday. ``It looks like we really have a valuable piece of science in our grasp.'' Brandenstein and Wetherbee steered the shuttle so close to orbiting space lab that Dunbar only had to move the 50-foot mechanical arm about 2 feet to grasp a grappling device on the satellite, Pennington said. After Dunbar secured the wiry fingers of the robot arm to the orbiting space lab, she turned the satellite slowly above the cargo bay so Ivins and Low could photograph it extensively for about four hours before it was secured in the cargo bay for the trip home. Bill Kinard, NASA's chief scientist for the LDEF project, said he was pleased with the initial results of the rescue mission. ``It was a beautiful sight,'' Kinard said after the satellite was stored. ``The views were very much as we expected. We expected to see some damage, particularly on the leading edge of LDEF. Essentially, it looked very much as we expected. We're delighted.'' The astronauts earlier reported that the nearly six-year stay in the harsh space environment has taken its toll on several of the 57 experiments in trays attached to LDEF's multisided exterior. ``Some pretty interesting things on the space end. Some of the panels ... that had aluminum foil over look like they've almost exploded. I mean they're just peeled back like a sardine can,'' Brandenstein said. The satellite, the size of a small school bus, was being pulled to Earth by atmospheric drag. If the astronauts had not retrieved it, trackers estimated it would have plunged to a fiery death in the atmosphere about March 9, its experiments lost forever. Scientists are eager to learn how the various experiments and materials have withstood the stay in space. This will help them design the space station Freedom and other future long-duration spacecraft. The retrieval ended a celestial chase that began with liftoff Tuesday. Columbia covered 1.3 million miles and circled the globe 50 times before making the pickup. Other orbiting satellites have been recovered before by astronauts, but none as big as LDEF.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Stabbed to Death, 10 Palestinians Wounded
DOC.TEXT: An Arab teen-ager today fatally stabbed a Palestinian man accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities, news reports said. Also today, Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least 10 Palestinians during stone-throwing street protests in the occupied Gaza Strip. Hospital officials said the body of Naim Mohamad Handukah, 50, was brought to Shifa Hospital in Gaza City with multiple stab wounds in the chest. Arab reports said Handukah was in his taxi company's office in the affluent Rimal neighborhood when a 16-year-old broke in and attacked him with a dagger. The army confirmed the death and said it was being investigated. Israel radio said Handukah was accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities and that his assailant was in police custody. Handukah's death brought to 170 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs for allegedly collaborating with Israeli officials during the 2-year-long Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. At least 646 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the uprising, and 43 Israelis also have been slain. Dozens of Palestinians blocked the main commercial Omar El-Mukhtar street in Gaza City today and hurled rocks at Israeli soldiers manning three nearby observation posts, Arab reporters and hospital officials said. The soldiers opened fire, wounding four Palestinians, including a 15-year-old youth in the right knee, hospital officials said. At least four Palestinians were wounded in a similar clash in Rafah, and soldiers shot and wounded two Palestinians in Khan Yunis, hospital officials said. The army said it was checking the reports.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Halts Euphrates' Flow for Dam Project
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Turkish president cutting off river's flow. Pickup 6th graf pvs, ``Turkey said...''
DOC.TEXT: In order to build a series of hydroelectric dams, Turkey today cut the flow of the Eurphrates River to Syria and Iraq in a move that could cause problems for the two arid nations over the next month. Invoking the name of Allah, President Turgut Ozal pushed a button that closed the hatches of the giant Ataturk Dam. The action will allow engineers to fill a reservoir to a height of 396 feet and build a concrete plug for a diversion channel as part of the construction project. During the one-month stoppage, Syria and Iraq will get less water from the tributaries of the Euphrates, the river that has been the lifeblood throughout history for the area that once formed ancient Mesopotamia. The ceremony today was a moment of pride and accomplishment for Turkey, which views the Southeast Anatolia project to build more than a dozen dams as the key to the economic development of the backward region. But the event is considered a cause for worry for Iraq and Syria, which are highly dependent on the waters of the 1,460-mile Euphrates River. It was the lifeblood of ancient Mesopotamia, a part of modern-day Iraq. For one month, Syria and Iraq will receive about one-fourth of the water they normally get from the tributaries of the Euphrates. Turkey said that since November, it has released extra water to Syria and Iraq to allow them to store water in reservoirs for use during the cutoff. Syria has made no statement on the water stoppage. Iraq sent its deputy foreign minister, Nizar Hamdoun, to Turkey last month to ask for a stoppage of two weeks instead of the planned one month. Hamdoun said the cutoff would not provoke a major crisis in Iraqi agriculture, but it would cause damage in some areas.
