Iraqi irrigation and agriculture officials said today that First Undersecretary Abdul Sattar Salman will head a high-level delegation to the Turkish capital to discuss problems arising from cutting the Euphrates flow. Turkey on Monday sent a foreign ministry delegation to tour Iraq, Syria, Egypt and Saudi Arabia to deliver a message that it does not intend to use its control of the rivers for political leverage. Syria is more dependent on the river, because Iraq has the Tigris River in its territory. But Syria is in a position to divert more of the Euphrates River water to its own reservoirs and allow just a trickle to Iraq. ``This is a problem they will have to solve among themselves,'' said a Turkish official who asked for anonymity. Ever since it started building dams on the Euphrates in the 1960s, Turkey has periodically reassured its neighbors they would all share the water. Once the project of 15 dams and 18 hydroelectric power plants is completed, however, Turkey will have a stranglehold on the waters of the Euphrates and Tigris rivers. The first generating unit of the Ataturk Dam is to start production in May 1991. The dam, about 100 miles from the Syrian border near Sanliursa, is the centerpiece of the massive Southeast Anatolia project, designed to harness the waters of both Euphrates and Tigris with a chain of dams and hydroelectric power plants. When completed in 2006, the project will produce 22 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually and irrigate an area of 4 million acres. This would double the yield in many crops in Turkey, producing $5 billion in surplus food, officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Forced Back Home Are Bitter, Poor
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Le Van Lich took a drag from his bamboo pipe and surveyed the grim one-room home he has shared with 17 other people since being forcibly repatriated from Hong Kong a month ago. A forlorn expression his constant companion, and his 2-year-old daughter sitting on his lap, Lich summed up his new life: ``I don't know about the future, I only know the fact before my eyes _ I don't have enough to eat.'' Luck has been going against Lich since he and his family set sail for Hong Kong in their 43-foot wooden boat to escape grinding poverty. They completed the 500-mile trip to the British colony on June 20, five days after Hong Kong authorities announced that newly arriving Vietnamese boat people would be considered illegal immigrants unless they could prove they faced persecution in their Communist homeland. That doomed Lich's chances of starting a new life in the West, for as he acknowledged, ``I have nothing to do with politics. I just left Vietnam for economic reasons.'' The 37-year-old fisherman and 11 other members of his family, including his wife and five children, were among the first group of 51 boat people to be sent back home against their will in the pre-dawn hours of Dec. 12. Another 36,000 Vietnamese in Hong Kong camps are waiting to see if they will face a similar fate. The forced repatriation triggered an international outcry, in part because of concern that the boat people would be punished upon their return home. Haiphong officials insist that Lich and other returnees need not worry. Timothy Raison, a British parliamentarian who visited 37 of the forcibly returned boat people last week, said he found no sign of persecution. ``I think we have been forgiven by the Vietnamese government,'' said Le Van Tuoi, another fisherman forced back on the same chartered flight as Lich. Lich agreed that local authorities have been friendly and that he does not fear punishment. But he sais, ``Now I have another worry. We don't have money; we don't have anything to live on. We lost our fishing boat and our fishing equipment.'' The boat that had been home and livelihood for three generations of Lich's family was left behind in Hong Kong. Since returning to Vietnam, they have had to live in a friends' tiny home tucked inside a maze of alleys in this gritty northern port city. A large cabinet and two beds are the only furniture; a makeshift altar with a faded picture of Jesus rests on a rickety wooden loft. Clothes hang to dry from three lines strung across the room, and stashed in a corner are the red, white and blue bags that hold Lich's meager family possessions. Britain and Hong Kong have promised to pay Vietnam about $600 to help reintegrate each repatriated boat person, but it is unclear how much cash each returnee will get. ``I'm waiting for the money from the Hong Kong government ... so I can buy a boat or a house,'' Lich said. ``The government also promised us when we arrived at the airport that it would help us build a house.'' Adults were given $30 and children $15 when they left Hong Kong, although Lich claimed they were promised more. The fishermen will need far more money to build or buy a boat equipped with nets, which Raison said could cost up to $10,000. In the meantime, Lich is frustrated with being idle and remains bitter at the Hong Kong and British governments for puncturing his dream of a better life. He remembered the three Hong Kong detention centers where he was imprisoned for nearly 18 months _ the crowded conditions, stifling boredom and what he described as inadequate food. He said his father died of lung cancer while languishing in the camps. Also fresh in his mind was the pre-dawn swoop by Hong Kong security forces in riot gear who whisked Lich and his family to the airport for the flight back to Hanoi. ``They didn't beat us, but they pushed and dragged us,'' he said. Added Lich, his sorrow unwavering: ``I'm angry, and I regret I ever left for Hong Kong.''

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Proposes Talks With South on Free Travel
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea on Saturday proposed talks with South Korea on allowing free travel between the rival countries. South Korea rejected the idea. The proposal was made in letters sent to the border village of Panmunjom. They were delivered to President Roh Tae-woo, Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon and three main opposition leaders _ Kim Dae-jung, Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil. According to South Korean officials, North Korea repeated in the letters a proposal by its leader, Kim Il Sung, that the two Koreas hold ``top-level political talks'' to discuss free travel on the Korean peninsula. They quoted the letters as saying in part, ``As a first step toward opening the gate of unification, the concrete wall set up on the southern side of the border should be torn down.'' ``If the southern side destroys the concrete wall, we will immediately remove a barbed wire fence on our side that marks the border line,'' they futher quoted the letters as saying. In a New Year's speech, the North Korean ruler called on South Korea to tear down a concrete border wall along the 155-mile-long border to ensure free travel as a first step toward unifying the divided peninsula. Choi Byong-bo, a spokesman for the South Korean government's National Unification Board, noted that North Korea has repeated similar proposals on numerous occasions since its Communist government was set up in 1948. The peninsula was divided at the end of World War II in 1945. Choi said southern leaders would not attend the proposed talks. In a nationally televised news conference last week, Roh proposed a face-to-face meeting with his North Korean counterpart to discuss possible free travel and ways to ease friction on the peninsula. He suggested the conclusion of a free travel and communication agreement between the two Koreas. North Korea rejected both proposals. South Korean officials accuse North Korea of trying to create the ``false'' impression that there is a barrier along the border like the Berlin Wall. ``There simply is no such wall along the border,'' Defense Ministry spokesman Brig. Gen. Kim Ji-woo said. ``'The North's false propaganda shows how they are embarrassed in the midst of sweeping changes in East Europe,'' the ministry spokesman said. Ministry officials said there are tank traps along some portions of the border that were used by North Korea when it invaded the South in 1950 to start the Korean War.

DOC.HEAD: Ten People Killed in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: Two passenger buses collided head-on Saturday, killing 10 people and seriously injuring five, Pakistan's official news agency said. The late afternoon accident occurred outside Jehangira village, about 60 miles east of Islamabad, Associated Press of Pakistan said. The report did not say how many people were on the buses. Officials said the two buses were apparently speeding. The seldom enforced speed limit on the ancient Grand Trunk road, where the accident occured, is about 55 mph.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Ruling Reopens Wounds for Many in Civil Rights Community
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court ruling last week in a protracted racial desegregation dispute from Yonkers, N.Y., reopened not-so-old wounds for many in the civil rights community. The decision, while perhaps more symbolic than substantive, is a painful reminder for civil rights leaders that the most likely champion of their aspirations now is Congress, not the high court. The civil rights movement's longstanding reliance on the court as an ally ended with a series of 1989 rulings that curtailed affirmative action, made it tougher to prove employment bias and restricted remedies for on-the-job racial harassment. The clear signal was that a court made more conservative by appointees of former President Reagan had swung the balance in civil rights lawsuits in favor of defendants and the white majority. Civil rights leaders still are smarting over those rulings, and are asking Congress for new laws to overcome them. The Yonkers decision limited judges' power to crack down on civil rights violations. The 5-4 ruling said a judge improperly fined Yonkers City Council members but acted within his authority in imposing coercive fines against the city for reneging on its agreement to desegregate housing. ``The message is perhaps not a powerful one, but a negative one,'' said Kerry Scanlon of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. ``Judges are going to be looking over their shoulder, wondering if they are going too far'' in ordering remedies for past civil rights violations. Steven Shapiro of the American Civil Liberties Union said he is happy that last week's decision, authored by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, was not written more broadly to pull in the judicial reins even more tightly. ``There are indications that suggest Rehnquist would have liked to go further but he couldn't hold the majority if he did,'' Shapiro said. Shapiro declined to speculate about which court members might have refused to join a broader ruling. But he said, ``Obviously, Justice (Sandra Day) O'Connor has been a swing vote in this area.'' Barbara Arnwine, executive director of the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, sees some positive signs in the Yonkers decision. ``The court has yet to take a plunge against strong, race-conscious, remedial measures,'' she said. Ms. Arnwine said last week's ruling may bode well for civil rights forces in a Kansas City, Mo., case now awaiting decision by the justices. In it, a federal trial judge ordered the city's school district to raise property taxes to help pay for racially desegregating public schools. The high court's decision is expected by July. Before ending its current term, the court also is expected to decide what could be its most significant civil rights case of the year: judging the validity of special preferences the federal government gives to women and minority members seeking licenses for radio and television stations. The court last year limited similar affirmative action efforts by state and local governments, ruling that a public works set-aside program in Richmond, Va., violated the rights of whites. The current case presents the court with programs initiated by the federal government, and its ruling could affect federal affirmative action beyond the broadcasting industry. Compared with last year, however, the court's docket of civil rights cases is light. ``Maybe we all can be thankful this isn't a busy year for the court in this area,'' said Scanlon of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. Others may share the opinion of one dejected civil rights attorney who, when asked last July what future setbacks loomed, replied, ``What's left?''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Richard Carelli has covered the Supreme Court for The Associated Press since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Charges Bhutto Pregnancy Leaves Country Without Leader
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto have turned her pregnancy into a political weapon, complaining that the country will be left without leadership while Ms. Bhutto takes maternity leave. The baby, Ms. Bhutto's second, is expected to be born before Jan. 20. Some of the strongest objections have come from another woman, Abida Hussein, an independent member in the National Assembly. ``The feminist in me has been really outraged over this pregnancy. It was wrong, irresponsible and poses very serious difficulties for our nation,'' said Ms. Hussein, a leading opponent of the Bhutto government. ``It's a very extreme situation. We will have no chief executive officer for a few weeks,'' she alleged. ``The constitution doesn't provide for maternity leave.'' Nasir Aslam Zahid, a constitutional expert in Pakistan's law, justice and parliamentary affairs ministry, said official Parliamentary rules cover Ms. Bhutto's absence, regardless of the reason. The laws provide for a senior minister, appointed by the prime minister, to head the Cabinet in her absence. In the past, particularly during her frequent travels abroad, Ms. Bhutto left her mother and National Assembly member, Nusrat Bhutto, in charge. The elder Bhutto also shares the chairmanship of the ruling left-of-center Pakistan People's Party with her daughter. ``No doubt she will have Mom look after the shop while she's away,'' said Ms. Hussein, a hint of sarcasm in her voice. ``(But) running a nation is not a family concern.'' Ms. Bhutto's detractors criticize the ruling party as a family dynasty started in 1967 by her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. He was prime minsiter from 1970 to 1977, when he was overthrown by President Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a coup. Amina Piracha, a lawyer and member of Bhutto's party, dismissed opposition complaints and said she did not expect the 36-year-old prime minister to be out of office for long. ``(Until now) she hasn't taken even one day of leave because of her pregnancy,'' she said. Ms. Bhutto's first child, Bilawal, was born less than a month before the November 1988 elections that gave her left-leaning party the largest bloc of votes. She was campaigning the day before the birth and returned to the campaign trail less than a week later. When Ms. Bhutto assumed office Dec. 2, 1988, becoming the first woman to leader a modern Moslem nation and, at 35, was the youngest world leader. Islamic fundamentalists condemned her leadership, saying a woman's rule ran contrary to the tenets of Islam. Ms. Piracha said Ms. Bhutto's leadership has debunked claims that having children puts serious limits on female ambitions. ``She has shown to the world that it is not a constraint,'' said Ms. Piracha. ``She has in fact been able to conduct herself with such dignity.'' Ms. Hussein dismissed speculation that Ms. Bhutto's often hostile opposition will move against the government during her absence. Last November, Ms. Bhutto's government narrowly survived a no-confidence motion. The opposition, lead by an alliance of right-wing, centrist and Islamic fundamentalist parties, has several times vowed to unseat the Bhutto government.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Said Willing To Help Contras if US Ignored Drug Links
DOC.TEXT: On a June day in 1985, Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, then managing director of the U.S. drive to aid the Nicaraguan Contra rebels, boarded a yacht anchored off the Pacific coast of Panama for a secret meeting with the country's military strongman, Manuel Antonio Noriega. North needed Noriega's permission to use Panamanian military bases and personnel to train Contra soldiers in their fight against Nicaragua's Sandinista government. Noriega enthusiastically joined in the effort to help the Contras, apparently betting that his cooperation would encourage U.S. officials to turn a blind eye to evidence that he was involved in narcotics trafficking, money laundering and gun running. The ousted Panamanian leader now claims that the U.S. began its campaign to remove him only after he refused to allow Panama to be used as a launching pad for Contra attacks against Nicaragua. North, who at that time was a White House aide, held at least two further meetings with Noriega, a strand in a web of high level U.S. government contacts with the Panamanian ruler that included sessions with Vice President George Bush, CIA Director William Casey and Vice Adm. John Poindexter, the Reagan administration's national security adviser. Analyzing these meetings, investigators for a Senate Foreign Affairs subcommittee on narcotics concluded last year that Noriega was following a divide-and-conquer strategy in his relations with the United States. Noriega eventually offered to provide military training and weapons for the Contras and also to infiltrate Panamanian troops inside Nicaragua to sabotage key facilities and assassinate Sandinista leaders. ``Noriega recognized that so long as he helped the United States with its highest diplomatic priorities ... the United States would have to overlook activities of his that affected lesser U.S. priorities,'' the Democratic-led panel said. ``In the mid-1980s, this meant that our government did nothing regarding Noriega's drug business and substantial criminal involvement because the first priority was the Contra war,'' it said. Noriega, now awaiting trial in Miami on narcotics charges after his ouster from power in a U.S. invasion last month, long has said he holds information highly embarrassing to key U.S. officials, information stemming in part from his face-to-face conversations with them. Noriega's lawyers say they will ask the government to turn over many sensitive documents bearing on Noriega's relationship with U.S. officials, documents which he contends will show the United States was aware of his narcotics activities for many years and chose to ignore them. The Senate subcommittee, headed by Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., sought many of the same documents but never succeeded in obtaining them from government agencies. Earlier, the congressional Iran-Contra committees also sought to trace Noriega's relationships, especially with North and the Contras. Jose Blandon, a former Panamanian intelligence officer who was fired by Noriega as Panama's counsel-general in New York City, told the Senate investigators that when Noriega and North held their first shipboard meeting, North was looking for ways to circumvent the congressional ban on U.S. aid to the Contras. Blandon testified that the meeting led to an agreement with Noriega in which up to 250 Contra soldiers received training at two Panamanian military bases, with Contra leaders being given permission to enter and leave Panama freely. At a second meeting in October 1985 in Noriega's office in Panama City, the general asked for a favor in return, saying Panama needed economic help to deal with more than $3 billion in foreign debt. Blandon told reporters Panama received some $200 million in U.S. and international bank loans during the next year. In August 1986, Noriega, through an intermediary, upped the ante with an explosive offer. Panamanian troops would infiltrate Nicaragua and assassinate top Sandinista leaders ``in exchange for a promise to help clean up Noriega's image and a commitment to lift the ban on military sales to the Panamanian defense forces,'' according to documents made public at North's Iran-Contra trial. According to the documents, Poindexter responded that the administration was barred by law from involvement in assassinations, ``but Panamanian assistance with sabotage would be another story.'' North and Noriega met in London in late September 1986 and Noriega agreed ``to take immediate actions against the Sandinistas and offered a list of priorities, including an oil refinery, an airport and the Puerto Sandino off-load facility.'' The committee found no evidence the sabotage plan was carried out. Casey met with Noriega in Panama in November 1985 and, according to the Senate subcommittee report, failed to raise the issue of Noriega's involvement with narcotics. The panel said Casey later justified his failure to raise the issue with Noriega, with whom the CIA had had a close working relationship for nearly two decades, because Noriega was providing valuable support for U.S. policies in Central America, especially in Nicaragua. The drug issue never came up in a December 1985 meeting between Noriega and Poindexter, the committee said. Noriega and Bush first met in 1976 when Bush headed the CIA and Noriega led the Panamanian intelligence service. They met again in 1983 in Panama when Bush was vice president. Last February, after Noriega was indicted, he alleged that Poindexter had told Panamanian officials in 1985 that the United States planned to invade Nicaragua. Bush rejected that as ``pure fabrication and a lie.'' Noriega also alleged that immediately before the U.S. invasion of Grenada in 1983 Bush called him and asked him to assure Cuban President Fidel Castro that Cuban soldiers and workers in Grenada were not a target of the attack. That claim also was labeled ``a total fabrication'' by Bush. Noriega said last year that his troubles with the United States began only after he balked at escalating U.S. requests to aid the Contras. In a speech last February, shortly after his indictment, Noriega said that Poindexter warned him to ``expect the consequences'' if he refused to cooperate further on Central America. Noriega said he considered the indictment to be ``the consequences.'' He gave another account of his encounter with Poindexter to Saul Landau, a senior fellow at the Institute for Policy Studies, a Washington think tank. In an article prepared for the February-March issue of Mother Jones Magazine, Landau said Noriega told him he had refused to allow Panama to be used as ``a launching pad'' for the Contras. ``Poindexter grew quite indignant, right in my office,'' Landau quoted Noriega as saying. ``He took out his pipe and banged it on the table. I'm not sure if he broke it. After that incident, the United States began its campaign to remove me.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Play It Down, But NBC Miniseries Raises Hackles In Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Although it finished second in the Nielsen ratings and lost to a television movie on Rock Hudson, NBC's ``Drug Wars'' was a hit, of sorts, in Mexico. The government and national media protested last week's series, and one sensationalist newspaper even printed speculation that the subject of the movie _ a slain U.S. drug agent _ was alive and well in La Jolla, Calif. Mexican officials had been anticipating the series nervously for months, well aware that the killing of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena in 1985 threw U.S.-Mexico relations into a crisis. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's priority has been to get his nation's stagnant economy moving again. He has tried hard to neutralize drug trafficking as an irritant to U.S.-Mexico relations in order to focus on improving trade and reducing the foreign debt. ``Drug Wars'' was unforgiving in its portrayal of a corrupt legal system that frustrated enforcement and covered up the Camarena killing, and officials feared it would damage Salinas' efforts to change Mexico's image. Most defensive was Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, who was governor of Jalisco state when Caramena was kidnapped in the state capital of Guadalajara. He was criticized for tolerating official corruption and sitting on his hands as major drug dealers operated freely. Posted behind six tons of seized cocaine at a news conference in October, the attorney general denied Mexico's anti-drug efforts were part of a ``show'' for the gringos and threatened to sue if ``Drug Wars'' contained any slander. However, Javier Coello Trejo, the assistant attorney general in charge of narcotics enforcement, said the series would have no effect. ``Our image is bad, it's not right, but there have been deeds that can't be mistaken. What is changing our image is the vigor with which our president is fighting the problem,'' he told The Associated Press. Like other NBC programs, the Sunday-to-Tuesday series appeared in English on Mexico City cable systems, along with public service spots trumpeting Salinas administration achievements in the drug war. U.S. officials are virtually unanimous in saying that Mexico has indeed made progress, and DEA administrator John Lawn said so on an NBC News segment that followed the first broadcast last Sunday night. Nevertheless, the Mexican government protested the series and some of the comments that followed as unfair ``and perhaps in bad faith,'' something NBC vigorously denied. Mexican officials pointed out that 34 tons of cocaine has been seized in the 13 months since Salinas took office, more than in the 10 previous years put together. Mexican sources also said that fully 30 percent of the Mexican anti-narcotics force as it existed at the end of 1988 is now in prison. And in December, Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced to 40 years in prison without parole for the killing of Camarena, whose bullet-riddled body was found nearly a month after his kidnap. With distraction provided by the visit of Spanish King Juan Carlos to Mexico, the president held his tongue during the TV series, but other Mexicans in politics and the media were not so sanguine. Opposition politicians said the administration should vigorously protest it as an insult to Mexico and Mexican law enforcement. The government wire service distributed, and the government newspaper El Nacional printed, a story that raked up old and discredited accusations that Camarena was somehow in league with the drug traffickers who killed him. ``This is just a sort of desperate and rather pathetic effort to try to appease the Mexican public to try to take the heat off in Mexico,'' said Elaine Shannon, author of ``Desperados,'' the book on which the miniseries was based. El Nacional also printed a story that attacked the credibility of the U.S. press, summarizing allegations that reporters had smoked marijuana in the White House during the Carter administration. Perhaps the most improbable article appeared under banner headlines in the sensationalist afternoon edition of El Sol de Mexico, seriously discussing speculation that Camarena was alive and living in La Jolla, Calif. Some Mexican officials asked if ``Drug Wars'' was part of a U.S. plot to denigrate Mexico, noting comments made on the news segments that seemed to equate Panama and Mexico. However, Salinas administration officials, although critical of the program's content, said it was unlikely to have any long-term effect. ``Now more than ever the relationship between our nations is friendly, particularly among those dedicated to fighting drug trafficking,'' said Fernando Arias, chief spokesman for attorney general Alvarez. He, like other officials, thought the American public was sophisticated enough to recognize a Hollywood production when they saw it. ``It is part of the ratings wars, not the drug wars,'' said Agustin Barrios Gomez, Mexico's consul general in New York. NBC said the series won an average 15.3 A.C. Nielsen Co. rating, representing more than 14 million households. It finished second overall in its time period. On Monday, the program's second night, it finished third to an ABC television movie on Rock Hudson and a lineup of CBS comedies.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Says He Won't Oppose Multiparty Politics in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev willing to accept multiparty political system in the Soviet Union. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that he is willing to accept a multiparty political system in the Soviet Union, where the Communist Party he leads has ruled for 72 years. His pledge came at the conclusion of a three-day visit to the restive Baltic republic of Lithuania aimed at persuading local Communists to restore the ties they severed with Moscow. But top party members rejected his appeal, saying union with the national party ``would mean death'' for theirs. In previous public appearances, Gorbachev had ruled out permitting the existence of other parties, which is already a political fact of life in Lithuania since the local legislature voted last year to revoke the Communists' constitutional guarantee of power. But Gorbachev said in Vilnius: ``We shouldn't be afraid of a multiparty system the way the devil fears incense.'' ``I see no tragedy in a multiparty system, if, and I can tell you this straightforwardly, it arises as a result of a normal historical process and answers the needs of society,'' he told a meeting of the Lithuania's Communist Party, which strengthened the republic's independence movement when it voted last month to break from the national party. However, Gorbachev said allowing more than one political party was ``no panacea'' for the nation's ills, and that his reforms of ``glasnost,'' or greater openness, and broader participation by Soviets in public decision-making were more important. He did not say when rival parties might be allowed to organize and run candidates nationwide, but his reference to the ``normal historical process'' could mean such developments are not immediately in the offing. Since the 1917 Russian Revolution, Communists have firmly held the reins of power in the Soviet Union, but they are being increasingly challenged by independent groups _ some calling themselves parties _ that have sprung up in the atmosphere of greater tolerance introduced by Gorbachev. Reforms Gorbachev put in place also led to popular uprisings throughout the Soviet bloc and dramatic democratic reforms in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria. Speakers at the meeting today told Gorbachev they were unimpressed by his promises of greater autonomy as an alternative to Lithuania's drive for full independence. They said their Communist Party must also support independence to keep the people's support. ``Our reality is that we Lithuanian Communists have no trump cards in our dialogue with the people,'' said Vasily Yemelianov, editor-in-chief of the newspaper Soviet Lithuania. ``The majority of Lithuanians are ready to sacrifice their material benefits for the sake of independence.'' To reverse the December decision ``would mean death for the Lithuanian Communist Party,'' Yemelianov said. In 1940 dictator Josef Stalin absorbed Lithuania and the two other Baltic states, Estonia and Latvia, under a secret deal with Nazi Germany. Instead of the conciliatory views Gorbachev came to elicit, he heard at least two hours of speeches largely defending the local party's decision. The speeches in the auditorium of the party's Central Committee were broadcast on Lithuanian television, and a text of remarks made by Gorbachev and others was provided for The Associated Press by Lithuanian TV correspondent Eduardas Potesinskas. During his visit, Gorbachev repeatedly ran into crowds of pro-independence protesters, and he tried to persuade them to hold back in favor of staying in the Soviet Union but on new and better terms of sovereignty. Gorbachev has faced ethnic turmoil and other domestic problems as a result of his program of social and political reform, but Lithuania's independence movement is probably the most serious crisis during his five years in power. On Friday, a leader of the movement accused Gorbachev of laying a ``propaganda trap'' in saying a draft law to be approved by a national vote would provide the mechanism to secede. Gorbachev was greeted at the Bridai collective farm in Siauliai earlier today by protesters carrying banners that read, ``We are for an Independent Lithuania'' and ``Our Aim is the Independence of Lithuania.'' After an exasperating day of trying to get his message across, Gorbachev showed his sense of humor was intact, telling the demonstrators: ``OK, I have read them all, take a rest.'' The crowd interrupted him frequently, and by the end of the discussion, his smile had disappeared and his face was grim. The scene was broadcast by government-run TV. With his wife, Raisa, and Lithuanian Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas standing beside him, Gorbachev cited economic factors that he implied would make it better for Lithuanians to remain in the union. ``Our ties within the country are very close,'' he said. The tiny republic of 3.7 million people receives 70 percent to 100 percent of its energy, oil and metals from the Russian federation, Gorbachev told the farmers. But Brazauskas, who supports the drive for independence, chimed in that the prices Lithuania receives for its goods are far below world levels. Foreign reporters were not permitted to accompany Gorbachev to Siauliai, 125 miles northwest of Vilnius, because it is a military region closed to foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Headed Home This Year From Eastern Europe?
DOC.TEXT: Now that they have overturned the Stalinist systems imposed on them by Moscow, some East Europeans are demanding the Soviet troops that underwrote Communist rule in their countries go home this year. The demands underscore the Soviets' waning influence in Eastern Europe, and they will prove a test of Moscow's willingness to relinquish control over a region where it has held sway for more than 40 years. If realized, the demands could also put pressure on NATO to match the Soviet troop pullouts with withdrawals of U.S. and other Allied forces in Western Europe, perhaps escalating sharp cutbacks already envisaged at Vienna talks on conventional arms reduction. Both superpowers already have signaled willingness at those talks for sizeable cuts in their European forces. Washington proposes a ceiling of 275,000 men each for the United States and the Soviet Union, while the Soviets want slightly higher ceilings that would remove other NATO forces from West Germany. The United States has about 300,000 troops stationed in Europe; the Soviets have 575,000, according to U.S. estimates. The Vienna agreement probably would envisage phased withdrawal over the next decade, rather than the immediate Soviet pullout this year sought by Czechoslovakia and Hungary. East Germany, strategically most important to the Kremlin, has made more modest demands. Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi proposed all foreign troops leave both Germanys by 1999 _ a timetable and balance that probably matches Moscow's thinking. Romania and Bulgaria, with no Soviet troops, are silent on the issue, while the prospect of German reunification leaves Poland in the awkward position of viewing the Warsaw Pact as a guarantor of its current borders. The most strident demand for swift Soviet withdrawal has come from Prague, whose new coalition government opens negotiations Jan. 15 with the Soviets on the pullout of Red Army soldiers who arrived with the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion and never left. ``I suggest that the Soviet troops should withdraw from Czechoslovakia by the end of 1990,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky, like his minister and friend Jiri Dienstbier a former dissident, said last week. In Hungary, too, Soviet troops arrived to suppress revolution _ the 1956 uprising against Stalinism _ and, as in Czechoslovakia, stayed under bilateral agreements now declared void in Prague and considered invalid by most Hungarians. After the foreign affairs and military committees of Hungary's parliament demanded withdrawal by the end of this year, Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth met Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov last week to arrange bilateral talks on the issue. But Nemeth _ unlike the current Prague government _ has stressed the withdrawal depends on agreement on Europe-wide troop reductions at the Vienna talks. Some 10,000 Soviet soldiers already have left both Hungary and Czechoslovakia under the phased withdrawal of 50,000 men from Eastern Europe, which was announced by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1988. An additional 6,000 of the 52,000 Soviet troops said to be left in Hungary are due to leave this year, and an undisclosed number are scheduled to leave Czechoslovakia, where officials say there are some 70,000 Soviet forces. A tank regiment of 1,300 men, an anti-aircraft regiment, a helicopter regiment and two battalions withdrew from Poland in 1989, with an additional brigade of landing and assault troops due to leave this year. But Poland, in many fields an outspoken leader of Eastern Europe's pull away from the Kremlin, has been quiet about demanding a full withdrawal of Soviet troops. ``Poland is one of the strongest supporters of the Warsaw Pact left in Eastern Europe,'' noted Hans Bennendijk, director of studies at London's International Institute of Strategic Studies. Poland has suffered throughout its history from being sandwiched between Russia and Germany. With talk of German reunification growing, the Warsaw Pact is protection against suggestions in West Germany of reclaiming former German territory that became part of Poland after World War II. East Germany traditionally was viewed by Red Army chiefs as the biggest conquest in the vast chunks of territory won in World War II, protecting the Russians from a repeat of the devastating Nazi attack in 1941 and enabling the Kremlin to threaten Western Europe. Moscow has about 380,000 troops in East Germany. Gysi's 1999 deadline for all foreign forces to leave both Germanys fits better with the Kremlin's thinking than quick withdrawals this year. At the Vienna talks, the United States has proposed reducing U.S. and Soviet troops stationed abroad in the NATO and Warsaw Pact nations to 275,000 for each superpower. The Soviet Union, eager to see cuts bite into the British, French and Canadian presence in West Germany, is talking of 300,000 to 350,000 troops stationed abroad in each alliance, Western diplomats at the negotiations say. The diplomats, speaking on condition they not be identified, say that total alone suggests the Soviets were considering withdrawing from less strategic nations such as Hungary _ which has no border with NATO _ to save most of their East German presence. But the demands from Prague and Budapest mean the Soviets lose the flexibility to scatter troop cuts as they want, and can no longer make the withdrawals so gradual. A preliminary agreement at the Vienna talks is envisaged by the end of this year, but negotiators expect it to take most of the 1990s for East and West to slice the huge weapons arsenals and armies amassed in four decades of Cold War. ``This must come as an unpleasant surprise to Moscow,'' Bennendijk said in a telephone interview. ``But what choice do they have? They are not in Czechoslovakia (for instance) as occupying powers.''

DOC.HEAD: Latest In Electronic Gear: The 10-Foot, $20,000 Television
DOC.TEXT: There was a video game controller the player doesn't even need to touch. There was hand-held copier and fax unit that can send and receive transmissions from cellular phones. There was a television screen measuring 120 inches _ yes, 10 feet _ from corner to corner. Industry officials predict more than $10 billion in orders will evolve from the Winter Consumer Electronics Show, which closed Tuesday after displaying what's hot in electronic gadgetry for the 1990s. Thousands of products captured the imagination of the more than 70,000 manufacturers, dealers and journalists who visited during the four-day show. ``We thought it was quite successful,'' show spokeswoman Cynthia Upson said Thursday. ``We talked to many retailers and exhibitors. They were quite pleased it was such a tremendous show. ``The mood for 1990 is very upbeat,'' she added. ``These retailers just came off the Christmas selling season. Many were here looking into what's new for a new decade. Retailers say they expect a nice volume for the spring selling season. When you hear that, you know you've had a successful show.'' Show officials say the winter electronics show and its summer counterpart, which is held in Chicago, together stimulate orders totaling more than half of the consumer electronics industry's sales. Factory sales for the industry are expected to reach a record $33.412 billion in 1990, up from $32.166 billion in 1989. The major players at the show were big ticket items such as home entertainment advances _ giant video and surround-sound audio _ that turn a living room into a home theater. Also displayed were digital sound systems that give a car or home the sound of a concert hall or cathedral. Mitsubishi introduced a rear-projection TV with a 120-inch screen. The set measures 8 feet wide, 6 feet high and 6.5 feet deep. The tab: $20,000. New home automation devices allow a person away from home turn on the dishwasher, lock doors, set alarms, program the VCR or turn on the air conditioner, all by telephone. But smaller electronic gadgets continued to capture the imagination of visitors to the show, which has been dubbed a Disneyland for adults. Broderbund Software unveiled a video game controller that it says eliminates all physical contact between player and machine. Instead of a joystick or button, the player uses hand movement to produce a response. In the ``Mike Tyson's Punch-Out'' game, for example, throw a left jab in the air and you throw a left jab at the video version of the champ. Panasonic-Technics offered a car radio that owners can can program for their favorite type of music _ jazz, easy listening, country-western, whatever. The radio then picks up the top station in the selected category as the driver moves from city to city. Blaupunkt Borsch Telecom introduced an electronic car navigation system that allows drivers to follow a video map to get to their destination. Franklin Computer and SelecTronic introduced hand-held computers that seek out Bible verses with the touch of a button. Franklin also displayed a tiny computer that provides definitions, spelling and grammatical guidelines for more than 250,000 words in Spanish and English. Singer Michael Jackson gets into the act with a new video game by Sega dubbed ``Moonwalker.'' The game features detailed antimation based on actual film footage of Jackson's dance moves. In the game, Jackson rescues children who have been kidnapped by an evil enemy. Ricoh offered compact products for the office on-the-go, including a hand-held copier and fax unit that can send and receive transmissions from modular or cellular phones. Ms. Upson said there was a growing interest in phone and office electronic equipment because some 25 million Americans now have offices in their homes. ``The dealers and manufacturers realize there is a tremendous potential there,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Say Slain Family Was Quiet, Pious, Poor
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Dennis and Cheryl Avery were a quiet couple who never had much money but were devoted to their three daughters and their church. Unhappy with the ordination of women and other changes in the church, they followed lay minister Jeffrey Lundgren to Ohio and became allied with his breakaway fundamentalist cult. They apparently became so controlled by him they turned over their paychecks and bought a gun for him on their credit card. And it may have been that very gun that killed them and their daughters last spring, police say. Lundgren and other cult members are charged in their slayings. ``They were very sweet, very family-oriented people,'' said Norma Corkern, a librarian who made friends with the Averys more than 10 years ago in Independence. ``Very loving. It just didn't make sense for them to be there.'' Avery, 49; Mrs. Avery, 42; and daughters Trina, 15, Rebecca, 13, and Karen, 7, were last seen in April, shortly after they told others in Ohio that they were moving to Wyoming. Their bodies were found Jan. 3-4 at the farm commune near Kirtland, Ohio, where the cult stayed, after police received an anonymous tip. They had been bound with duct tape, shot and buried in a barn. Police theorize that the deaths were a ritual sacrifice to cleanse the cult. Lundgren, 39, his 19-year-old son and three other cult members are charged with their murders. His wife and seven others are charged with conspiracy. The deaths left those who knew them struggling to understand what went wrong. ``I just think they didn't know what they were getting into when they went to Kirtland,'' said Marie Haworth, a friend from Independence. Avery and his wife both grew up on the West Coast as members of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, a church that has roots in common with the Mormon Church but is separate. They were married in Independence, where the church is based, in 1970. Avery, who worked 17 years as a computer programmer for a Kansas City bank, was a deacon in one of the RLDS congregations dotting the Independence area. Mrs. Avery taught preschool and Sunday school, sewed her family's clothes and took her bookworm daughters to summer reading programs at the public library. The family lived in a small house in an older section of Independence. The daughters attended public schools until May 1986, then were schooled at home, church records show. When the RLDS church voted to ordain women in 1984, the Averys and many others were unhappy, Mrs. Haworth said. They moved to a different congregation, where they met Lundgren, who had grown up in Independence and been ordained an RLDS lay minister. Lundgren moved to Kirtland in 1984 to become a volunteer guide at an RLDS temple, and the Averys followed in 1987. No one knows when Lundgren and his followers made the switch from his fundamentalist RLDS teachings to a cult whose members drank heavily, trained for paramilitary activities and called their leader ``the prophet,'' said Grant McMurry, the RLDS' world church secretary. Mrs. Avery's mother, Donna Bailey of Centralia, Wash., said she telephoned and wrote her daughter frequently after the Averys moved to Ohio. ``I caught on early on that these were the wrong types of beliefs,'' Mrs. Bailey said in an interview published Friday in The Kansas City Times. ``At one time she said, `People think we're a cult, but we're not.' That made me concerned.'' Shortly after the Averys arrived in Ohio, Lundgren was asked to resign from the temple position, and he was eventually defrocked after his teachings became ``un-Christian,'' said the Rev. Dale Luffman, head of the northeast Ohio chapter of RLDS. The Averys broke all ties with the RLDS church after Lundgren was asked to resign. Unlike most of Lundgren's followers, the Averys lived in town, about three miles from the commune. Avery worked at a security company and did odd jobs. His wife worked at a fast food restaurant. Dennis Yarborough, police chief in Kirtland, said cult members turned over their paychecks to Lundgren. Lundgren often seemed irritated with Avery, according to John Olivarez, whose daughter once lived at the commune. Bonnie Olivarez, then 11, lived there with her mother in spring 1988, until Olivarez regained custody. The mother is charged in the murders. Olivarez said according to his daughter, Lundgren ``would complain that Mr. Avery could only do five pushups. Everybody else was doing 20 or 30.'' The Averys moved in the fall of 1988 to a home about 30 miles from the commune, leaving several months of back rent unpaid, said landlord Stan Skrbis in Kirtland. But the family apparently kept its ties with the cult. Avery used his credit card to buy a .45-caliber gun for Lundgren shortly before the killings. Authorities say a gun of that caliber was used in the murders. No one knows why the Averys were picked. ``These were all people from nice families in our community _ not just the Averys but the people who are in trouble, too,'' said Mrs. Haworth. Mrs. Corkern added, ``The worst thing is those little girls _ they never had a chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Match Iranian POW Release, Red Cross Says
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross announced Saturday that Iraq has agreed to free 50 disabled Iranian POWs, clearing the way for the first prisoner exchange between the two countries in more than a year. Peace talks between Iran and Iraq have been stalled almost since they began in August 1988, and the deadlock has left an estimated 100,000 captives on both sides languishing in POW camps. Some have been held since the early stages of the war, which began in September 1980. The International Committee of the Red Cross said 50 Iranian POWs will be released and returned to Iran after Iran returns 50 Iraqi prisoners to Baghdad. Iran's U.N. ambassador, Kamal Kharrazi, announced in New York last week that Iran would release the ailing Iraqis. The Iraqi authorities have ``promised to reciprocate with the release of an equal number'' of POWs, a Red Cross official said Saturday. The Iraqis are scheduled to be set free Wednesday, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said a Swiss airliner had been chartered to fly the Iraqis home. U.N. officials have registered 55,000 POWs held by Iran and 19,500 by Iraqi, but they believe the total held by both sides is about 100,000. Both sides hold a total of about 1,000 ailing or disabled prisoners. The 1948 Geneva Convention stipulates that all prisoners of war should be released when hostilities cease. A cease-fire halted fighting between Iran and Iraq in August 1988, but the POWs have become pawns as both sides quarrel over details of the U.N. resolution that cleared the way for the cease-fire. In 1988, the two sides exchanged about 400 disabled and ailing prisoners. The operation collapsed in November of that year as each country accused the other of lying about the number of captives they held. This month, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offered to restart the peace talks and said Iraq was ready to exchange all disabled and sick prisoners as a first step toward a total prisoner exchange. Iran countered that it would not agree to total swap, or to implement other clauses of the cease-fire resolution, until Iraq withdrew from Iranian border areas captured during the final days of fighting. But Iranian officials have expressed support for a Soviet offer to mediate a new round of peace talks. The Soviets have close links with Iraq and were its main arms supplier during the war. Relations between Moscow and Tehran have improved considerably since the war ended. Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said Tehran would consider any Soviet proposal ``containing a systematic and clearly defined formula for the implementation of U.N. Security Council Resolution 598,'' the cease-fire resolution. The Iraqi foreign ministry also welcomed the Soviet offer.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SAN SALVADOR
Leftist Salvadoran Politician Found Dead In Guatemala
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with confirmation, bodies found Thursday, paramilitary groups blamed, CORRECTS location on Jalpatagua. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A prominent leftist Salvadoran politician who was reportedly kidnapped in Guatemala City was found shot to death near the Guatemala-El Salvador border, officials said today. No one claimed responsibility for the slaying, but a Guatemalan politician blamed it on Guatemalan and Salvadoran paramilitary groups. The body of Hector Oqueli Colindres, 45, deputy secretary-general of the National Revolutionary Movement in El Salvador, was discovered Friday night in Jalpatagua, a city 60 miles east of Guatemala City, his party said. Oqueli had been shot in the head, a spokesman for the opposition National Revolutionary Movement said in El Salvador. Gilda Flores, a Guatemalan who was driving Oqueli to the airport in Guatemala City when they were reportedly kidnapped Friday, also was found dead, according to the party official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mario Solorzano Martinez, secretary-general of Guatemala's Social Democratic Party, confirmed the party's report and deplored the slayings. ``We energetically condemn this act, which shows that the authorities are inefficient,'' he said. ``...this is an combined action of Guatemalan and Salvadoran paramilitary forces. It's obvious this was well planned.'' He said the victims' bodies were taken to a hospital in Cuilapa, 40 miles east of Guatemala City and would be moved to a funeral home in Guatemala City. Oqueli and Ms. Flores were abducted by armed men early Friday morning, his party said in an earlier statement. The Salvadoran politician was reportedly on his way to Managua, where he was to help monitor preparations for the Nicaraguan election on Feb. 25. Oqueli, who had been in Guatemala since Jan. 11, also was reportedly planning to attend a meeting of Latin American socialist leaders in Ecuador. The leader of the National Revolutionary Movement, Guillermo Ungo, was the presidential candidate of a leftist coalition in the March elections in El Salvador. Ungo could not immediately be reached for comment today. Before his body was found, Oqueli's party condemned his kidnapping, saying it ``demonstrates again the insecurity that exists in our country.'' Oqueli was a deputy foreign minister in Salvador from October 1979 until March 1980, when a military coup overthrew the government. Like many other leftists, he quit El Salvador after the coup, but he returned to his country in 1987 to participate in politics. The slayings come at a time of increasing political violence in El Salvador and Guatemala, where rightist factions have longstanding ties. The governing rightist party in El Salvador, known by the Spanish acronym Arena, was founded in Guatemala in the 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Time Alliance Will Continue, With Adjustments, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Cuba continues to be an important military and intelligence asset for the Soviet Union and the long-standing Moscow-Havana alliance is expected to survive deepening ideological differences, according to analysts. There is little question that the relationship is far less relaxed than it was before Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev assumed power but the consensus among experts is that Cuba is too valuable for the Soviets to cast aside. Still, as U.S. officials see it, there is evidence of a decline in Soviet assistance to Cuba, a trend that may continue but not to the point where the survival of the regime is threatened. One example of the strength of the relationship was the recent delivery of Soviet MiG-29 jet fighters to Cuba, the officials say. Says Cornell University professor Rhoda Rabkin, ``There is little sign that the Gorbachev era leadership considers Cuba an expendable Soviet commitment.'' Among other assets, she notes the Soviets have an extensive electronic intelligence gathering facility in Cuba and installations that enable Soviet long-range reconnaissance aircraft to monitor U.S. East Coast military activities. Thanks to Cuba, the Soviets also are able to maintain a strategic naval presence in the Caribbean. Professor Jaime Suchlicki of the University of Miami's Institute of Inter-American Studies points out that these Soviet activities have forced the United States to install expensive surveillance and tracking facilities to keep an eye on the Soviets. Gillian Gunn, an associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a Washington research group, says Soviet leaders have been cool to U.S. admonitions that they distance themselves from Castro. Gorbachev has left the impression he opposes Castro's effort to promote subversion in the hemisphere. But the Soviets have told U.S. officials privately they have no way of knowing how Castro would react if they pushed him too hard, according to Ms. Gunn. ``If they tinker with his aid, he could mess around with their military access,'' she says, summing up Soviet concerns. Soviet bloc arms continue to find their way to Central America via Cuba, but the Bush administration is more inclined to blame Havana than Moscow. Uncertainty about Soviet-Cuban relations has arisen as a result of Castro's repudiation of perestroika and glasnost and Gorbachev's willingness to nudge hard-line regimes from power in Eastern Europe. A strain in relations was evident last summer when Castro banned two Soviet Spanish-language publications because he was offended by their irreverent comments about socialism. Castro has said that death is preferable to abandonment of socialism. U.S. officials say there is one area in which Soviet aid to Cuba appears to have dried up. The Soviets used to provide Cuba with surplus oil, enabling Castro to sell the commodity at world market prices for a handsome profit. According to the Economist Newsletter, revenues from oil exports reached $621 million in 1985 and then fell sharply. Last year, the earnings were ``almost certainly nothing,'' it said. Gorbachev has called for ``stricter accountability'' in the way Cuba uses Soviet aid, estimated at $4.3 billion by U.S. officials. No recipient of U.S. aid gets nearly as much. One official said that given Gorbachev's emphasis on improving living standards in the Soviet Union, ``he would like to reduce his economic burden in Cuba (further) but not to be point where the survivability of the regime comes into doubt.'' One test of the durability of the Soviet-Cuban relationship will come next year when payments on Cuba's substantial Soviet debt, estimated at $10 billion, fall due. It is widely expected that Cuba will ask for lenient terms. Just how accommodating the Soviets will be remains a question mark.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says He'll Push in Latin America for Recognition of Panama Regime
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Saturday he will press Latin American nations to recognize the U.S-installed Panamanian government when he travels to the region. Quayle, in Utah for a fund-raising ski race, told a news conference he intends to go beyond fence-mending during three trips he plans to Central and South America over the next two to eight weeks. ``The president wants me to go down and have a very strong consultation process with our Latin American friends,'' Quayle said. ``The mission is one to not only have consultations, but to talk about the liberation aspects of the people of Panama.'' Many Latin American officials say Quayle will have a tough time explaining the Dec. 20 invasion by 14,000 U.S. troops as anything other than a violation of Panama's sovereignty, especially while an invasion force remains. But the vice president said from his talks with Latin leaders, he is convinced they understand that President Bush ordered troops into Panama as a last resort. Quayle's itinerary is still being put together, with the only announced stop his attendance at the Jan. 27 presidential inauguration in Honduras. As for shoring up the civilian government of Guillermo Endara, installed as Panama's president after the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Quayle said one of the first things the United States can do is ``to attempt to have other governments recognize the Endara government.'' Endara was a presidential candidate in a May 7 election that independent observers said he won handily but which was subsequently invalidated by Noriega. Some Latin American nations contend Endara, to earn authority on his own, must be installed either by a new election or by the Panamanian Congress. Quayle said the new government has the support of the Panamanian people, but must now make strong efforts to build a judicial system, reform the Panamanian Defense Force, and strengthen the economy. ``What's important now is that Endara moves forward to hold and maintain the support he has now,'' Quayle said. The vice president made these other comments: _ He said Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev is in ``full control of the political situation in his country, and is doing his best to reform a situation that desperately needs to be reformed.'' _ He predicted disappointment for those who have suggested that changes in Eastern Europe will save the United States money on defense. ``Obviously, there will be modest changes in expenditures for national security, but no huge shift in domestic and non-domestic spending,'' Quayle said. _ He took issue with use of the word ``blockade'' to describe the recent presence of U.S. naval forces off the coast of Colombia. He said the vessels went to the area only in the event the Colombian government needed assistance in cracking down on the drug trade. ``We will not impose ourselves on the Colombians,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reported US Memories Failure Said Sign of Need for High-Tech Policy
DOC.TEXT: The reported impending shutdown of a $1 billion private consortium to produce computer memory chips points to the need for new government policies to help encourage long-term investment by high-technology companies, a congressman said Saturday. The seven-company joint venture, U.S. Memories, had been launched last summer as an effort to challenge Japanese dominance of the memory chip market. Rep. Robert S. Walker, R-Pa., ranking minority member of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, responded to published reports that U.S. Memories would announce Monday it was folding because it had failed to attract enough investors. ``I think what it indicates is the need for national policies that encourage a better investment climate for high-tech industries,'' Walker said. He added: ``Part of the problem right now is that our investment climate in this country is not such that most businesses want to take long-term risks. And that is apparently one of the considerations here.'' Walker said that to help deal with this situation, Congress should enact the capital-gains tax reduction being advocated by the Bush administration and also should approve a permanent extension of the research and development tax credit. The New York Times, The Washington Post and the Austin (Texas) American-Statesman carried stories Saturday citing unidentified electronics industry sources as saying the dissolution of U.S. Memories would be announced at a news conference Monday in Santa Clara, Calif. The Times said that while Sanford L. Kane, president of U.S. Memories, would not comment on the reports, he did say he was extremely frustrated by his failure to persuade computer companies to sign up for the venture. ``One can only bang their head against the wall for so long. Sooner or later you get a headache,'' the Times quoted Kane as saying. U.S. Memories had planned to raise $500 million in equity from computer and semiconductor companies and $500 million in debt to build a large-scale memory chip plant. However, the venture has not been able to sign up any investors beyond the seven companies that launched U.S. Memories last June. Those members were three computer companies _ IBM, Digital Equipment Corp. and Hewlett-Packard _ and four semiconductor companies _ Advanced Micro Devices, Intel, LSI Logic and National Semiconductor. Today U.S. companies rely primarily on Japanese manufacturers of dynamic random-access memory chips, or DRAMs. In 1988, Japan controlled about 80 percent of the $6.4 billion market. Currently, DRAMs have been in ample supply and prices have plummeted, thus removing the urgency for a new domestic source such as U.S. Memories. However, U.S. Memories supporters had warned that companies rejecting the idea merely because of the current market glut were being shortsighted. On that issue, The Washington Post quoted Brookings Institution analyst Kenneth Flamm as saying: ``The bottom line is that the great memory glut is going to be a short-term phenomenon.''

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Border Guard Claims Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers on Saturday quoted an Albanian border guard who fled the country as saying security forces fired on protesters last week and that one city was in a state of ``revolution.'' Yugoslavia's Tanjug news agency, meanwhile, said there was ``nothing unusual'' going on in Albania, one day after reporting that authorities there had imposed a virtual state of emergency to prevent unrest. Also Saturday, the Albanian state-run news agency ATA quoted an Italian diplomat as denying there was unrest in the isolated country. Albania, located between Greece and Yugoslavia, is the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe and is closed to most foreigners, so none of the reports could be independently confirmed. Daily newspapers in Greece on Saturday quoted Albert Tzeka, 20, as saying widespread protests had broken out in at least three cities in his country against the hard-line Communist leadership. ``The people have risen up. The people and the students ... especially in Shkoder, Korce and Sarande,'' Tzeka was quoted as saying. ``In Shkoder there is a revolution. The army and the sigurimi (security police) fired on the people and there are many dead and injured,'' the daily Kathimerini quoted Tzeka as saying. Yugoslav and Greek newspapers have carried unconfirmed reports since Thursday of demonstrations and a state of emergency in Shkoder, Albania's second-largest city. Tzeka said that in Shkoder, ``the police, wanting to subdue the demonstrators, fired upon them. They hanged four students to set an example.'' He added that the demonstrators seemed determined to continue their uprising. The Athens newspapers did not say how Tzeka, who was serving on the southern Albanian border, obtained his information, particularly about Shkoder, which is in the north. The newspaper Eleftherotypia quoted Tzeka as saying that ``we learn everything in my country by word of mouth.'' Tzeka said also that border patrols along the Greek and Yugoslav borders were intensified after the December uprising in Romania, which ousted the Stalinist leadership of Nicolae Ceausescu. He was quoted as saying Albanian soldiers had been ordered to kill anyone trying to escape. An officer at the Greek border village of Filiates confirmed Tzeka crossed the Albanian border Tuesday and requested political asylum. Albanian authorities have consistently denied any trouble in their country, describing reports of turmoil as ``slander.'' Tzeka could not be reached by The Associated Press on Saturday. In Yugoslavia, the Tanjug news agency said information available from police and travelers at the Yugoslav-Albanian border Saturday suggested there was ``nothing unusual, nothing special'' in Albania. It said even shopping trips by diplomats in Albania, who usually visit the Yugoslav towns of Struga and Ohrid over the weekend, have not been halted. On Friday, Tanjug reported that ``Albanian authorities, in an effort to prevent unrest against the regime, have imposed extremely strict control measures in the country.'' It said the security measures ``can be termed a state of emergency,'' but did not say when the measures were allegedly imposed. Albania's ATA news agency Saturday quoted Paolo de Nicola, the interim charge d'affaires of the Italian Embassy in Tirana, as saying at the Foreign Ministry that Italian media reports about unrest in Albania ``do not refer to reality, they are groundless.'' Miloslav Milic, a reporter for Belgrade television from Yugoslavia's Kosovo province which borders Alabania, told The Associated Press that ``frequent sound of firearms'' was heard Friday from the direction of Albania.

DOC.HEAD: 1 Killed, 10 Wounded in Tripoli Bombings
DOC.TEXT: Three bombs exploded near Syrian army checkpoints in a commerical district of Tripoli on Saturday, killing one civilian, wounding 10 and causing panic among commuters during the morning rush hour. Elsewhere, scattered clashes were reported Saturday between rival forces in Beirut and south Lebanon, but no casualties were reported. Late Friday, a bomb exploded near the abandoned Saudi Arabian Embassy in a residential neighborhood of west Beirut, but no injuries were reported. None of the feuding factions in Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war claimed responsibility for the explosions at three different locations on the sidewalks of Tripoli. However, a police spokesman who demanded anonymity said they were probably a protest of the Syrian military presence in the city. Police said panic swept Tripoli's central business section when the bombs detonated a few minutes apart around 9 a.m. Police said frightened motorists caused major traffic jams trying to flee the area. Tripoli's 850,000 inhabitants are mainly Sunni Moslems, who work on Saturday and take Friday off. Each bomb contained about six pounds of TNT and exploded within 15 yards of Syrian checkpoints in Lebanon's second-largest city, 50 miles north of Beirut. Tripoli has been policed by the Syrian army since 1983, when Syrian-backed dissident Palestinian groups forced Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organizaion from their last stronghold in Lebanon after Israel's 1982 invasion. A bombing campaign also occurred in Moslem west Beirut after Syrian troops arrived there in 1987 to end three years of anarchy by feuding Moslem militias. Saturday's explosions shattered windows within a two-mile radius, leaving streets carpeted with glass shards, and damaged 14 cars, police reported. They said the fatality from the first blast was a 65-year-old electrical tools salesman. The other casualties were passers-by. Tripoli's Coordination Committee, which runs day-to-day administrative affairs, blamed the bombings on the forces of the rebel Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, who seeks to force the Syrian army out of Lebanon. ``This is the way the outlaw general sees fit to carry on his so-called war of liberation,'' the committee declared in a statement. Aoun's mainly Christian army units and Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen clashed with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades before dawn across Beirut's dividing Green Line Saturday. Police reported no casualties in the one-hour firefight. But it underlined a marked increase in tension in the divided capital. At least four people have been killed ans 12 wounded in gunbattles along the three-mile-long demarcation line in the last week. The violence violates a cease-fire that took effect in September, ending six months of fierce artillery battles between Aoun's troops and the Syrians. The four-pound bomb in Beirut exploded late Friday night under a car parked 80 yards from the abandoned Saudi Arabian Embassy in the residential Manara neighborhood of west Beirut. The embassy was closed in 1985 after it was ransacked and burned by Shiite Moslem militants of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. They were protesting Saudi curbs on the number of Iranians allowed to make the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, after riots there in 1987 that the Saudis blamed on Iranian instigators.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Faces Renewed Debate Over Martin Luther King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: When Arizona lawmakers ended years of bitter debate in September by creating a state holiday to honor the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., it seemed the issue finally had been put to rest. But four months later, as 46 other states and the federal government prepare to honor the slain civil rights leader on Monday, Arizona's holiday is on hold and the state faces more months of divisive debate before voters settle the controversy in November. Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a holiday by executive order in 1986, but it was rescinded by his successor, Republican Evan Mecham, after the state attorney general ruled that Babbitt's order was illegal. Year after year, the Republican-controlled Legislature refused to enact the holiday but offered to put it before the voters. Supporters rejected that option, saying privately that they feared it would be rejected and that the campaign would divide the state and cause further harm to its image. Democrat Rose Mofford, who became governor when Mecham was removed by impeachment convictions, finally found the key to getting a King holiday bill through the Legislature during a September special session. She got business leaders to spur lawmakers into action by arguing that not having a King holiday was hurting the state's economy and could kill its chances of landing the 1993 Super Bowl. Dozens of conventions and meetings had been canceled in 1987 and 1988 in a boycott to protest Mecham's cancellation of the holiday. The state estimated the lost convention and tourism receipts at more than $25 million. The Legislature agreed to the holiday, but only if it supplanted Columbus Day so that state employees would not be given an additional paid day off. That set the stage for two groups _ those who didn't think King deserved a holiday and the Italian-Americans who wanted Columbus Day preserved _ to launch a petition drive to put the issue on the November ballot. They collected nearly 80,000 petition signatures, nearly twice the number required, in only three months. The King holiday was put on hold in December pending the outcome of the referendum effort. Among other things, that means Arizona still will observe Columbus Day in 1990. Julian Sanders, a conservative activist who spearheaded the petition drive, said he was convinced that a majority of Arizonans don't want a King holiday. ``The people in Arizona are really angry about what's transpired,'' he said. ``It will still go down 2 to 1.'' Supporters of the holiday have begun organizing for what many believe will be a bitter campaign, and say they fear the rejection of the King holiday here could strengthen opposition to the holiday elsewhere. ``Should Arizona rescind the King holiday, this will simply be the first state to put that issue on the ballot,'' said Sen. Carolyn Walker, the only black in the state Senate. ``Then it will go like dominos.'' Noting that pressure from the business community was a key in passing the King holiday bill in September, supporters hoped for continued support from that sector. ``For me, it's the wrong motivation,'' said Dr. Paul Eppinger, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Phoenix and a leading proponent of the King holiday. ``But if that's the motivation that stimulates people, I'll take it.'' Business leaders pledged support Friday at a Martin Luther King breakfast in Phoenix. ``The business community is very eager to get the holiday passed, whatever the cost is to the Legislature,'' said Bill Shover, director of public affairs for Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Arizona Republic and The Phoenix Gazette. Shover, who also is chairman of the Phoenix '93 Committee that's bidding to bring the 1993 Super Bowl to Phoenix, said business leaders fear a renewed economic boycott of the state. Sanders argues the state has not suffered economically because of the King controversy; and even if it had, that is not the issue. ``If we don't have a majority in this state that wants to honor Martin Luther King for what he was as a man, then the whole thing is a fraud and a sham,'' Sanders said. State lawmakers say it is unlikely any legislative action will be taken on the issue before November. ``This is an election year,'' said state Rep. Sandra Kennedy, a supporter of the King holiday. ``No one wants to say anything about the King holiday. They're all saying, `Let's let it go to a vote of the people.'''

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Inaugurates First Black Elected Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `To go...' to CORRECT to hull sted hall.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos RM3, RM9, LaserColor upcoming
DOC.TEXT: L. Douglas Wilder was inaugurated today as America's first elected black governor, which he called a triumph for the principles in the Declaration of Independence. Wilder, a grandson of slaves, said he wanted young people to hear Thomas Jefferson's words about freedom, so he included them in his remarks as he became Virginia's 66th governor on the grounds of the former capital of the Confederacy. Jefferson himself served as Virginia governor in Revolutionary War times. Wilder said he wanted young listerners ``to know that oppression can be lifted, that discrimination can be eliminated, that poverty need not be binding, that disability can be overcome.'' He reminded them, though, that the offer of opportunity ``carries with it the requirement of hard work, the rejection of drugs and other false highs, and a willingness to work with others whatever their color or national origin.'' Retired Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the U.S. Supreme Court administered the oath of office to Wilder, who had been lieutenant governor, before 15,000 guests at the Capitol. The 58-year-old Wilder, a self-proclaimed ``mainstream'' Democrat, won the closest gubernatorial election in Virginia history on Nov. 7. A recount demanded by Republican opponent J. Marshall Coleman resulted in a Dec. 21 certification of a 6,741-vote victory margin, or less than half a percent. He is the first black elected governor in any state, but one black, P.B.S. Pinchback, served temporarily as Louisiana governor for 43 days in late 1872 and early 1873 after the governor was impeached and removed from office. The inauguration was preceded by a prayer service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, where Confederate President Jefferson Davis was confirmed, and the ceremonial presentation of the keys to the Executive Mansion by outgoing Gov. Gerald L. Baliles. Jesse Jackson and former tennis star Arthur Ashe attended the prayer service. Wilder hadn't let Jackson campaign on his behalf, but Wilder's press secretary, Laura Dillard, said Jackson was invited to the inauguration because ``it's appropriate. He's a leading national figure in Democratic circles.'' Jackson described the inauguration as a historic moment. ``To go from the hull of a slave ship to governor is a great American story,'' he said. ``It's a great world story.'' Wilder said Virginians are witnessing times when the ``whirlinds of rebellion shake all shores where tyranny once ruled, and we are redeemed in our deeply held and treasured beliefs in the development of the high possibility of every individual who breathes the sweetness of liberty's air.'' Wilder said his administration would be challenged to maintain freedom because of the slowing economy. ``But progress will be possible ...,'' he said. ``Resources employed in the past for the finer things in life can be _ and will have to be _ deployed for the more serious of our needs. For we know that freedom is but a word for the man or woman who needs and cannot find a job.'' About 12,500 tickets were sold for the Inaugural Ball at the Richmond Coliseum, and a huge tent was erected outside to handle the overflow crowd. Tickets cost $50 and box seats went for $2,500 to $7,500. Wilder, who is divorced, said his son and two daughters would accompany him to the ball. He was to deliver his first gubernatorial address to the General Assembly on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: The Families of Charles and Carol Stuart: What They Knew, When They Knew
With AM-Stuart-Death and Deceit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are members of the families of Charles and Carol Stuart and when they apparently knew that Charles Stuart's mugging story was a hoax and that he was a suspect in her murder:
DOC.HEAD: EVELYN DIMAITI, 58
GIUSTO DIMAITI, 64
DOC.TEXT: The parents of Carol Stuart and residents in the Boston suburb of Medford. They did not know until Charles Stuart's suicide on Jan. 4 that he was in any way linked to the crime.
