Shortly after news of the suicide broke, DiMaiti was rushed to a hospital for observation after he had trouble breathing. Until recently he worked for Sonny's Pizza, a family business in Chelsea that makes pizza dough.
DOC.HEAD: CARL DIMAITI, 37
DOC.TEXT: Carol Stuart's older brother and only sibling. He lives in Medford and also works for Sonny's Pizza. He has said he knew nothing until authorities linked Charles Stuart to the slaying shortly after his suicide.
DOC.HEAD: DOROTHY STUART, 60
CHARLES STUART SR., 67
DOC.TEXT: Both are the parents of Charles, Matthew, Michael and Mark Stuart. Stuart Sr., a retired insurance salesman, is the father also of Shelley Yandoli and Neysa Porter, daughters born to his late first wife. The couple live in Revere. They apparently learned their eldest son was a suspect at a family gathering Jan. 2, two days before he committed suicide.
DOC.HEAD: MATTHEW STUART, 23
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart's youngest brother and a mixer at a paint factory. Matthew Stuart has said through his lawyer that he met Charles at the crime scene and disposed of a gun and a purse containing some of Carol Stuart's belongings. He said the shootings must have occurred by time the meeting occurred but that he did not realize either person was shot until later. It is not known when the brothers struck the arrangement to meet at the crime scene.
DOC.HEAD: MICHAEL STUART, 28
DOC.TEXT: A firefighter in Revere. Michael Stuart has said through his lawyer that Matthew told him three days after the Oct. 23 shootings that their sister-in-law apparently had been shot by Charles. He also said Charles approached him weeks before the crime and talked vaguely of a plot, but that he replied he didn't know what Charles was talking about and didn't want anything to do with it. He said the discussion seemed significant only in retrospect.
DOC.HEAD: SHELLEY YANDOLI, 36
DOC.TEXT: A half sister to the Stuart brothers and a part-time bartender at a Revere restaurant owned by some cousins. A telephone conversation between her and Michael Stuart before the family gathering Jan. 2 reveals that she knew by that time that Charles was involved in the shooting. The conversation was routinely taped at the firehouse where Michael Stuart worked.
DOC.HEAD: MARK STUART, 26
DOC.TEXT: A computer operator who lives in Revere. He has said through an attorney that he learned Jan. 1 that the mugging story was a hoax, but it is not clear which of his siblings informed him.
DOC.HEAD: NEYSA PORTER, 34
DOC.TEXT: Shelley Yandoli's sister and a half sister to the four brothers. She is a housewife and mother of two. She apparently learned Charles was a suspect the same time as her parents at the Jan. 2 family gathering.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airliner Crashes in the Urals, 23 Killed
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet airliner with a flaming engine crashed Saturday while attempting an emergency landing on a field in the Ural Mountains, and 23 people were killed, the Tass news agency said. Thirty people were injured, Tass said. The Tupolev-134 jet, carrying 64 passengers and six crew members, was flying from the Siberian oil center of Tyumen to Volgograd via the Ural Mountain city of Ufa, Tass said. An engine caught fire, and the jet crashed while the crew tried to land at a farm about 30 miles from the Ural industrial city of Sverdlovsk, 870 miles east of Moscow, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Men Return Home After Four Decades
DOC.TEXT: Two men who served Japan's war effort in Malaysia during World War II and remained in a remote jungle to help Communist rebels for 45 years returned home Saturday saying they hope to help modern-day Japan. Relatives and friends greeted Shigeyuki Hashimoto, 71, and Kiyoaki Tanaka, 77, with flowers at Tokyo's Narita airport as the men, appearing frail and weary, were taken from their plane in wheelchairs. The two, who left in 1944 to work in a wartime Japanese iron factory in Malaysia _ then called Malaya _ said they joined Communist guerrillas after the war in 1945 to help the country gain independence from Britain, Japan's former enemy. ``We fought for a long time and faced a range of difficulties,'' Hashimoto told reporters. ``We lost touch with all of our old friends. Now only the two of us are still alive.'' On Wednesday, the two men left the Malaysian border jungle where they and their comrades in the Communist Party of Malaya fought for 45 years. The insurgency ended in December, when Communist leaders reached a peace agreement with Malaysian and Thai government officials. ``We're Japanese, so we never forgot about Japan, even for one day,'' Tanaka said. ``We looked forward greatly to returning to Japan, but as Japanese we couldn't leave behind the people we were fighting alongside for all those years until this opportunity.'' Tanaka's wife, Haruse, 72, was unable to travel to the airport because of illness, but she watched her husband's return on television. Several other relatives had flown earlier to Thailand to meet the men and accompanied them back to Japan. ``I never doubted he was still alive but I did not hear from him or about him for nearly 50 years, so of course I was worried,'' said Hashimoto's sister, Kikuko Ishiwatari, 74. Both will be hospitalized for about 10 days for medical check-ups, a Health and Welfare Ministry official said. ``I don't know anything about modern-day Japan,'' Hashimoto told reporters in a weak voice. ``But I hope to learn as much as possible and do what I can to help the nation.'' When Malaya gained its independence from Britain in 1957, Hashimoto said, ``We could have returned to Japan but it would have required our surrender to the Malaya government, and we chose not to do so.'' He said they decided to fight until the Communist insurgency ended and they succeeded in establishing a Maoist state. ``But last year, a peace accord was reached and we became finally free so we could come back to Japan.'' His account was interrupted by doctors who cautioned him against further efforts to speak. While in the jungle, the two men reportedly learned of changes in Japan from a shortwave radio. During the insurgency, the Communists fought against British Commonwealth forces in bloody battles during what was known as the 1948-1960 ``emergency.'' Fighting then continued on a lesser scale. More recently, Thai-Malaysian military strikes and a Thai amnesty badly hurt the guerrilla movement, leading to December's peace agreement. Over the years, a number of former Japanese Imperial Army soldiers have emerged from long periods of isolation in remote areas of Asia controlled by Japan during World War II. The government is investigating the cases of 48 former Japanese soldiers who could still be alive, according to the Health and Welfare Ministry.

DOC.HEAD: New Data Casts Doubt About Formation of Stars and Galaxies, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: A satellite designed to detect patterns of cosmic creation has found nothing to explain how basic structures in the universe, such as galaxies and stars, came to exist, researchers said Saturday. In a news conference announcing first results from the Cosmic Background Explorer satellite launched last November, four scientists said instruments detected none of the patterns of microwave and infrared radiation that would help to explain how stars and galaxies started forming shortly after the Big Bang primordial explosion 15 billion years ago. The scientists, presenting their findings on the final day of the 175th national meeting of the American Astronomical Society, said the satellite found nothing that would disprove the Big Bang, but the data did not unravel mysteries of the processes since. ``I am completely mystified how the present structures (in the universe) came to exist without leaving some trace,'' said John Mather, an astronomer at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Space Flight Center. He said the finding adds to the puzzle, but he believes more data from the satellite may eventually produce a solution. ``We have not eliminated our existence yet. We are here,'' he said. This existence alone, he implied, proves that there was a process releasing energy after the Big Bang. The $150 million COBE satellite, launched Nov. 15, carried into space for the first time instruments designed to detect microwave and infrared radiation created shortly after the Big Bang, the explosion that started formation of the universe. It was expected that the three satellite instruments _ one for microwave and two for infrared _ would find energy traces of the violent, superheated processes that formed the stars, galaxies, black holes, quasars and other structures in the universe. Current theories are that bits of matter at many points in the universe formed small centers of gravitational attraction that drew more and more bits of matter together until the centers became so dense that stars were born. Once a group of stars were formed, their mutual attraction, in turn, led to galaxies, and then to clusters of galaxies, and eventually to structures that form patterns reaching hundreds of millions of light years across the sky. According to the theories, the tremendous heat from such processes would produce microwave and infrared radiation, some of which should still be detectable in the vast reaches of space. In order for these models to be correct, however, scientists expected that COBE would detect ``lumps'' or ``seeds'' _ the radiation signatures of dense pockets of matter that came together very early in time. Instead, NASA researchers said they so far have found that the infrared and microwave background is completely ``smooth'' from one year to 1 million years after the Big Bang, the period in which star formation is believed to have begun. ``We have detected data for a smooth early universe,'' said George Smoot of the University of California, Berkeley. He said it was hoped that by studying the fossil radiation from that distant time, COBE investigators would have answers to what shaped the current universe, ``but instead we just keep making the problem worse.'' ``An infinite universe that is as smooth as a baby's bottom wouldn't have any way to go,'' said Mather. ``There's got to be a seed or nucleus to pull things together. We didn't find anything.'' Michael Hauser of Goddard, the principal investigator on a broad spectrum infrared instrument designed to look for what he called ``relic radiation of primordial luminous objects'' said it was too early to draw conclusions. All of the COBE investigators emphasized that the current information is ``very preliminary'' and more readings during the yearlong life of COBE may change the picture completely. But Ned Wright, an astronomer at the University of California, Los Angeles, said the finding ``rules out any great cataclysmic events at any time after the Big Bang.'' Stephan P. Maran, an astronomer associated with NASA's space telescope project, said the COBE findings ``are not consistent with those theories on the origin of the large scale structures that we observe in the universe now.'' He added: ``This may mean that some new kind of physical phenomena may have to be recognized as the origin of these structures, or the theories need to be improved.'' Nancy Boggess, another member of the COBE science team, said all instruments on the satellite worked perfectly. A NASA statement said the instruments ``are performing exquisitely with precision never before achieved.''

DOC.HEAD: Deaths Reported in Rampage in Azerbaijani Capital
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Groups of people went on a rampage Saturday night in the capital of Soviet Azerbaijan, causing an unspecified number of deaths, the official Tass news agency reported. Tass said government and Communist Party authorities in the Caucasus republic of Azerbaijan called on citizens to aid law enforcement authorities, indicating the events in the capital of Baku were serious. The latest violence in the ethnically torn southern republic occurred as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded a three-day visit to Lithuania in which he failed to turn back the Baltic republic's independence movement. Gorbachev has repeatedly warned that regional independence movements and ethnic conflicts could doom his political and economic reform movement. Telephone calls from Moscow to Baku, an oil-producing center and port on the Caspian Sea, did not go through Saturday night, so independent confirmation of the Tass report was not immediately possible. Tass said ``groups of hooligan elements'' had rampaged in the city of 1.7 million people. ``Tragic events ensued, there are human victims,'' it said. Soviet authorities use the phrase ``human victims'' to refer to deaths. The report said authorities had taken steps to restore order in Baku and that police had arrested people ``suspected of committing acts of violence.'' It gave no details. Other official reports told of weapons being seized in Azerbaijan on Saturday and of villages besieged by assailants. In another Caucasus republic, Georgia, activists said scattered strikes continued Saturday to press Communist Party leaders to come to the republic and consider demands for it to secede from the Soviet Union. The Georgian capital, Tbilisi, has been the scene of political rallies for days. The violence in Azerbaijan began in 1988 when the mostly Moslem republic began arguing with neighboring Armenia over who should govern the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. The enclave is in Azerbaijan but dominated by Armenians, who are mostly Christians. The dispute ignited a virtual civil war between the republics. Tass said arms were seized Saturday by police in Stepanakert, Nagorno-Karabakh's administrative center. The cache included two homemade mortars, a machine gun, 17 rifles and dozens of explosive devices, the report said. The weapons arrived in mail brought to the city aboard a jet from Yerevan, Armenia's capital, Tass said. Elsewhere, ethnic Armenians tried Saturday to surround several mostly Azerbaijani villages in Nagorno-Karabakh, according to the Azerbaijani news agency Azerinform. The news agency's deputy director, Savili Peretz, said he knew of no casualties. On Friday, Azerbaijanis wearing bulletproof vests and armed with machine guns caused unspecified casualties in the Armenian village of Manashid, Tass said. The news agency said Friday that Lt. I. Tsymbalyuk of the Interior Ministry, which is trying to keep order in the region, was shot and killed in the Azerbaijani village of Akhullu, apparently by an Azerbaijani policeman. Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of 160,000 people, has been under Azerbaijani control since 1923. Attempts to annex it to Armenia spurred unrest that has left about 200 people dead over the last two years. Azerbaijan last week renewed a railroad blockade of Armenia, which gets most of its supplies through Azerbaijan. With fuel and foo in Armenia running dangerously low and temperatures several degrees below freezing, ``The people are furious because the central authorities are not paying adequate attention to events,'' said Eduard Shakh-Nazaryan, an editor at the government-run Armenpress agency. ``This will lead to unpredictable consequences if it continues,'' he said in a telephone interview from Yerevan. ``I mean, military conflict between us if they continue like this.'' Azerbaijani unrest broke out earlier this month as well on the border with Iran, including in Lenkoran. Azerbaijanis who wanted to be united with their ethnic brethren across the frontier rampaged for several days over New Year's, tearing down border fences. Soviet-Iranian talks were held Saturday in Moscow and Baku during a visit by Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister Mahmoud Vaezi and Tale Massule, head of the Iranian Foreign Ministry's passports and visas department. Tass said the Iranian representatives agreed to consider Soviet proposals to facilitate cross-border contacts.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors, Police Dodge Errant Shots from Video Makers
DOC.TEXT: A bullet whizzed through a kitchen cabinet and put a 6-inch hole in the ceiling of a woman at home with her two young sons _ apparently because of a training video being filmed 1{ miles away, authorities said. Kim Robinson and her neighbors were pinned down for nearly two hours as automatic gunfire ripped through their rural community Thursday, hitting several mobile homes about an acre apart in Keysville Estates. Several squad cars and a police helicopter responded to residents' cries for help. As Hillsborough County sheriff's Deputy Ron Cain walked around the Robinson yard, several more rounds landed nearby and Cain thought he was under attack, Capt. Robert DeLuna said Friday. By the time the commotion subsided, police discovered neighbors and officers had been dodging stray bullets from two out-of-town businessmen who said they were making a law enforcement training video at a private gun range 1{ miles away. ``It was like being in a war,'' said Mrs. Robinson, whose children are 3 and 4. ``We didn't know where the bullets were coming from.'' The men making the video, Thomas G. Bailey and Steven P. Nelson, said they had been told there were no homes for at least two miles. They had an M-16 rifle, a 9mm Heckler and a Koch MP5 assault weapon, deputies said. ``We took all precautions. We had to rely on folks familiar with the area,'' Nelson said. ``It's unfortunate we were misled.'' The state attorney's office is reviewing the case, but prosecutors said no charges were filed immediately because no one was injured and the stray bullets were apparently unintentional. Bailey, who makes training films for a living, and Nelson, a chiropractor, said they were testing weapons and videotaping them for evaluation. The tapes are used for training special police units such as Special Weapons and Tactics teams. Darrell Vogel said his mobile home was hit twice. ``It put a hole clean through the double-wide _ big enough to put your little finger through. One put a hole right over my little boy's desk,'' Vogel said. ``If he had been doing homework, he'd be dead.''

DOC.HEAD: Money Stolen From Da Vinci House
DOC.TEXT: Thieves broke into the 15th-century home of Leonardo da Vinci and made off with money in the cashbox, authorities reported Saturday. The thieves broke a window and entered the house late Friday or early Saturday, police said. They took about 1.5 million lire, or $1,200, from the cashbox, the proceeds from sale of books about the artist, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. Da Vinci was born in the house near Florence in northern Italy in 1452. He died in France in 1519 after producing such works as the ``Last Supper'' and ``Mona Lisa.'' The house was opened to the public as a museum in 1986 after restoration.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Flock To Stores To Beat Price Hikes
DOC.TEXT: East Germans went on a frantic shopping spree Saturday after plans for limited price rises triggered widespread speculation about further price increases in their economically troubled nation. Also Saturday, East Germany's economics minister became the highest-ranking government official to urge transforming the state-controlled economy into a free-market system, something demanded by potential Western investors. The Communist-dominated government said price increases are needed to begin dismantling the costly and inefficient state subsidies for dozens of basic goods, including clothing and food. Late Friday, the government said prices would double or triple for children's clothing and related items Monday. That triggered a nationwide shopping rush during the four hours the stores were open Saturday, despite the government's promise to raise state child support payments in return. ``The increased state aid won't cover all of the difference in prices,'' said one man, his arms loaded with purchases at the Centrum department store in downtown East Berlin. The price increases are aimed mainly at making state-subsidized goods less attractive to foreigners, who can acquire East German marks cheaply on the black market and then buy items at a fraction of the price they would pay in the West. East Berlin leaders also have wiped out state subsidies for flowers, Christmas trees and other plants, while announcing plans to close ``several'' diplomatic missions abroad. Such measures are aimed at cutting a budget deficit of nearly $1.3 billion. East Germans braced for price increases for other essential goods, including groceries, after hearing reports on West German radio that such plans were in the works. The FDGB labor federation, which has been seeking greater independence after decades of government control, demanded negotiations over any further price hikes or reductions in state subsidies. ``We will use all of the labor union means at our disposal to have a say in this,'' the FDGB said in a statement. Economics Minister Christa Luft said East Germany should adopt a free-market economy as a way out of its economic woes. ``It must be an efficient free-market economy that proves itself to be internationally competitive,'' Mrs. Luft told leading West German industrialists, including Daimler-Benz chief Edzard Reuter. Such an economic system must also take into account social and environmental concerns, she said. A recent series of warning strikes has increased the pressure on Communist Premier Hans Modrow's shaky coalition government. Modrow, during a Cabinet meeting, cautioned about what he sees as the dangers of the growing number of politically motivated strikes, according to West Germany's ZDF television network. Modrow offered the Social Democratic Party the post of deputy environmental minister, marking the first time the growing opposition has been invited to have any direct role in the government. The official news agency ADN said Modrow had offered the job to Social Democratic leader Ibrahim Boehme, but there was no immediate word on whether he accepted. In a highly symbolic move on Saturday, Boehme's party approved a modification of its name to adopt the same title as West Germany's leftist Social Democrats, whose members include popular former Chancellor Willy Brandt. Several prominent West German Social Democrats attended the session and promised campaign support before East Germany's first free elections. East Germany's Social Democrats, who claim to have 32,000 members, are expected to be a major force after the May elections. A commentary in Neues Deutschland, the official Communist Party newspaper, suggested the Communists consider becoming an opposition force to regain their credibility. ``Maybe the (Communist Party) should march out of the government coalition and into opposition ranks, with clear eyes and an upright walk,'' the newspaper said. Opposition groups then could ``show what they can do.'' With a half-dozen major opposition groups running against the Communists during the elections, there is a good chance the Communists will be in a distinct minority anyway in less than four months.

DOC.HEAD: Officer's Sentencing Overshadows First Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The celebration of Martin Luther King's birthday may be muted in Miami this year because of the remembrance of three nights of rioting after the police shooting of an unarmed black motorcyclist a year ago Tuesday. A manslaughter verdict against Miami Police Officer William Lozano eased animosity slightly in Miami's inner-city black community. But the jury's verdict against the Colombian-born policeman angered Hispanics, and black leaders say little progress has occurred in the past year to substantially change problems that erupted into racial violence four times in the 1980s. They also worry about the possible reaction to Lozano's sentencing, set for later this month. All of the disturbances were triggered by the deaths of black men at the hands of police or the subsequent acquittal of those officers. ``We're riot-prone here by virtue of our legacy alone,'' said Marvin Dunn, a professor and community psychologist. ``I don't think that the circumstances that have taken us to the brink time and time and time again have significantly changed,'' said Dunn, who has written extensively about the 1980 riot. ``Miami today is just as likely to have a police-community confrontation erupt into violence as it was a year ago or even 10 years ago.'' City officials, not surprisingly, paint a more positive picture. ``Hopefully, we've outlived these things,'' said Mayor Xavier Suarez. ``I think there has been a coming together to some extent of government and the affected neighborhoods.'' The city was celebrating the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday last Jan. 16 when Lozano shot at a speeding motorcycle, killing the driver and sending his passenger to his death in the resulting crash in the poverty-stricken Overtown neighborhood. The deaths of Allan Blanchard and Clement Lloyd led to looting, sniping and firebombings that left one other man dead, 11 people injured, 372 arrested, 13 buildings burned and other buildings damaged. Barry Greff, who represents the Lloyd family in a $10 million wrongful death suit against Lozano and the city, believes the severity of the sentence to be issued Jan. 24 will dictate community reaction. ``Although the family certainly doesn't advocate it, my impression is the mood definitely shows the possibility of a community reaction, a negative community reaction,'' Greff said. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People went so far as to ask Gov. Bob Martinez to send in the National Guard to replace Miami police after a handful of officers on the 1,100-member force wore black bands on their badges or wrists to protest the conviction of a fellow officer. Lozano, 31, faces a sentence ranging from probation to 45 years in prison, with state guidelines recommending 12 to 17 years. Factors to be considered include on the one hand his high ratings by the police department before the shooting, but also ``his lack of remorse,'' prosecutor John Hogan said. Rabbi Solomon Schiff, chairman of the Dade County community relations board, said he expects a peaceful acceptance of the sentencing because of extensive media attention to the judicial process, including televising of the entire trial. Dunn is less certain because he sees poor police-community relations as the root of Miami's repetitious violence. ``The problem is overzealous, particularly young, inexperienced officers with a certain attitude toward black youths,'' he said. Poverty and alienation in Overtown also are factors, some black leaders say. The southern edge of the neighborhood, a black community since 1896, has seen a wealth of construction, including the $52 million Miami Arena and a $33 million high-rise complex that displaced 260 families. ``Some people believe there's master plan afoot to wipe out Overtown and put in high-rises,'' said the Rev. Willie Sims, a Baptist minister and the community relations board's crisis coordinator. ``They're renovating a black community that will no longer be a black community,'' said Democratic state Rep. Willie Logan of suburban Opa-locka. ``This isn't going to really benefit the people who are affected by the riots.'' Assistant City Manager Herbert Bailey, who is coordinating downtown redevelopment, resents that attitude as political posturing. ``When you get people who say we're not doing anything, you're talking to people who don't want to see what is new,'' he said. ``Overtown didn't get that way overnight, and you certainly are not going to cure it overnight.'' Bailey concedes there is not much private-sector interest in rehabilitation of Liberty City, another blighted neighborhood farther from downtown. Psychologist Dunn sees overall improvement in income and educational levels of Miami blacks, but believes conditions are worse for the poorest third. ``The folks who are most alienated and are most likely to cause trouble in the streets are folks who are not being touched by these economic improvements,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Cuts Off Euphrates Waters To Syria, Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Commando forces ...' with details from scene; INSERTS 1 graf after 16th graf, `Turks maintain ...' with flow figures.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal cut the flow of the Euphrates River with the push of a button Saturday, diverting its waters to a reservoir and raising fears of tension with Turkey's arid downstream neighbors. ``Starting with the name of Allah all-forgiving and for the benefit of our people,'' Ozal said as he pushed the button at the end of a cord extending from a channel at the giant Ataturk dam. During the one-month stoppage, Syria and Iraq will get 75 percent less water from the tributaries of the Euphrates, the 1,460-mile-long river that has been the lifeblood throughout history for the area, once ancient Mesopotamia. The river already slows to become a sluggish stream before joining the Tigris at the Shatt-al-Arab waterway in Iraq and emptying into the Persian Gulf. Commando forces stood guard on heights in the reservoir area while 10,000 people watched the ceremony at the dam site about 60 miles north of the Syrian border. White, blue and pink clouds mushroomed from smoke bombs exploded on the opposite side of the river during the ceremony, as water gushed down the middle of the dam's three derivation channels. Once the Southeast Anatolia project of 15 dams and 18 hydroelectric power plants is completed, Turkey will have a stranglehold on both the Euphrates and Tigris rivers. But in a speech, Ozal promised Syria and Iraq that ``Turkey would never use the water of Euphrates as a threat.'' ``This was a technical necessity but we have taken all possible care not to cause any damage to our neighbors,'' Ozal said. Ozal proposed that Turkey's neighbors invest together in infrastructure projects as he said European countries had done. He did not give details. Turkey views the dam and a chain of others to be built in the future as crucial for the economic development of its backward southeastern region, providing much-needed electricity and water for crop irrigation. It says the monthlong stoppage of water will allow engineers to fill a reservoir to a height of 396 feet and build a concrete plug for a diversion channel as part of the construction project. Syria is more dependent than Iraq on the river, because Iraq also has the Tigris running through its territory. But being upstream, Syria could keep more of the Euphrates waters in its own reservoirs and allow a trickle to Iraq. Syria has made no public statement on the water cut. Iraq said it would send a senior envoy to Ankara on Sunday to discuss problems arising from the reduction in the Euphrates flow. Iraq sent its deputy foreign minister, Nizar Hamdoun, to Turkey last month to ask for a cut in the Euphrates flow of two weeks instead of the planned one month. Turkey said two weeks was not enough time. Hamdoun told reporters that the cutoff would not provoke a full-blown crisis in Iraqi agriculture, but it would still cause damage in some areas. Turkish officials have taken an Iraqi delegation to the dam construction site to explain the situation, Foreign Ministry officials said. Turks maintain that since November they have released extra water to Syria and Iraq, to allow them to store water in their reservoirs for use during the shortfall. A state waterworks official at the dam site said that since November, Turkey had released 4.42 billion cubic yards of water downstream, and 1.1 billion cubic yards of it had been allowed into Iraq by Syria. Ozal said the construction of the massive dam by Turkish workers and engineers showed ``what we are capable of doing.'' There has been talk in newspapers and diplomatic circles of possible future strains among the countries of the mostly arid region since Ozal said last summer in an off-the-cuff remark that Turkey could block the Euphrates River waters to punish Syria for providing support to Kurdish guerrillas waging war for independence in southeast Turkey. When completed in 2006, the Southeast Anatolia project will produce 22 billion kwh of electricity annually and irrigate an area of 4 million acres. The additional energy should double the yield of many crops in Turkey and produce $5 billion worth of surplus in the country, which is agriculturally self-sufficient, officials say. The first of the Ataturk dam's eight electricity-generating units is scheduled to go into operation May 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Bans New Independent Serbian Group
DOC.TEXT: Communist authorities Saturday banned a new Serbian independent political group and denounced its program as nationalist, the Tanjug news agency reported. The name of the group is Society for the Preservation of Historical Truth, the Serbian Language, The Cyrillic (alphabet) and for the Defense of Kosovo. Its chairman, Mirko Jovic, was briefly detained Friday in Nova Pazova, 18 miles northwest of Belgrade, and its leaders were harassed by police, the group's sources said. Authorities said they banned the society because it ``abused the constitutionally guaranteed freedom of association ... and fomented Yugoslav nationalist hatred and intolerance and (called for the) toppling of the foundations of the socialist self-managed, democratic system.'' Group representatives said a week ago they were planning to formally constitute themselves as a Party of Serbian National Renewal on Jan. 27. Vuk Draskovic, a member of the newly formed party's leadership and prominent Serbian writer, said Friday he and Jovic had received threats after they announced their plans to form a political party. Yugoslav state-run media have launched a campaign against the group, accusing it of advocating nationalism and bloodshed with other Yugoslav nationalities, especially with the Croats. Draskovic denied that his party is nationalist and said the campaign represents ``an organized hysteria by Serbian Communists and their leadership.'' Even though Yugoslavia has not formally adopted a law allowing independent political groups and parties to form, numerous such groups have mushroomed in the past few months. Communist authorities claim some of the new parties have clear nationalist programs leading to open clashes between rival Yugoslav republics.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Welcomes Soviet Moslem Visitors
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Moslems who have demonstrated violently for the right to travel freely to Iran received good news Saturday from the Iranian foreign minister, who said they are welcome to visit his country. The minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, made the announcent in Tabriz, the capital of Iran's East Azerbaijan province, where he helped complete travel arrangements for Soviet Moslems, the official Iranian news agency said. The news report, which was monitored in Nicosia, did not say when the first Soviet visitors were expected in Iran. The province borders Soviet Azerbaijan, which was once part of Iran. Earlier this month, Soviet Azerbaijanis who want to be united with their Iranian brethren rampaged for several days, tearing down border fences. Soviet-Iranian talks were held Saturday in Moscow and Baku, the capital of Soviet Azerbaijan, during a visit by Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister Mahmoud Vaezi and Tale Massule, head of Iran's passports and visas department. The Soviet news agency Tass said the Iranian officials agreed to consider Soviet proposals to facilitate cross-border contacts and to receive a Soviet delegation in Tehran later this month, possibly to sign travel agreements. The Soviet and Iranian Azerbaijani republics share a common language, culture and religion. They are demanding an open border and freedom to trade and cross the frontier. Following the border unrest, the Soviet Foreign Ministry said restrictions on travel to Iran would be eased. Azerbaijan was divided in 1828. In 1941, the Red Army invaded northern Iran and set up a short-lived puppet republic after World War II. But the Soviets pulled out in 1946 because of international pressure. For the last two years, Soviet Azerbaijan also has been involved in a violent dispute with the neighboring Soviet republic of Armenia over an enclave in Azerbaijan they both claim the right to govern.

DOC.HEAD: Couple With Taste for High Living Sentenced in Fraud Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A high-living Northern Virginia couple who lured consumers to visit time-share resorts with false promises of expensive prizes was sentenced to prison for bankruptcy fraud and money laundering. U.S. District Judge Claude Hilton on Friday sentenced David A. DeFusco, 34, of Great Falls to five years in prison and his wife, Annette, 28, to 35 months. The DeFuscos hid large sums of money by laundering funds through fake corporations rather than tone down their gourmet lifestyle and pay off $2.5 million in debts, U.S. Attorney Henry Hudson said. Hudson said the couple fled Northern Virginia in March 1989, leaving behind nearly 100 creditors in the Washington area as well as a stack of lawsuits and consumer fraud complaints. Their flight came shortly before bankruptcy officials acted to seize their assets. They later were discovered in California, living in a haven for millionaires outside San Diego and operating a business similar to one that brought on a barrage of consumer complaints here. Hudson said the DeFuscos received up to $100 each for potential customers they lured to visit time-share condominium resorts with promises of nonexistent gifts, such as BMW cars and gold bullion. David DeFusco in October pleaded guilty in Beaumont, Texas, to mail fraud and conspiracy charges and is awaiting sentencing there. Under a court agreement, he will spend an additional 70 months to 87 months in jail for organizing what prosecutors said was a $720 billion fraud scheme. Prosecutors arrived at that figure by multiplying the average $34,000 prize offering times the 24 million pieces of mail delivered during the scheme. A business he operated in Washington state also has been the target of an investigation in recent years. Before sentencing, DeFusco said his success as measured by opulent jewelry and luxury cars was the product of ``what we still believe were legitimate business practices.'' Prosecutors rejected that notion. ``These people lived a lavish lifestyle at the expense of many consumers and many other creditors,'' Hudson said. In the Virginia case, the DeFuscos pleaded guilty on Oct. 20. Prosecutors said the couple used phantom corporations and aliases to hide money frozen in bankruptcy proceedings from creditors who claimed unpaid debts of $2.5 million from the DeFuscos and their companies. After a bankruptcy trustee ordered liquidation of their assets last spring, the couple sold two cars and moved $250,000 worth of personal possessions to California and opened their new business under assumed names, authorities said. FBI agents who raided their Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., home on July 5 found jewelry, furs, a Persian Rug worth $15,000 and art work valued at more than $10,000. DeFusco admitted diverting $1 million worth of corporate and personal assets that had been frozen by a bankruptcy trustee. Mrs. DeFusco admitted diverting $290,000 worth of assets as part of the scheme with her husband.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News ^LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actors Dennis Quaid and John Goodman will reign over two of the most popular Mardi Gras parades next month. Goodman, who plays Roseanne Barr's husband on the ABC show ``Roseanne,'' will be grand marshal of the Krewe of Endymion on Feb. 24. Quaid, who burned up the keyboards as Jerry Lee Lewis in the film ``Great Balls of Fire,'' will be Bacchus the next day, carnival officials said Friday. Mardi Gras is Feb. 27. Both have several ties to Louisiana. The two starred in the 1987 police thriller ``The Big Easy,'' set in New Orleans, and ``Everybody's All-American,'' a 1988 film shot in Baton Rouge. Goodman was married in New Orleans on Oct. 27 to Bogalusa native Annabeth Hartzog, a former student at the University of New Orleans. ``I'm just nuts about New Orleans,'' Goodman said Friday. ``It's going to be a good time for everyone. You know, man, anything goes.''

Oh, mercy! A grinning Bob Dylan kicked off an international tour at a New Haven nightclub with old standards and cuts from his latest album. ``I never saw him smile before,'' said Joel Evans after watching Dylan's first set Friday night at Toad's Place to promote his critically acclaimed album, ``Oh Mercy.'' Dylan, 48, known for an extremely aloof stage presence, surprised the crowd with broad grins and extended eye contact. Backed by a three-piece band, he played such classics as ``Rainy Day Women Nos. 12 and 35'' and ``One More Cup of Coffee'' as well as new material. The New Haven show was one of only three Dylan will play in the United States before dates in Brazil and Europe. The other U.S. shows are in State College, Pa., and Princeton, N.J.
DOC.HEAD: A longer version moved on some sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Former Boston Celtics star Dave Cowens found that becoming a Republican may have fouled up his chances of running for secretary of state. Cowens, 41, director of the New England Sports Museum and a Democrat until last month, put the word out to Republican Party leaders Friday that he would run for office. But the former center and player-coach was unaware of a state law that says a candidate for statewide office in one party cannot have been enrolled in another political party during the year prior to the filing deadline. Cowens switched his registration Dec. 8. The filing deadline for secretary of state is June 5. ``He got caught traveling,'' said Paul McCarthy, the only Republican candidate for secretary of state to have filed thus far. Cowens' only option may be to run as a write-in candidate, something he said he would consider. Some Republicans said Cowens could become their candidate if McCarthy stepped aside and no other Republican ran. But McCarthy said, ``I'm committed to the race, no matter how tall my opponent is. I'll fight him into the state convention March 10, and maybe I'll slam-dunk him.'' Responded Cowens: ``A lot of people have tried.''

Grand Ole Opry star Jeanne Pruitt says her farm will be disturbed by a planned interstate highway. ``It will come right through the collard green patch,'' she said. Pruitt, best known for her hit song ``Satin Sheets,'' learned Friday that Interstate 840 will cross her 160-acre farm south of Nashville, isolating 40 to 60 acres of the property. ``I'm sorry that's where it has to come, but if it's got to go somewhere, it's got to go,'' she said, adding that she might sell the land for a more secluded location. The 53-mile stretch of interstate is designed to ease Nashville traffic by offering a southern bypass off Interstate 40. Construction should be completed by the end of the decade.

Comedian David Letterman didn't gain a new fan by having 78-year-old Gabriel Raba as a guest on his late-night talk show. ``He's a silly guy,'' said the New Underwood rancher, who appeared on NBC-TV's ``Late Night With David Letterman'' Tuesday to discuss a 13-month calendar he created and had copyrighted. ``He never clearly showed the calendar. He had it in his hand and was flipping it around.'' Raba said he was more amused by the pre-show preparations than Letterman's on-the-air wisecracks. ``A girl even danced with me to keep me from getting nervous,'' he said. ``And they put makeup powder on me, just like a lady.'' Raba's idea would bring order to the current calendar, which has months with 28, 29, 30 or 31 days. His calendar would have 13 months, each with 28 days for a total of 364. He's soliciting suggestions for what to call the 13th month. To keep the revised calendar in sync with the 365-day year, Raba would have a 48-hour New Year's Day and a 48-hour Leap Year day. ``You should have heard them clap and whoop and holler when I mentioned the 48-hour New Year's and Leap Year,'' Raba said of the New York studio audience.

DOC.HEAD: Rampaging Elephants Destroy Houses, Crops
DOC.TEXT: Wild elephants rampaged through a northern village, damaging vegetable fields and about a dozen houses, the state news agency said Saturday. No one was injured in the Friday night episode, but many villagers panicked and fled their homes, said the news agency Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha. At least 10 elephants trampled mud-and-straw houses and winter vegetable crops in Netrokona village, 80 miles north of Dhaka, the report said. About 1,000 elephants roam the area's Garo foothills and the southeastern Chittagong hills. At least 35 people were killed by rampaging elephants in 1987. No deaths were reported in 1988, the latest year for which figures are available.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Urges Junking of Minuteman 2 Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Air Force officials are calling for retirement of all 450 of the nation's Minuteman 2 intercontinental ballistic missiles in a move to save $400 million a year, according to a published report. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has received the green light to discuss the proposal with congressional leaders this week before any final decision, The Washington Post reported in Saturday's editions. An Air Force spokesman, Col. Patrick Maloney, said Saturday when asked about the plan that the service does not discuss budget proposals until the budget becomes final. The Post quoted officials as cautioning that President Bush might veto the idea before unveiling his fiscal 1991 budget to Congress on Jan. 29. In another cost-cutting move, Cheney on Friday froze civilian hirings at the Defense Department, saying it was made possible by eased world tensions. Department officials, however, said they did not know how much the work force will be reduced by the freeze. The freeze lasts until Sept. 30 and applies to all Defense Department civilians worldwide, including part-time and temporary employees. The department currently employs 927,000 civilians full-time and another 123,000 on a temporary or part-time basis. Up to 80,000 workers retire or otherwise leave that work force each year, the Pentagon said. The Minuteman 2 carries a single warhead with an explosive force estimated at 1.2 megatons, or the equivalent of 1.2 million tons of TNT. The missiles are based at Malmstrom Air Force Base, Mont.; Ellsworth Air Force Base, S.D., and Whiteman Air Force Base, Mo., The Minuteman 2 is relatively inaccurate compared with later missiles. Published estimates say half the missiles launched would land within 1,200 feet to 2,000 feet of the point of aim. Similar estimates for the 550 deployed Minuteman 3 missiles, which carry three smaller warheads, are from 600 feet to 700 feet. Besides the Minuteman, the nation's land-based missiles include 50 MX Peacekeeper missiles with 10 warheads each. Counting other missiles and bombs, the Minuteman 2 force represents about 3.5 percent of the nation's strategic nuclear warheads. The Bush administration has proposed building a new Midgetman single-warhead missile that could be moved about on giant trucks. Midgetman proponents say the mobile missiles would be much more difficult to hit than known, fixed positions such as current Minuteman silos. Because they are old and inaccurate, the Minuteman 2 missiles have been candidates for retirement for some time. The administration told Congress last summer that a likely strategic nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union would mean significant reductions in missiles on both sides.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Says He No Longer Objects to Rival Soviet Political Parties
LaserPhotos XVIL1,3,4; LaserColor XVIL5
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Saturday he no longer objects to the legalization of multiple political parties in the Soviet Union, where his Communist Party has held a monopoly on power for 72 years. ``I see no tragedy in a multiparty system if _ and I can tell you this straightforwardly _ it arises as a result of a normal historical process and answers the needs of society,'' Gorbachev told Lithuania's Communist Party. It was a surprising reversal by Gorbachev, who had remained opposed to the idea of rival political parties, even as pro-democracy movements forced an end to one-party Communist rule elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Soviet police routinely have broken up demonstrations by the Democratic Union _ until recently the only Soviet organization trying to establish itself as an opposition party. A reason for Gorbachev's turnaround could be that multiparty systems already exist in Lithuania and Latvia. The party ideology chief in the third Baltic republic, Estonia, has said the same is inevitable there. Lithuania was the first to legalize other political parties, and Lithuanian Communists will face them in February elections to the Lithuanian parliament. Gorbachev came to the Baltic republic in an effort to persuade the Lithuanian Communist Party to reverse its decision last month to break with the central Communist Party. The three-day visit ended with the Lithuanians refusing to budge. The president concluded Saturday's party meeting with the statement, ``We have laid a good foundation for continuing the dialogue.'' He then returned to Moscow. Gorbachev pleaded for unity in both the party and the Soviet Union but faced pro-independence demonstrators at every stop and clearly had no significant effect on public opinion. Lithuanians strongly support independence for the republic, which was forcibly annexed in 1940 while occupied by the Red Army. The Communist Party ideology chief, Vadim A. Medvedev, told a news conference after the meeting that elaboration on Gorbachev's statement on multiple parties will be contained in an article written by Gorbachev and due to appear in the Soviet press, possibly as early as Sunday. Communists have held exclusive power in the Soviet Union since a few months after the 1917 Russian Revolution. A number of parties operated in the last years of the czar's reign but had little power, and a number competed for control during the turbulent year of revolution itself. Gorbachev's statement was the first indication the Soviet Union might catch up with the wave of political reform that has been sweeping Eastern Europe in recent months. Poland, East Germany, Hungary and Romania have all eliminated the Communists' guaranteed hold on political power and either formed multiparty systems or scheduled free elections. Gorbachev has made clear his willingness to end the Communists' legal guarantee on political power, codified in the Soviet Constitution, but until now, he expressed scorn for a multiparty system. On Friday, he told an audience in Siauliai, Lithuania: ``Haven't you and I seen and known during our long life that even with 10 or 20 parties, the most cruel dictatorships formed and flourished? ``And will a multiparty system save society? No, it is the regime that determines who lives how and who breathes how.'' Gorbachev's reversal was his second surprising announcement on the Lithuanian tour. On Thursday, he said a law was being drafted to set up a mechanism for republics to secede from the Soviet Union. He promised that the Lithuanian people would be allowed to choose their own fate and predicted they would remain in the union once they realize the financial costs and human dislocation that secession would cause. In a long speech to the Lithuanian Communists, Gorbachev said separatists were in too much of a hurry. ``Think a thousand times before embarking on an independent drift without a compass, without a map, a fuel reserve or a competent crew,'' he said. In a lecturing tone, Gorbachev also warned: ``There is no absolute freedom, and you won't find absolute independence anywhere... Everything in the world is interrelated.'' Lithuanian Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas said in his speech that events forced his party to split with the national Communist Party. ``Comprehensive analysis of the political situation throughout the republic convinced us that only an independent Communist Party could hold the trust of the residents of Lithuania, and only on that basis could it remain a serious political force,'' he said. In the end, Gorbachev invited the breakaway Lithuanians to the next national party congress in October, implying the meeting might adopt enough reforms to bring them back into the fold. The invitation might be to Gorbachev's advantage, since the Lithuanians are likely to back him against conservative opponents in the congress.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Winning $10 million in sweepstakes money wasn't enough for Bob Castleberry. Now he's out to be mayor of this town of 50,000. ``I had thought about it for years,'' Castleberry said Friday. ``I grew up watching my father giving everything to the community. Now I just want to do what I can.'' Castleberry, 60, announced Thursday that he is entering the race for mayor of Denton, a town of 50,000. His father served on the City Council from 1929-30 and then again in the early 1950s. Castleberry attracted attention last March after winning $10 million in the Publishers Clearing House Sweepstakes. He retired from his sales job at Moore Business Forms in Denton this month. ``I knew I couldn't do both jobs justice,'' he said. ``One job would have suffered.'' Two-term incumbent Mayor Ray Stephens has not yet announced his intentions for the campaign. The election for the non-paying job is May 5. Castleberry said as a result of his appearances in commercials for the magazine subscription service, he's gaining valuable exposure with potential voters. He also gets lots of phone calls and letters from women with marriage in mind, but he doesn't pay much attention to them. The money is coming in annual payments. He got $500,000 last year and will get $250,000 this year and each year for the next 27. In the final year, when he is 90, he will get a lump sum payment of about $2 million. ``I plan to live to be at least 100,'' he said. Castleberry has used the money to set up scholarships at Texas A&M University, the University of North Texas and Texas Woman's University and to buy a $32,000 automobile. He wants to buy a small horse ranch, but hasn't found what he wants so far.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Sworn In As Nation's First Elected Black Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 12th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos RM3, RM9, LaserColor upcoming
DOC.TEXT: L. Douglas Wilder became the nation's first elected black governor Saturday and said his inauguration at the spot where the Confederacy collapsed almost 125 years ago shows ``oppression can be lifted.'' ``We mark today not the victory of party or the accomplishments of an individual, but the triumph of an idea,'' Wilder said in his inaugural address outside the Virginia Capitol, which was capital of the Confederacy in the Civil War. ``The idea that all men are created equally.'' Wilder, a lawyer and Democratic former legislator and lieutenant governor who turns 59 Wednesday, took the oath of office from retired U.S. Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., a Richmond native who headed the city's school board during the period of resistance to school integration. Wilder, who is divorced, was flanked by his two daughters and son as he took the oath. A largely black crowd estimated by police at more than 35,000 was more than double attendance at the 1985 inauguration. Wilder said his inauguration represents a triumph for ideals expressed in the Declaration of Independence by Thomas Jefferson, a Virginia governor during the Revolutionary War. ``If these words about freedom are to be heard at all today, I hope they will be heard by the young people of this commonwealth,' Wilder said. ``I want them to know that oppression can be lifted, that discrimination can be eliminated, that poverty need not be binding, that disability can be overcome,'' he said. ``And the offer of opportunity in a free society carries with it the responsibility of hard work, the rejection of drugs and other false highs, and a willingness to work with others whatever their color or national origin,'' he continued. Cheers interrupted Wilder's 15-minute address five times, once when he proclaimed ``freedom is meaningless when a woman's right to choose is regulated outside the dictates of her own faith and conscience.'' Wilder's support of abortion rights was a prominent issue in his fiercely fought campaign against Republican J. Marshall Coleman, who opposes abortion. A recount showed that Coleman lost by 6,741 votes, or less than half a percent, in the closest race for governor in the state's history. Wilder became the state's 66th governor and the first black to be elected governor in any state. Black Lt. Gov. P.B.S. Pinchback served as Louisiana governor for 43 days in late 1872 and early 1873 after the elected governor was impeached. Music for the inaugural ceremony included ``God Bless America'' and ``America the Beautiful.'' But not a note was heard of the state's official song, ``Carry Me Back to Old Virginia.'' As a freshman state senator in 1970, Wilder sought to have the song abolished because its lyrics contain the word ``darkies.'' The inauguration was preceded by a prayer service and the ceremonial presentation of the keys to the Executive Mansion by outgoing Democratic Gov. Gerald L. Baliles. Jesse Jackson and former tennis star Arthur Ashe, a Richmond native, attended the prayer service. Wilder hadn't let Jackson campaign on his behalf, but Wilder's press secretary, Laura Dillard, said Jackson was invited to the inauguration because ``it's appropriate. He's a leading national figure in Democratic circles.'' Jackson described the inauguration as a historic moment. ``To go from the hull of a slave ship to governor is a great American story,'' he said. ``It's a great world story.'' Wilder said an economic slowdown would challenge his administration ``but progress will be possible.'' ``Resources employed in the past for the finer things in life can be _ and will have to be _ deployed for the more serious of our needs. For we know that freedom is but a word for the man or woman who needs and cannot find a job.'' Wilder said he will tell the state legislature on Monday his ideas for handling the state's projected $900 million revenue shortfall over the next two years. The weekend, however, was devoted to celebrating his inauguration with a parade, public reception and inaugural ball. About 12,500 tickets costing $50 or more were sold for the ball at the Richmond Coliseum. A protest sign at the inauguration, referring to the largely poor neighborhood in Richmond where Wilder grew up, read: ``Is there a ball for Church Hill?'' ``The eyes of the nation are on Virginia,'' said Mildred Swann, a Hampton social services worker in her 40s. During her four-hour wait for the ceremony to begin, she recalled how she evaded Klan gunfire as she tried to get fellow blacks in Mississippi to register to vote in the early 1960s. ``For me to see something like this in my lifetime _ there's some hope for the world,'' she said. When Wilder was introduced, she bowed her head and cried.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Thousands of Palestinians Leaving Territories
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians are migrating from the Israeli-occupied territories in increasing numbers, with about 24,000 leaving the rebellion-wracked lands last year alone to live in Jordan, an official said Saturday. Mohammed Al-Edwan, head of the Interior Ministry's department of inspection and control, said ministry figures show that more than 45,600 Palestinians have left the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to live in Jordan since 1983. He said the figures are ``increasing day after day and month after month.'' More than half of the 45,600 who have left since 1983 left in the past two years, since the beginning of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. There are about 1.7 million Palestinians now living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Hardships have greatly increased since the uprising began. Ministry figures show that about 22,000 Palestinians migrated from the territories in the first 11 months of 1989, Edwan said. He estimated that about 2,000 more left in December. Edwan said those figures exclude students studying abroad and those who left for pressing personal reasons like illness. Travel to the West Bank was unrestricted until 1967, when Israel captured the territory from Jordan in the Middle East war. Many West Bankers have close family and business ties to Jordan. About half of Jordan's 3 million people come from Palestinian families who fled or were driven from their homes during wars with Israel. Interior Minister Salem Masadeh said he was not familiar with the figures, but that if they were true, ``it would be the cause of much sorrow.'' In a related development, the Parliament confirmed Saturday an earlier government decision abolishing the Ministry of Occupied Territories, with only two votes against the move. The government dismantled the ministry to put into effect King Hussein's 1988 decision renouncing claims to the West Bank in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The PLO has declared an independent state of Palestine, challenging Israeli occupation. The PLO's equivalent of a foreign minister, Farouk Kadoumi, ended a four-day visit to Jordan on Saturday and lashed out at Israeli Cabinet minister Ariel Sharon for describing Jordan as a substitute homeland for Palestinians. ``Sharon is a terrorist, and his statement was condemned by the different political circles, including those friendly to Israel,'' Kadoumi said in a departure statement carried by Jordan's official Petra news agency. The right-wing Israeli official suggested Thursday that Jordan should open its borders with Israel, despite the technical state of war between them. ``Jews would be able to travel to Jordan...and the Jordanians will be able to visit Tel Aviv,'' he told Israel television. On Friday, he told Israel radio that such a move would help the peace process, adding: ``I repeat, Jordan is a Palestinian state.'' Sharon and some other Israeli hard-liners favor permanent Israeli rule over the West Bank and Gaza.

Guillermo Alfredo Benavides Moreno is the highest-ranking military officer to be accused of a human rights abuse crime in the 10-year-old civil war. ``We want to make one thing very clear: that this is only one phase of the investigation, which has been carried out so that the truth may be known. DOC.HEAD: President Reverses Communist Ban, Announces National Referendum
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 22 grafs to UPDATE with president announcing referendum on Communist Party ban. Pickup 14th pvs, ``They refused...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BUC5,BCCH29,BUCH50
DOC.TEXT: President Ion Iliescu on Saturday reversed a decision to ban the Communist Party, calling it a ``hasty decision,'' and instead said the issue will be decided in a national referendum. Iliescu responded to widespread protests Friday by announcing that the Communist Party, the sole ruler of Romania from 1948 until last month, had been outlawed. In a nationwide television and radio broadcast, Iliescu said the governing National Salvation Front had been criticized for the action, and he said the people will decide the fate of the Communists in a Jan. 28 referendum. ``It was a hasty decision, contrary to the democratic spirit,'' Iliescu said of Friday's announcement. Iliescu complained that popular pressures had even led some Front members to consider resigning. ``Then we realized that in this way, we would leave an open road to anarchy and chaos in the country. which would be a genuine national disaster,'' said Iliescu, who took office after the popular revolution that ousted Ceausescu. ``We need the massive support of the whole country.'' ``The Communist Party self-destructed or was removed from political life on Dec. 22,'' he added, referring to the day dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown. ``The Front is against any leading role of any party. We are in a dramatic moment because we inherited an extremely difficult decision from the dictatorship. We need patience, wisdom and unity,'' he said. The Jan. 28 referendum also will include the question of whether to reinstitute the death penalty, which was abolished by the revolutionary leadership after the executions of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. There have been nationwide calls to bring back the death penalty by those who feel life imprisonment is too lenient a punishment for crimes committed by Ceausescu cronies as well as by members of the Securitate, Ceausescu's dreaded special police. Police said 11 Securitate members will stand trial Monday in Timisoara, the birthplace of the revolution, where street protests of official foot-dragging led the army to assume control Friday night. The army controlled the city, the birthplace of Romania's revolution, on Saturday after local leaders were forced to resign amid street protests demanding the ouster of Communists from the revolutionary government. The army takeover apparently was an administrative measure and did not mean the region was under martial law. The army's support was crucial to Ceausescu's overthrow. Shooting continued until Friday in Timisoara and the city of Arad near the Hungarian border, between army units and members of Ceausescu's Securitate, the Yugoslav state news agency Tanjug reported. Thousands of people took to the streets on Friday in Bucharest, Timisoara and Brasov to demand reinstatement of the death penalty for Securitate members and to protest the participation of Communists in the interim government. No demonstrations were reported in Romania on Saturday. Lorin Fortuna, the leader of Timisoara's local National Salvation Front council, resigned after demonstrators complained the council was doing nothing about Securitate forces being held, according to a police official who identified himself only as Capt. Streza. The Securitate defendants to be tried in public on Monday in response to the popular pressure include a general, whom Streza did not name. The army took power to guarantee law and order and uninterrupted municipal services until elections planned by Jan. 19, Streza said in a telephone interview, quoting Maj. Gen. Gheorghe Popescu, commander of the armed forces in Timis county. The county's chief city is Timisoara. A new administrative council will be elected by representatives of factories and other organizations and institutions within the region, according to a Tanjug report. All leading members of Romania's Communist Party are under arrest for investigation of their role in the regime run with an iron hand by Ceausescu, who was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed Christmas Day. The Ceausescus' three-hour trial at an undisclosed location 60 miles from Bucharest was described Saturday in the newspaper Libertatea, which carried an interview with Niki Tedorescu, whom it identified as their attorney. ``They refused any cooperation with us. They did not understand what we said,'' Tedorescu recalled. ``Ceausescu kept repeating that he did not recognize the tribunal.'' ``They denied they had any property, or any luxury property,'' said Tedorescu, who was interviewed at a military hospital where he was recovering from a bullet wound received in the fighting in Bucharest. After his overthrow, Romanian media reported the feudal splendor in which the Ceausescu family lived while their countrymen did without the most basic commodities. ``I didn't expect them to be so uneducated,'' Tedorescu said. ``Both of them, but especially her (Mrs. Ceausescu), were disobeying all the laws of grammar.'' Mrs. Ceausescu was touted by the regime as a key intellectual with major scientific achievements. Officially, she held a doctorate in chemistry. ``I was surprised they looked so well, even in the state they were in, trembling with fear. I thought that in spite of their age, they looked better than me, and I am much younger.'' Asked his last words to Ceausescu after the death sentence was passed, Tedorescu answered: ``According to the law, I asked him if he objected to the (death) sentence, and he indicated no. He was convinced in my opinion that he would not be executed.'' The Ceausescus were executed shortly after the trial.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Opening to Multiparty System: Broader Democracy or Breakdown?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's dropping of his staunch opposition to one-party Communist rule is a logical extension of his drive to permit broader expression of views and competitive elections for public office. But while Gorbachev's statement Saturday that he can ``see no tragedy in a multiparty system'' constitutes a recognition of existing political reality in some Soviet republics, it could spawn fractious, ethnic-oriented parties with little concern for the union. And, of course, it may eventually doom the 70-year-old Communist political apparatus that operates parallel to _ and wields more power than _ the government at all levels of Soviet society. The Kremlin's Eastern European allies have challenged their own Communist leaders in recent months, and those countries have moved far away from the monopolies that used to be held by the ruling political cliques. But in the Soviet Union, where the first democratic reforms began nearly five years ago, Gorbachev and the top leadership have steadfastly refused to relinquish the party's position as the only legally recognized political entity. Members of the Democratic Union, a tiny but outspoken group that brazenly calls itself an opposition party, have been routinely subjected to detention, arrest and even beatings by authorities, who have learned to tolerate many other forms of dissent. Since the Communists obliterated their political opposition in the first years after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, the ruling party has controlled not just the political sphere but all walks of life. Party membership was a prerequisite to professional advancement. Party officials determined what children were taught, what people could read and where they could work. The party, now 20 million strong, also served as a strong unifying force, bringing together and exercising power over the more than 100 nationalities and ethnic groups that make up the vast Soviet Union. Opponents of multiparty rule have suggested that if the Communist monopoly were broken, the union would disintegrate into dozens of parochial parties playing for the support of the narrow ethnic groups that concentrate in each republic and region. The opposing interests of those groups are at the heart of much of the unrest that has shaken the country for two years. As recently as Friday, only a day before conceding he would be willing to tolerate other political parties, Gorbachev was warning of the hazards of such a system, and arguing that the Communist Party could serve as a forum for multiple views. ``Haven't you and I seen and known during our long life that even with 10 or 20 parties the most cruel dictatorships formed and flourished?'' he asked during a visit to a collective farm in independence-minded Lithuania. ``And will a multiparty system save society? No, it is the regime that determines who lives how and who breathes how.'' ``Just look,'' he added, ``with only one Communist Party of the Soviet Union how many opinions we have! And how much plurality, democracy under a one-party system. How many public movements ... I welcome it.'' But de facto, Lithuania already has at least two political parties vying for official recognition. One, referred to as the independent Communist Party of Lithuania, is the majority party in the republic that voted to break with Moscow and pursue its own course, prompting the visit of Gorbachev and other party leaders in an unsuccessful attempt to mend the break. The other, calling itself the Communist Party of Lithuania (Platform CPSU), is made up of party stalwarts still loyal to Moscow who left the republic's party and set up their own contingent that continues to follow the platform of the Soviet Communist Party. In other republics, local popular front groups have fielded candidates for legislative posts in opposition to Communists, and in Latvia on Saturday, about 200 environmental activists announced the formation of a Greens party with goals similar to those of the Greens in Western Europe. In Estonia, Social Democrats from several European countries held an international conference sponsored by the Social Democratic political organization in that Baltic republic. Gorbachev, who last May was elected to a five-year term as president but whose real power still resides in his leadership of the party _ which has no certain tenure _ refused during the Congress of People's Deputies session last month to permit the body to consider revoking the party's constitutional monopoly on power. And he has been quick to put down the Congress' fledgling and loosely knit opposition, which calls itself the Inter-regional Group. But the Kremlin chief is by his own account a political realist, and his comments Saturday reflected more an acknowledgement of the political forces at work than an endorsement of the concept. ``I see no tragedy in a multiparty system _ and I can tell you this straightforwardly _ if it arises as a result of a normal historical process and answers the needs of society,'' he said. ``We shouldn't be afraid of a multiparty system the way the devil fears incense. ``Still, a multiparty system is no panacea. What we really need is glasnost and democratization and genuine participation of the people.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Michael Putzel is The Associated Press' chief of bureau in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Rally In Ambulance Worker Pay Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of ambulance workers and their backers rallied with banners and a brass band Saturday to support pay demands of the emergency crews in an 18-week-old dispute with the government. London ambulance workers, who earn $16,906 a year after five years at work, began job actions more than four months ago. They were suspended on Nov. 8 and replaced by police and military staff when they decided not to respond to non-emergency calls. Although management stopped putting emergency calls through to the ambulance workers, in many cases the depots remained staffed and unpaid crews responded to such calls from hospitals or fire stations. The pay dispute spread through the country, and on Thursday 60 workers in West Sussex county, south of London, went on unofficial strike. The death of a man in that district Saturday received wide news coverage when it was announced it had taken 31 minutes for a fully equipped ambulance to reach him. An estimated 15,000 ambulance crew members and their families marched Saturday along Whitehall and into Trafalgar Square to cheers and applause from crowds estimated at 15,000 or more. The march, which included banners, a brass band and young children, lent a carnival atmosphere to the government center of the capital. A police inspector said it was one of the biggest rallies held in London for many years. ``We could not fit everyone into the square, so people are packed onto surrounding pavements,'' he said. Ambulance workers have demanded an 11 percent raise and a pay formula like those of police and firemen, guaranteeing automatic raises. The government has offered an increase of 9 percent over 18 months, but it says it won't accept the pay formula.

DOC.HEAD: Reputation for Arms Deals Drew IRA to South Florida, Officials Indicate
DOC.TEXT: Four suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas accused of trying to buy a Stinger missile in an undercover sting may have been attracted to south Florida by its reputation for arms deals, federal officials suggested. The sting that began last fall culminated in the arrests Friday of three Irishmen and a Canadian on arms charges. All four were being held without bond Saturday at the Palm Beach County Jail, and were to be arraigned Tuesday before a U.S. magistrate in West Palm Beach. The region has never been known for a significant IRA presence. But it usually leads the nation in gun cases, said Bruce Snyder, a spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Alchohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Miami. ``Traditionally, we are the No. 1 area,'' especially for machine guns and other high-powered weapons, Snyder said. Although the Miami area has its share of international intrigue involving Latin America, other U.S. cities such as New York, Boston and San Francisco have reputations as sympathetic havens for IRA members and fund-raising. Last July 12, authorities arrested three IRA ``technical experts'' in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Pennyslvania and seized radar and missile parts. ``This is the first one I remember in south Florida, and I've been here since 1969,'' Snyder said. ``This is the first one we've had with the IRA.'' The investigation by the ATF, the FBI and the Customs Service began in late October after agents received reports that the men, three of whom lived together at a trailer park in Riviera Beach near Palm Beach, were looking to buy weapons, agents said. ``South Florida certainly has a reputation as a place where weapons can be provided,'' ATF agent Robert Creighton said Friday. Seamus Moley, 30, of Ireland was arrested outside a West Palm Beach warehouse after handing over $50,000 for the shoulder-launched, heat-seeking Stinger, which rebels in Afghanistan used to shoot down Soviet warplanes and helicopters, Snyder said. Kevin Joseph McKinley, 33, and Joseph McColgan, 39, also of Ireland; and Sean John McCann, 39, were arrested a short time later, the spokesman said. The missile was borrowed from the military for the ``sale,'' and was supposed to be the first of several transactions with the Provisional IRA, or ``Provos,'' the guerrilla arm of the nationalist group fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland, according to Snyder. ``They were talking about other military weapons and military high explosives,'' he said. Customs and ATF agents concocted a similar sting involving sophisticated weapons in West Palm Beach last June when two men allegedly sought machine guns and explosives to kill members of a rival Colombian drug cartel. ``I don't think you can take these two instances and draw the conclusion that this is a center'' for terrorist activities, Customs supervisor Tim Wagner said Friday. ``It is, however, one of several places where arms obviously can be purchased.'' McKinley, Moley, McColgan and McCann were charged with violating the Arms Export Control Act, possession of a destructive device and conspiracy. If convicted, each faces up to 25 years in prison and a $750,000 fine. McKinley, Moley and McCann lived at the trailer park for at least a year, and all four worked in the West Palm Beach area. The three roommates shook their heads when asked if they were guilty as they were led to jail, but McColgan was more talkative. ``I'm just a poor Irishman here on holiday, and I was entrapped by certain people here,'' he said. ``Certain people have offered to sell me a piece of equipment for the Irish Republican struggle.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Help for Eastern Europe, Criticizes West
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Saturday hailed pro-democracy uprisings in Warsaw Pact nations and the greater liberty in the Soviet Union, but he accused Western democracies of abusing their freedom. In a wide-ranging address to diplomats accredited to the Holy See, the pontiff also appeared to indirectly criticize the American invasion of Panama for the harm it caused civilians. He praised U.S. and Soviet leaders for improvements in superpower relations and called for greater religious rights in Islamic countries.
