The pope's annual address to the diplomats is generally his most detailed comment on the state of world politics. ``The Holy See has greeted with satisfaction the great transformations that, particularly in Europe, have recently marked the lives of so many people,'' the Polish-born pontiff said. ``Warsaw, Moscow, Budapest, Berlin, Prague, Sofia and Bucharest ... have become like the stages of a long pilgrimage toward liberty,'' John Paul said. ``We must render homage to the people who, at the cost of immense sacrifices, courageously carried this out, and to the political authorities who favored it.'' The pope did not mention any leaders by name, but he appeared to be extending clear support for the liberal policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whom he met in December in the first encounter between a pontiff and a Soviet leader. In contrast to the glowing comments about Eastern Europe, the pontiff said Western democracies often do not know how to use their liberties and instead embrace such ``counter-values'' as egoism, hedonism, racism and materialism. ``The newcomers to freedom and democracy should not be let down by those who are considered `veterans,''' John Paul said in French. While praising the uprisings in Eastern Europe, the pontiff warned of ethnic and nationalist passions unleashed by movements for greater liberty. ``The consequences of the Second World War ... call us to vigilance,'' he said. ``Century-old rivalries can still resurge, conflicts among ethnic minorities can inflame anew, nationalist feelings can be exacerbated.'' Turning to superpower relations, the pontiff said his contacts with U.S. and Soviet leaders had revealed ``their will to build international cooperation on a more secure foundation.'' On the subject of Panama, he appeared to criticize the U.S. invasion that ousted dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``There, once again, it is the civil population that has suffered the most,'' John Paul said. ``It is to be hoped that, without delay, the Panamanian people can recover a normal life, with the dignity and liberty that are the right of a sovereign people.'' The pontiff called on Islamic countries to provide greater religious rights and a bigger role in public life for their Christian minorities. The pope also touched on the following areas: _Africa. John Paul praised the holding of elections in Namibia and the negotiations to end conflicts in Angola and Mozambique. He said political reforms in South Africa had to be ``better translated into reality.'' He also decried the wars in the Sudan and Ethiopia that were aggravating famines there. _Latin America. The pope said the holding of democratic elections in Chile and Brazil were an ``important step.'' He condemned the slaying of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador and said it was a ``suicidal illusion'' to think that violence could solve the country's problems. He also assailed violence and terrorism in Peru and Colombia. _Middle East. The pontiff said the situation of Lebanon remained ``precarious'' and that the Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank were ``still submitted to suffering that is difficult to accept.'' He said the Israeli-Palestinian problem could only be resolved through negotiations recognizing the ``legitimate aspirations'' of both sides. _Far East. John Paul called for a peaceful resolution of the Cambodian and Sri Lankan conflicts. He encouraged Vietnam's recent opening toward the West and greater tolerance of religious activity. ``The church and the Holy See are obviously ready for all dialogue that could improve the situation in that country,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: DeVries Would Consider Using Banned Artificial Heart To Save A Life
DOC.TEXT: The first surgeon to implant the Jarvik artificial heart says he might use it again if a patient's life were threatened, even though the Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn its approval. ``I have an option of either disobeying the law and helping a dying patient, or letting the patient die because I'm scared of what the FDA will do to me,'' said Dr. William C. DeVries. ``If it comes to a matter of you getting slapped on your wrist and saving a patient's life, you'd rather get slapped on the wrist.'' The FDA said last week it was withdrawing approval of the device's use after inspections revealed ``serious deficiencies'' in the way Symbion Inc., the Jarvik's manufacturer, was carrying out studies with the device. The FDA cited shortcomings in quality control, research-site monitoring, training of personnel and reporting of adverse reactions. DeVries said Friday he believes the Jarvik ``is scientifically a sound device, and it keeps people alive that would normally die.'' He would refuse to use the device if he found problems affecting the quality of the artificial heart, he added. But ``I don't intend to have my patients suffer because I don't have a device available,'' the Louisville-based surgeon said. The head of the transplant and artificial-heart program at the University of Arizona, Dr. Jack Copeland, also said last week he would consider continued use of the artificial heart because he believes there is no scientific basis for the FDA's decision. DeVries said he asked the FDA what he should do about Carl E. Bryant, a suburban Louisville man who received a Jarvik 7-70 on Dec. 22 as a bridge to a heart transplant. He said the FDA told him, ``You go ahead with what you're doing.'' DeVries said the Jarvik has been used by 37 clinical investigators and implanted as a bridge to a transplant more than 150 times, making it one of the leading devices being used to buy time for patients who need heart transplants. DeVries was the only surgeon in the United States authorized by the FDA to perform permanent implants of artificial hearts. He implanted the Jarvik-7 into the chests of Barney Clark _ the world's first artificial heart patient _ William Schroeder, Murray Haydon and Jack Burcham. Schroeder of Jasper, Ind., lived 620 days after receiving his Jarvik-7 Nov. 25, 1984, becoming the longest living receipient of the artificial heart. The last permanent artificial heart recipient was Burcham, who died 10 days after the implant on April 14, 1985. DeVries' artificial heart research is funded by Humana Inc., a Louisville-based health-care chain that lured him from the University of Utah several years ago. DeVries said Humana supports his intention to explore the possibility of using other mechanical assist devices as well the Jarvik. But the surgeon notes ``it would take months'' to gain the necessary approval to switch. Humana's commitment is to research on artificial hearts and mechanical assist devices, ``not to the Jarvik specifically,'' said company spokeswoman Susan McArthur.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacists Gather in Tennessee Despite Ordinance
DOC.TEXT: Police blunted a Ku Klux Klan homecoming rally Saturday in the town where the group was founded by citing its leader with violating a parade ordinance. About 200 white supremacists from various groups gathered in the town square to hear the Rev. Thom Robb, national director of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, blast communists, homosexuals, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and his ``worshipers'' and local officials who had opposed his group. Later Saturday, more than 300 Klansmen and skinheads chanted hate slogans as they marched around the town square in Lawrenceburg, about 20 miles west of Pulaski. A man who drew derision from the white supremacists was arrested for grabbing an American flag from a pole and trying to burn it. The Klan has marched through Pulaski on the Saturday before King's birthday for the past four years. Officials tried to preempt the hate group by obtaining the only parade permit the town would issue for Saturday, a restriction upheld by a federal judge last week. Police cited Robb with violating the local ordinance, and he was ordered to appear in court when he refused to sign the citation. ``We didn't have a parade. We were blocked out of a place to meet,'' Robb said, accusing ``narrow-minded promoters of intolerance'' of trying to deny the Klan freedom to peacefully assemble and freedom of speech. However, Klansmen and skinheads taunted a man holding a poster supporting King's ideals, ripped the poster from his hands and tried to burn it. ``I just wanted to come and show the other side of the story,'' said Sam Black, 22, a journalism student from Western Kentucky University. ``If I can make one little bit of difference I would like to show someone here something else besides hatred,'' Black said. Pulaski, 71 miles south of Nashville, was the birthplace of the original Ku Klux Klan in 1866. Modern Klan factions evolved from a second movement organized in 1915.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill Three in West Belfast
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers in plainclothes shot and killed three men who were allegedly holding up a betting shop Saturday in West Belfast, police said. A fourth man, apparently a passer-by, was wounded by gunfire, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Police later said the alleged robbers had been carrying very realistic replica guns. Police did not immediately identify the dead men, but Sinn Fein, the legal political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said the names they had been given by local people were of men ``with a long track record of this sort of thing.'' Sinn Fein denied that any of the dead were members of the IRA, though Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams accused the security forces of ``the cold-blooded and savage murder of three young men.'' He made the accusation before it was reported the guns were fakes. The predominantly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the 60 percent Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Irish Republic. Brian Mawhinney, Northern Ireland minister, said Saturday's killings would be thoroughly investigated. ``Does anyone really believe that the would-be robbers told either their intended victims or the security forces that the guns they were carrying were in fact only imitations?'' he said. In their statement, authorities of the constabulary said two soldiers who were on duty but not in uniform interrupted a robbery at a betting shop on the Falls Road in West Belfast. ``Shots were fired, and three persons were killed _ one man in a car and the others, both of whom had been hooded, outside a stolen vehicle. A fourth person, believed to be a passer-by, was injured.'' Police said the car used by the suspects had been stolen from a hospital parking lot the previous night. A spokesman for the constabulary, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not know who started the shooting. He also declined to comment on reports in Belfast that the soldiers were members of the elite SAS, the Special Air Service unit of the British Army. He said such reports were ``rumor and speculation.'' A man interviewed by Independent Television News, who claimed to have witnessed the shooting, said the soldiers fired at two men as they lay wounded on the sidewalk. The man was not identified in the report.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Spill in NY-NJ Waterway Called `Mini-Alaska' for Damage to Fish, Birds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `New Jersey...,' to clarify that oil leaked from underwater pipeline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: A half-million-gallon oil spill that one official dubbed Exxon's ``mini-Alaska'' has fouled one of the East Coast's richest spawning grounds, and environmentalists fear it will cause long-term devastation. The Environmental Protection Agency said it was prepared to fine Exxon Corp. $10,000 a day starting Wednesday unless it received a detailed explanation of the Jan. 2 spillof home heating oil in the Arthur Kill shipping channel between New Jersey and the New York City borough of Staten Island. New Jersey filed suit Friday against Exxon over the 567,000-gallon leak from an underwater pipeline _ which the company originally had pegged at just 5,000 gallons. But New York officials decided not to sue because the company agreed to pay for an environmental study and damages. Carcasses of oil-coated ducks and dying seagulls have been recovered from the shores of Prall's Island, one of the Audubon Society's oldest urban sanctuaries. By midday Saturday, 369 birds had been counted dead by the Coast Guard and dozens more were being cleaned and treated for injuries. ``The number we find dead are obviously very conservative numbers,'' said Bruce Freeman, administrator for the marine fisheries division of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. ``The ones you find aren't necessarily all the ones that died. Some of these may fly into another area and die weeks later or months later,'' he said. Exxon's wildlife coordinator, John Launchi, said Saturday that the waterway is clean and the cleanup crew will focus on sopping up oil in the marshlands. ``The cleanup effort is lessening because we've recovered all the oil from the Arthur Kill,'' he said. ``But the maintenance work will go on for a long time.'' The fish and other organisms that have evolved to survive in the long-polluted waterways may not be able to take this latest punch, said Judith Weis, a Rutgers University doctor of zoology who has studied the waterway for 10 years. ``They may not be able to produce as well; their eggs may not hatch properly,'' she said. ``We are looking at the few survivors as it is. Think of them as the heroes who have managed to persist in this dreadful place. ``Now they could be pushed over the brink.'' Ms. Weis, who is on leave from Rutgers and working at the National Science Foundation in Washington, said: ``I would certainly not predict that the populations will be totally wiped out. I can predict that their populations will be sharply reduced.'' As the food supply becomes more scarce, birds will be forced to fly to areas such as the Hackensack Meadowlands to survive, said Peter Dunne, spokesman for the New Jersey Audubon Society. That will force birds that normally migrate there to make room for the Arthur Kill birds. ``You can think of it as musical chairs and somebody just pulled one of the chairs out of the room,'' Dunne said. ``Eventually, someone lands on the floor.'' New Jersey sued Exxon on Friday to recover damages from the oil company's spill, and officials left open the possibility of filing criminal charges. Exxon, in response to the threat of a lawsuit by New York, said it will pay for ``appropriate'' environmental studies of its oil spill, and that it has accepted responsibility for ``damages for which it is liable.'' New York Attorney General Robert Abrams held off on the suit but said he would not hesitate to file court papers if Exxon goes back on its word. ``Exxon's violations of New York State's Navigation and Environmental Conservation Laws and the federal Clean Water Act are obvious and incontestable, and have created a `mini-Alaska' in the Arthur Kill,'' Abrams wrote to Exxon. Last March, an Exxon tanker ran aground on a reef an spilled 11 million gallons into Alaska's pristine Prince William Sound. In New Jersey, officials say Exxon has not refused to pay for costs involved with the cleanup and restoration of the area, but the company has not agreed either. ``The state is incurring substantial costs,'' said John Hagerty, spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. ``Whatever we spend, we anticipate Exxon paying for, either voluntarily or pursuant to a court ruling. We haven't been able to put a pricetag on our environment yet.'' The EPA gave Exxon until Wednesday to explain how the spill occurred, what the company's response was to protect the environment and what is being done to restore the environment. EPA spokeswoman Kim Helper said her agency was particularly concerned that Exxon initially estimated only 5,000 gallons of oil had spilled. Exxon officials originally blamed a faulty leak-detection alarm for allowing so much oil to spill undetected. But on Tuesday they revised that assessment, saying the device was oversensitive, but not faulty, and said its attorneys advised them not to say anything further on the cause. Exxon spokesman Phil Wetz said the company also would not comment on the proposed EPA fines or on the New Jersey lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Releases Former US Sympathizers
DOC.TEXT: The first of 7,000 Vietnamese imprisoned because of their U.S. ties during the Vietnam War will begin resettlement in the United States this weekend, the White House said Saturday. The former South Vietnamese soldiers, government workers, former employees of the U.S. government and their families are being brought here under an agreement concluded last July with the communist government in Hanoi, said presidential Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Neither the White House nor the State Department gave details on when and where the 61 Vietnamese would arrive in this country from Bangkok, Thailand, where they have been since early this month. Fitzwater said the refugees' arrival represents ``years of intensive U.S. diplomatic efforts to obtain permission for those persons and their families who were closely associated with the United States during the Vietnam War period to immigrate to the United States.'' ``All Americans rejoice at this event, but we particularly share the joy of those in the Vietnamese-American community who will now, at long last, be reunited with their family and friends in the United States,'' said Fitzwater. Another 88 former detainees are scheduled to arrive here later this week, with the total to reach 700 by the end of the month, the White House said. The entire 7,000 are expected to be in the United States by Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Attorney Named to Team
LaserPhoto MH4
DOC.TEXT: A top Justice Department lawyer who played a role in the Oliver North case was named Saturday to help lead the prosecution of ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega on drug charges. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said Deputy U.S. Solicitor General William C. Bryson and two Miami assistants would lead the prosecution team, and removed himself from the case. Lehtinen said at a news conference that he never planned to prosecute Noriega despite appearing as co-counsel at Noriega's arraignment. ``My approach has always been to assemble teams of experienced assistants to win the many long, complex cases we face here,'' the prosecutor said. ``The Noriega case has been no different.'' Noriega, who surrendered Jan. 3 to U.S. troops who invaded Panama, is accused of using his country to protect shipments of cocaine, drug-processing chemicals and drug money. He is believed held in a basement apartment at the federal courthouse. The February 1988 indictment named 15 other people. Bryson will coordinate the drafting of briefs and argument of legal issues in the case, Lehtinen said. Bryson is a former law clerk to Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall and has been with the Justice Department since 1978. He was named deputy solicitor general in 1986 after heading the criminal appellate section. He was acting solicitor general last year, and during that time wrote the government's Supreme Court brief urging the justices to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision guaranteeing a woman's right to an abortion. Bryson was also involved last year in the attorney general's effort to prevent leaks of classified information at former White House aide North's Iran-Contra trial. Classified information is a concern in the Noriega case because of the fallen Panamanian ruler's long association with the CIA. Lehtinen said all information needed to successfully prosecute the case will be provided to prosecutors. ``The United States government has every intention of providing all material necessary for the prosecution,'' he said. ``Mr. Bush has said that.'' Defense attorneys already are asking for classified materials, Lehtinen has said. Also named to head the team were Assistant U.S. Attorneys Michael Patrick ``Pat'' Sullivan and Myles H. Malman, both longtime Miami prosecutors. Lehtinen said Attorney General Richard Thornburgh did not order him off the case, although unidentified Justice Department sources in Washington expressed reservations last week about Lehtinen's ability to run the busy Miami office and handle a trial expected to last up to six months. Lehtinen said it was his decision to not try the case. ``There are a number of other major drug, white-collar crime, public corruption and other cases pending in the Southern District of Florida, and in my role as chief federal prosecutor for this district I could not devote the time to the Noriega case that would be needed for its proper presentation to the court,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Relish Being Part of History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf from bottom, ```Some of...,' to CORRECT woman's name from Wiggins to Wheaton.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Wilder Inauguration, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some of the estimated 35,000 people who jammed the Capitol grounds for Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's inauguration couldn't see the ceremony and had to strain to hear the oath of office. But it didn't matter. They got what they came for: a feeling of being a part of history, seeing the nation's first elected black governor take office. ``I'm a little disappointed we couldn't get any closer,'' said Lillian Wiggins of Washington, D.C. ``But the fact that I brought my grandchildren and that it's an historic occasion makes it important that we stay.'' She added, ``We'll go home and see what happened on television.'' The crowd was more than twice as large as the one that saw Wilder's predecessor, Gerald L. Baliles, take office four years ago. As they waited for the ceremony to begin, many in the crowd commented that the weather was ideal. Temperatures were in the 30s but seemed warmer to bundled-up spectators who were jammed shoulder-to-shoulder in bright sunshine. Security was tight, with police guarding entrances to the grounds and ushering spectators to roped-off areas. Latecomers were stuck with bad vantage points even if they had tickets for bleachers reserved for 3,500 invitees. ``We had tickets, but we showed up late and they wouldn't let us in,'' said Nolan Dawkins, a judge from Alexandria. The Dawkins children were glad they came anyway, because they got to see the parade of marching bands and military units that followed the swearing-in ceremony. ``I wanted to come because I want to tell my kids about this when I grow up,'' said Kelli Dawkins, 9. ``I want to tell them I was there to see the first black governor.'' Kelli's sense of history was lost, however, on 3-year-old sister Ashley. Asked if she knew who Doug Wilder was, Ashley replied: ``Kelli's friend.'' Rachel Wheaton didn't make the mistake Ms. Wiggins and the Dawkins family made. The Petersburg High School history teacher and 72 students staked out places front and center at 8 a.m., four hours before the ceremony. ``Some of these kids got up at 4:30 this morning,'' Ms. Wheaton said. ``Some of them asked off their weekend jobs so they could attend, and others gave up their free Saturdays because they know this is historic not only for Virginia, but for the nation.'' Savannah Williams, a cultural anthropologist from Surry, was first in line for one of about 300 available seats for a 9 a.m. prayer service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church across from the Capitol. ``I've been standing here in the cold since 7:15,'' Ms. Williams said. ``Africans first came here in 1619, and now it's 1990. I think it's important to see a person of African descent finally become a governor.''

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross' Mystery Donor Turns Out to Be Mentally Handicapped Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo in name.
DOC.TEXT: For months, American Red Cross officials were mystified by weekly donations of $1 or less from an anonymous contributor who has sent in $17 thus far for victims of Hurricane Hugo. Recently they discovered the benefactor is Dalbey Marsh, 51, a mentally handicapped man who lives in Rossiter and ekes out the contributions from his Social Security income. Now the Red Cross wants to give him special thanks. ``We are going to send him some stuff and a certificate thanking him for helping us out,'' said Glenn Ellis, executive director of the Charleston, S.C., Red Cross. ``What I told him is how much we appreciate that dollar we got from him each week _ even more than the big donations _ because we knew it really came from his heart. He may have his troubles, but he really cares about people,'' said Ellis. ``I'm glad to humbly do good to help the poor and help end suffering,'' Marsh said Saturday. ``I just wanted to be generous and help out. It's just because I want to be nice. I have my troubles, too, and some of those used to be pretty bad. But I am a Christian, and I try to be kind.'' Marsh moved to a personal care home 3{ years ago after spending 20 years at a state hospital in Torrance. Red Cross officials had been baffled about the donations since they began arriving in September. The drawn-out scrawl on the envelopes led them to believe that the mystery donor was a child. Marsh's identity was learned with the help of Dolores Comstock, Rossiter's postmaster. Ms. Comstock said Marsh has made many trips over the past few years to her Main Street post office to mail money to various charities. When he was unable to donate a dollar bill, she taped his change to a piece of cardboard. ``I'd notice he would send a dollar, or change, to the Helen Keller Foundation,'' she said. ``He had seen ads on TV that money helps buy vitamin A to eradicate blindness in children in Third World countries. He was concerned about children becoming blind.'' After Hurricane Hugo ripped costal South Carolina in September, claiming 29 lives and causing nearly $6 billion in damage, Marsh asked Ms. Comstock where he could send contributions. ``I thought of a couple of agencies, and he chose the Red Cross,'' she said. ``He's on a limited disability income, but he sends off little bits and pieces of what he has.'' Marsh said he also sent money to help earthquake victims in San Francisco. ``I like to think what I send helps, but if I can't do it, I pray about it,'' Marsh said. ``I hug the Bible and say, `Lord, someone needs your comfort.' In some ways, the Lord has watched over me.'' Because of publicity over the past few days Marsh has been busy taking telephone calls from reporters, but he said he won't let the attention go to his head. ``I even got my face on TV,'' he said. ``But my reward will be in heaven. I prefer to wait until heaven, for a great reward awaits me there.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Developer Trump to Raze Historic Hotel, Build Huge Complex
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump said Saturday he and partners will raze the landmark Ambassador Hotel, site of Robert Kennedy's murder and a faded glamor palace, to build a major office, hotel and residence complex. The New York billionaire's plan and endorsements by Mayor Tom Bradley and two key city councilmen seemed to spell doom for the once-grand edifice, which closed a year ago. Residents concerned about vanishing cultural heritage had urged preservation of the hotel and school district officials wanted to buy the 23-acre site on Wilshire Boulevard for a badly needed new high school. The project, which was portrayed as in the earliest stages of planning, will probably include a hotel, office space, shopping areas and residential buildings, Trump said. The New York City-based real estate magnate revealed his investment in the project at a news conference in the East Garden room of the 494-room hotel, which opened in 1921. It was in an Ambassador kitchen on June 5, 1968, that Kennedy, a New York senator and Democratic presidential candidate, was assassinated by Sirhan Sirhan moments after claiming victory in the California primary. Though it once counted U.S. presidents among its guests, and its famous Cocoanut Grove nightclub was a watering hole for Hollywood legends, the lobby area was now the only place fit for people to gather, Trump said. The hotel site was purchased last September for $64 million by Wilshire Center Partners, who include Irish real estate developer Robin Power and New York developer and investor Scott Malkin. Trump, whose involvement was rumored a month ago, was announced as the new managing partner of what is now Trump Wilshire Associates. He would not estimate the project's cost but anticipated no problem in financing it. ``I'll be investing a substantial amount of money in the project over a period of years,'' he said. ``I think we're going to have a very, very easy time getting the financing.'' The only specific structure envisioned by Trump is a 50,000-square-foot ``Cocoanut Grove Ballroom'' to fill what he said was the need for a really big ballroom in Los Angeles. It would be twice the size of the biggest ballroom here. The plan was firmly backed by Mayor Bradley, Councilman Nate Holden, whose district includes the Ambassador, and Council President John Ferraro. The officials characterized the plan as a way to revitalize the declining neighborhood a few miles west of downtown and link the downtown business district with the Century City complex on the city's west side. ``I believe it has great potential. This stretch of Wilshire Boulevard needs to be reborn,'' said Bradley. He noted he had asked the developers to help find an alternate site for a school in the area. ``Why did it take you so long to find L.A.?'' Ferraro asked Trump. Trump and Holden said the land was too expensive for a school, even if the Los Angeles Unified School District sought to acquire it through eminent domain. ``You would have the world's most expensive school,'' Trump said. Trump said it was ``very unlikely'' that any portion of the original structure would be preserved, and soundly bashed what remained of the Ambassador's character. ``This is not a good building to be in if there was an earthquake. It is an old structure and from the safety standpoint ... you wouldn't be allowed to build a building like this today,'' he said. ``Second of all it's not, according to most, the aesthetic building that really we should have at this site. It's so old and so dilapidated and so run down, and ... it's been leaking. ... It's really in very bad shape.'' He said virtually every world class architect was vying for the job of designing the new project and he expected cultural heritage buffs would ``love'' the result.

DOC.HEAD: Liberal Official in China Reportedly to be Purged
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities will soon purge a liberal official who pioneered free-market policies in southern China and advocated democracy, an independent newspaper reported Saturday. The Chinese-language daily Ming Pao reported that Yuan Geng, 71, director of the Commerce Bureau in Shekou, would be dismissed and his economic reform policy would be criticized. Yuan transformed Shekou, a district of the Shenzhen special economic zone, from bare land into a coastal industrial town after the government began its experiments in free-market economics in four coastal cities in 1979, Ming Pao reported. The newspaper quoted the liberal leader as having said publicly, ``The Communist Party needs democracy as it needs air.'' Ming Pao said Yuan put an end to the fixed wage and introduced social security and housing reform in Shekou, a town 18 miles northwest of Hong Kong. Ousted party chief Zhao Ziyang, then premier, praised the reform as the ``Shekou model.'' Ziyang was expelled as party chief in the wake of student-led pro-democracy protests that the government crushed by sending troops across Beijing in June. He was replaced by Jiang Zemin, a hard-liner. Shekou News, a liberal weekly published by Yuan's bureau, has been banned since November, Ming Pao reported. It said government officials accused Shekou News of organizing demonstrations, giving full coverage to marches in Beijing, and calling for press freedom and democracy to support students in the capital. Ming Pao also said a purge of the media has started in the free-wheeling southern city of Canton and in Shenzhen. It said party members must register anew and many media organizations have been reshuffled. It also said the top man of the party newspaper Canton Daily will be replaced because ``he has not done his best in the previous investigation.'' The news paper said party members in the media have had to reveal what they did during the pro-democracy movement last spring.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Storm Brings Rain, Snow to California
DOC.TEXT: A storm soaked California and brought heavy snow to that state, Oregon and Nevada on Saturday, triggering a mud slide that trapped several cars and closed a road. Scattered showers extended as far east as the northern and central Rockies, and skies over much of the West were cloudy. To the east, snow showers fell in the Great Lakes region, the upper Ohio Valley and northern New England. Up to a foot of new snow blanketed northwest Pennsylvania and up to 6 inches fell in the mountains in the western sections of the state. California began getting heavy rain Friday. Between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. Friday, Sacramento received 1.56 inches of rain. The rainfall total for the day of 2.53 inches easily surpassed the old record for the date of 1.65 inches established in 1906. On Saturday, several feet of mud came crashing down across the San Francisquito Canyon Road about 50 miles north of downtown Los Angeles, closing it in both directions, said Highway Patrol spokesman Tom Coleman. Several cars became mired in the mud, and drivers had to escape through windows, said Los Angeles County fire Capt. James Jeffries. No injuries were reported. Up to 4 inches of rain were expected in some of northern California's coastal mountains and coastal Southern California. Winter storm warnings for up to 3 feet of snow by Sunday morning were issued for California's Siskiyou Mountains and Mount Shasta, the Sierra Nevada range in California and Nevada, and the Lake Tahoe area in western Nevada. Winds gusting up to 40 mph were expected to cause blowing, drifting snow at higher elevations in Nevada. Snow was also expected at higher elevations in Southern California and Oregon's southern Cascade Mountains. Much of the Northeast had blustery winds Saturday. Brisk southerlies blew over the High Plains, helping raise temperatures into the 50s. The temperature reached 52 degrees in Casper, Wyo., equaling the record high for the date set in 1953. The low for the Lower 48 states Saturday morning was 14 degrees below zero in International Falls, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Two French Tourists Killed by Maoist Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas stopped a bus in the southern Andean highlands, ordered the passengers out and shot and killed two French tourists, police said Saturday. Four other foreign tourists were killed under similar circumstances in the same area last year. The Shining Path rebels stopped the bus Friday night and ordered the 72 passengers to get out. They then shot and killed 22-year-old Stephane Marino, a fisherman, and Christelle Berthelot, a 22-year-old student, police said. Both victims were carrying French passports. The bus was traveling between the cities of Ayacucho and Andahuaylas, about 250 miles southeast of Lima. The two French tourists left Lima four days ago, police said. The region where the two were traveling has been declared an emergency zone by the government, giving broad powers to the military to fight leftist rebels. The U.S. Embassy and other embassies have issued warnings urging tourists not to travel to the emergency zones, which account for nearly a third of the territory of Peru. Two German tourists were killed in the same area in May last year, and an Australian man and a woman from New Zealand were killed there in November. At least 22 foreigners _ including foreign aid workers and one journalist _ have been killed by the guerrillas since 1980, when the Shining Path launched its armed insurgency near Ayacucho. Eight foreigners were killed in June 1986 when the rebels bombed a tourist train to Machu Picchu, the ancient citadel of the Incas near Cuzco. The Mao-inspired Shining Path is fighting to topple Peru's elected government. It operates throughout the Andean highlands, in the coca-growing jungles of the northeast and some coastal cities. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the violence since 1980.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Rocky Flats Workers Exposed to Beryllium Have Lung Disease
DOC.TEXT: Twelve people who were exposed to the metal beryllium while working at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant have contracted a deadly lung disease, according to an Energy Department study obtained by a newspaper. Eight current Rocky Flats workers and four retired employees tested positive for berylliosis, The Denver Post reported in its Sunday editions. They were among more than 750 employees at the federal complex 16 miles northwest of Denver who have handled beryllium, a metal used in the manufacture of plutonium triggers. So far, diagnostic tests have been given to 391 of those workers. No deaths have been reported, but the incurable disease usually proves fatal to 30 percent of those who contract it, doctors said. The disease was discovered during a $2 million medical study of Rocky Flats financed by the Energy Department and the National Institutes of Health. Researchers say it is the biggest workforce study of berylliosis to date and is scheduled to be completed in 1993. The study is being overseen by Denver doctors from the National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine and the University of Colorado Medical School. ``This study will have an impact on every beryllium operation in the world,'' said Dr. Lee Newman, an assistant CU medical professor leading the research with Dr. Kathleen Kreiss of National Jewish. The Energy Department released records on the study after The Post requested them under the Freedom of Information Act. Beryllium is a strong, lightweight metal that increasingly is being used in nuclear, aerospace, telecommunications and computer industries, as well as in ceramics, dental alloys, car parts and golf clubs. Berylliosis is difficult to detect because it usually remains dormant for 10 years after the metal lodges inside the body. The Denver researchers are trying to develop tests that will warn the Energy Department if a worker is susceptible to the disease. Contact with finished beryllium products isn't hazardous, Newman said. But an estimated 800,000 American workers have been exposed to beryllium dust in 93,000 private and government plants across the nation, and are considered at risk for the disease. The Environmental Protection Agency ranks beryllium 28th among the most-used substances linked to cancer in industry. At Rocky Flats, the Energy Department has spent $2 million in the past four years on a program to improve safety conditions and reduce airborne beryllium concentrations in manufacturing areas, said department spokesman Pat Etchart at Rocky Flats. ``We've installed high-velocity, low-volume ventilation systems and more efficient containment hoods in process areas,'' Etchart said. ``A safety training program for all workers in those areas has also been initiated and medical monitoring was strengthened.'' But during an environmental audit of the plant last summer, Energy Department investigators cited Rocky Flats for not following federal and state procedures in monitoring beryllium emissions from smokestacks. Rocky Flats' new operator, EG&G Inc., said it is protecting workers from airborne beryllium dust by insisting on a factory standard twice as tough as the guideline set by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Newman said protection programs at Rocky Flats were improved after the first case was discovered there in 1984. He believes ``the safety setup is pretty good'' now for beryllium at Rocky Flats. About 2 percent to 5 percent of all workers exposed to beryllium eventually develop the disease, researchers say.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Stabs Palestinian; Soldiers Shoot 12 Palestinians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS five grafs to UPDATE with continued investigation into killing of Palestinian; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Arab teen-ager Saturday fatally stabbed a Palestinian man accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Twelve other Palestinians were reported shot by soldiers during protests in the Gaza Strip. In the occupied West Bank, Israeli troops arrested dozens of Palestinian activists during a series of raids, the army said. Hospital officials said 50-year-old Naim Mohamad Handukah was brought to Shifa hospital in Gaza City with multiple stab wounds in the chest. Arab reports said Handukah was in his taxi company's office in the affluent Rimal neighborhood when a 16-year-old youth broke in and attacked him with a dagger. The army confirmed the death. ``The police carried out a chase after the youth, but he got away,'' said Gaza District Police spokesman Yigal Golan. He said police knew the name of the suspect. Israel radio said Handukah was apparently accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities. His killing came hours after masked Arabs shot to death Safedin Al Qudsi, 40, in the Bureji refugee camp Friday night. Arab reporters said he was also suspected of assisting Israel. The deaths brought to 170 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the 2-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Most have been accused of collaborating with Israel. At least 646 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have been slain. In Gaza City, dozens of Palestinians blocked the main commercial street and hurled rocks at Israeli soldiers manning three nearby observation posts, Arab reporters and hospital officials said. The soldiers opened fire, wounding four Palestinians, hospital officials said. At least four other Palestinians suffered gunshot wounds in a similar clash in Rafah. Soldiers also shot and wounded four Palestinians in two other incidents, hospital officials said. The army said Palestinians had thrown a bottle of acid on a jeep patrol but that no one was injured. They said they had no reports of shooting incidents but were checking further. In the West Bank, soldiers raided the villages of Yatta, Beit Rima, Anabta and Jaba and rounded up dozens of Palestinian activists, the army said. It said troops also confiscated ``much inciteful material and equipment used by masked youths.'' It did not provide details but said the villages have been sites of hostile activity. Also Saturday, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, head of the Central Command, ordered a continued investigation into the actions of paramilitary border police following a report that they gave a false account of the fatal shooting of a Palestinian teen-ager, Israel television reported. An investigation determined Thursday that the border police had violated orders in the death of Fadi Zabakli, a Bethlehem teen-ager who was killed during a demonstration Dec. 28. He died Sunday. Mordechai now wants more information in the case, the television said. The army spokesman had initially said Zabakli and other Palestinian youths had carried axes and ignored orders to halt as well as warning shots in the air. However, an ABC-TV tape broadcast on Israel television showed that the youths did not have axes and that a border policeman had not fired warning shots in the air. Instead, it showed the policeman kneeling, aiming and firing, hitting Zabakli in the back of the head.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa. (AP) Jerome Weinstein, editor of the Centre Daily Times for 35 years, died Friday after suffering a heart attack. He was 73. He became sports editor of the Times in 1937, a year before he graduated from Penn State. In 1940, he was named city editor-managing editor. The following year, he joined The Associated Press and served as news editor in Philadelphia and Harrisburg. He rejoined the Times in 1945, and was editor from 1945 until his retirement in 1980. Weinstein also was a former president of the Pennsylvania Society of Newspaper Editors in 1953 and of The AP Managing Editors. He is survived by his wife, Thomazine Curtin Weinstein, and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Six Die In House Fire
DOC.TEXT: Six people, including five children, died in a house fire early Saturday after they were trapped inside by window bars intended to guard against break-ins, authorities said. Killed in the Jacksonville fire were babysitter Valerie Johnson, 17, her 2-year-old daughter, Ashley, and four children of Ethel Landrum, owner of the home. She was in Miami for a hairdressers' convention, said Wayne Doolittle, a spokesman for the Jacksonville Public Safety Department. Ms. Landrum's children were identified as Jamal Spencer, 1, Cleveland Spencer, 3, Kenya Elmore, 14, and Eddick Landrum, 11. Padlocked burglar bars on the home's windows and doors prevented those inside from escaping, Doolittle said. The fire, which was reported at 12:27 a.m., broke out in a bedroom. The cause of the fire was still being investigated. Ms. Johnson and the 11-year-old were dead at the scene and the four others died later in hospitals. All the victims died of smoke inhalation.

DOC.HEAD: Four Blacks Killed In Latest Natal Violence
DOC.TEXT: Four men were killed in the latest round of unrest in the southeastern province of Natal, scene of a 3-year-old fight between black factions, police said Saturday. Two men were killed in separate attacks near the port city of Durban, and the other two died in Sweetwaters, about 50 miles inland, police said in their daily unrest report. They gave no details. Members of the United Democratic Front, a nationwide anti-apartheid coalition, have been battling Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu group, for supremacy in Natal since the end of 1986. Both groups oppose apartheid, the white-led government's system of racial discrimination. However, the Front is more militant and favors confrontational tactics, such as boycotts and strikes, that Inkatha does not endorse. More than 160 blacks were killed in December fighting in Durban's townships, and the figure has exceeded 50 so far this month. At least 13 people were killed Thursday night when homes were set on fire. More than 2,500 people have been killed since the two groups began fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Families of Flight 103 Victims Updated by Scottish Police
DOC.TEXT: More than a year after Pan Am Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, police officials from that Scottish town came to the United States to brief relatives of the bombing's victims on Saturday. About 130 people showed up at the St. Charles Hotel in this town about 30 miles south of Albany to hear Chief Constable George Esson of Lockerbie give details of his department's investigation. ``Better late than never,'' said Bert Ammerman, president of Victims of Pan Am Flight 103. The group Ammerman heads is made up of relatives of the 259 people killed when a bomb smuggled aboard Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988. Eleven more people were killed on the ground as debris from the exploded jet rained down on the Scottish village. Esson said he and two other investigators traveled to the United States because Ammerman, a resident of River Vale, N.J., requested that they inform families individually in a way the U.S. government had seemed unwilling to do. Victims of Pan Am Flight 103 came together after the crash in part because the families were frustrated by the lack of information coming from their own government. ``We've not only lost loved ones, but the love of our country and the feeling that our country would be there for us,'' said Bill Monetti of Chatham, N.J., whose nephew, Rick Monetti, was killed in the crash. ``We have a government that would like this to be an invisible episode,'' said Georgia Nucci of Hudson, who lost her son Chris Jones. However, many family members who showed up said they were encouraged that agents from the FBI and a member of the Presidential Commission on Security, Aviation and Terrorism showed up at the briefing. Ammerman, whose brother Tom was killed in the bombing, said he would like to see U.S. law enforcement agencies act more like their counterparts in Scotland. ``Today's meeting was a major step forward in having appropriate agencies extending themselves to the families,'' he said. Informational packets were handed out to the families at a closed-door briefing Saturday morning. The contents of the packets were not revealed, but Esson said that catalogues were included listing items recovered at the crash site that are still unclaimed. About 15 percent of the personal effects of the victims is still in storage in Lockerbie, Esson said. Nucci said the closed-door meeting also featured videos showing a reconstruction of the bombed out portion of the plane and the memorial service held last Dec. 21 in Lockerbie to mark the one-year anniversary of the crash. A presidential commission has been investigating the disaster since last August. Their report is tentatively due on May 1.

DOC.HEAD: Roving Gang Slashes Actress, 2nd Man in Manhattan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, bgn `Despite her...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comments from actress. Picks up 7th graf pvs, ```She was...' SUBS 10th graf pvs, ```My mother...,' to UPDATE with further comments. Note language in 6th graf. Book title `Viveka...Viveca' is cq in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Swedish-born actress Viveca Lindfors was slashed across her neck on a Manhattan street early Saturday by a marauding gang suspected in a similar random attack minutes earlier, police said. The 70-year-old actress, whose stage and screen career covers a half-century, needed 27 stitches after the attack at about 1:35 a.m. on a Greenwich Village street, said police spokesman Sgt. Peter Berry. Another victim required 40 stitches when he was slashed from his ear to his throat, Berry said. Police had no motive and had made no arrests. Despite her injuries, Ms. Lindfors went ahead Saturday afternoon with a performance for senior citizens, said her granddaughter, Natasha Fried. The actress later said she would not allow the attack to drive her from the city. ``This is where we live, me and my children and grandchildren, and we're not going to be kicked out by those bastards,'' she told the Daily News. But Ms. Lindfors also showed some compassion for the person who slashed her. ``I'm coming off easily, compared to him,'' she told The New York Times. ``My ear is cut, but his life is going to be hell if he doesn't face something within himself. Her granddaughter said Saturday afternoon's audience would not have known if Ms. Lindfors was in any pain. ``She was great,'' the granddaughter said. ``It was a good outlet for her. It was a good way for her to release emotion.'' The show, ``An Actor Works: Poetry,'' took place in The Theater Studio a few blocks from where the attack occurred, said Ms. Lindfors' daughter, Lena Tabori. ``She's unbelievable. She got in at 5:30 this morning, got up at 10'clock and she goes on at three,'' said Ms. Tabori from her mother's Manhattan apartment. ``This is typical of Viveca. She's incredible.'' According to police, Ms. Lindfors and three other actresses were talking on a sidewalk after completing a Friday evening performance at The Theater Studio. A group of five or six men ran past the four women, slashing Ms. Lindfors and continuing on, police said. Ms. Lindfors said she and her friends were discussing Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and Lithuania when she was attacked. ``In the middle of this discussion, this kid, he grabbed my face. ... And the next second I found myself down on the pavement,'' she said. Ms. Lindfors was slashed on the neck below her left ear. When she arrived at St. Vincent's Hospital for treatment, she met the gang's other victim _ 36-year-old Dennis Beal of New York, who was attacked shortly before Ms. Lindfors. Berry said the two attacks occurred five minutes and three blocks apart. Police are theorizing the same group of men were responsible for both, he said. Beal was walking along when a group ran up on him from behind, Berry said. The last man in the gang cut Beal, the spokesman said. Ms. Lindfors was born in Sweden and came to the United States in 1946 after eight years with the Royal Drama Theater. She has appeared in dozens of plays, movies and television shows in Sweden and the United States. Her films include ``Four Men in a Jeep'' in 1948, ``No Exit'' in 1960, ``The Way We Were'' in 1973 and ``Welcome to LA'' in 1977. Her television appearances include spots on ``The Defenders'' and ``Ben Casey.'' She is also a producer, writer and director. She is founder and artistic director of the Berkshire Theatre Festival, and her book, ``Viveka ... Viveca'' was published in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Rare, Slight Quake Rattles Baltimore Suburbs
DOC.TEXT: Suburban Baltimore residents were shaken by tremors from a rare, light earthquake on Saturday, said a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey. An earthquake with a magnitude of 2.5 on the Richter scale occurred at 4:48 p.m. EST in the Baltimore area, said USGS spokeswoman Pat Jorgenson. The epicenter of the quake was about 15 miles northwest of downtown Baltimore, she said. The Richter scale is a measure of the energy released during ground motion caused by an earthquake. An earthquake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans and usually causes no damage. ``California probably has several hundred daily in this range,'' said Jorgenson, explaining there were no damages or injuries reported. Jorgenson said scientists at the National Earthquake Center in Golden, Colo., ``were a bit surprised'' when they began getting calls from residents in Randallstown and Ellicott City, Md., who felt the tremors. Scientists ``are very sure this was an earthquake'' because they verified it on seismograms from the East Coast, the spokeswoman said. The last probable reported earthquake in the Baltimore area was in 1939, according to USGS records. ``I'm surprised they (area residents) even knew it was an earthquake since it wouldn't feel like anything more than a truck rumbling by'' a private home, said Jorgenson. USGS experts said there is no identifiable fault in the area, Jorgenson said.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana GOP Overwhelmingly Rejects Senate Bid by Ex-Klan Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th, `Duke, 39...,' to UPDATE with quote from Duke. ADDS 1 graf at end to explain election system.
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana Republicans on Saturday endorsed a New Orleans state senator to challenge incumbent U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, decisively rejecting a bid by a former Ku Klux Klan leader to gain the nomination. Delegates at the statewide convention picked state Sen. Ben Bagert over three other announced candidates _ Secretary of State Fox McKeithen, state Rep. Quentin Dastugue of Metairie and state Rep. David Duke of Metairie, the former Klan leader. The final vote showed Bagert with 451 of the convention's 792 delegate votes, followed by Dastugue with 183, McKeithen with 99, Duke with 52 and New Orleans businessman Pat Taylor with three. There were four abstentions. ``We have the energy and experience and the guts to lead a willing campaign,'' Bagert said in accepting the nomination. Bagert, 46, had been considered the front-runner for the party nomination after winning commitments from than 350 of the 540 delegates chosen at party caucuses statewide on Dec. 9. The delegates elected at the caucuses, however, had not been required to support the candidate they said they would vote for. Duke, 39, won no more than 50 delegates at the caucuses and party officials said previously he had little support among party regulars. He said he would oppose Johnston regardless of whether he won the GOP endorsement. ``I believe that I can beat Bennett Johnston. I believe that I can attract people who have not come to our party yet,'' Duke said after Bagert was nominated. Duke, elected to the state House last year as a Republican, has ties to neo-Nazi groups and currently is president of the National Association for the Advancement of White People. The party's endorsed candidate for next October's general election could gain access to many resources from both the state and national Republican Party campaign committees, including lists of potential donors and volunteers. Political analysts have said it would take such a major commitment to beat Johnston, a three-term Democrat who heads the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. He has been in office since 1972 and won re-election with 86 percent of the vote in a 1984 race against minor opponents. However, state GOP chairman William Nungesser has said Johnston can be beaten this time in spite of a multimillion-dollar campaign treasury. ``We have all these people wanting to run because Bennett is vulnerable,'' said Nungesser. Any Republican or Democrat can run in the Oct. 6 open primary against Johnston. Each GOP candidate, except Duke, had said he would not run unless he is the party's nominee. The non-partisan primary serves as the general election unless no one receives a majority. Then the top two vote-getters enter a runoff, regardless of party affiliation.

DOC.HEAD: Middlebury College Fraternities To Be Forced To Admit Women Or Close
DOC.TEXT: Fraternities on the Middlebury College campus must admit women or close, the school's Board of Trustees voted unanimously on Saturday. ``I think it represents an imaginative, creative thoughtful and workable approach to a series of concerns on this campus that have been with us for a long time,'' said college President Olin Robison. A review of the role of fraternities on campus was prompted by outrage more than a year ago, when members of the Delta Upsilon fraternity hung a bloodied female mannequin over the balcony of their house during a party. Robison said while there had been other concerns about sexism on campus in recent years, the incident with the mutilated mannequin ``certainly galvanized campus opinion ... that something needed to be done.'' In a statement, the board said ``any social organization that discriminates on the basis of gender or whose practices have the consequences of exclusion on the basis of gender are antithetical to the mission of the college and not appropriate as a mode for our society at large.'' Tom Dubreuil, house director of the Delta Upsilon fraternity, said in a prepared statement that the trustees decision has given the local and national chapters ``an extremely challenging task.'' ``The decision does show that the majority of students want to keep fraternities on campus,'' Dubreuil said. ``I expected a much more negative response to the future of fraternities, and I think the trustees have made the fairest decision they could.'' Under the board's decision, fraternities must have had their national rules changed on exclusionary policies or have severed all connections with their national organization to be allowed on campus after Dec. 31. If a fraternity succeeds in getting its national organization to change the rules to admit women with equal rights, it may retain its Greek letters. If not, the fraternity buildings will be offered to other co-educational student groups and be known as ``houses,'' Robison said. Fraternities have until the end of March to decide whether to comply with the board's decision. Middlebury College, a small, liberal arts school located about 35 miles south of Burlington, has featured fraternities since the turn of the century. Sororities have not been part of campus life since the 1960s, although Middlebury has been co-educational for a century, Robison said.. Robison, who is retiring as president this year, said endorsement of the trustees' action by directors of the Alumni Association board of directors gives the decision more weight. The association, said president William Kieffer in a statement, ``believes that all Middlebury Alumni will accept this as an excellent solution to a very difficult issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Causes $1 Million Damage to Delaware County Daily Times
DOC.TEXT: A fire at the Delaware County Daily Times newspaper caused an estimated $1 million in damages Saturday and forced editors to print Sunday's edition at a nearby sister paper. The fire, which broke out in the press room about 2:45 p.m., may have been caused by roofers using propane torches to repair the roof of the suburban Philadelphia newspaper office, said Fire Chief Tom Micozzie of the Primos Secane Westbrook Park Fire Co. No. 5. The fire was brought under control about 4:30 p.m. and is still under investigation, he said. Two editors and a reporter were inside the building when its fire alarms sounded, but they escaped without injury. The newspaper's printing press, pressroom, editorial department and a paper storage area received extensive water damage. In addition, the roof of the building will have to be replaced, Micozzie said. ``I'd say we're looking at an excess of $1 million in damages,'' he said. Much of the water came from the building's sprinkler system, which Miccozie credited with saving the structure. Kelvyn Anderson was one of three staff members working in the newsroom when the fire broke out. ``The alarm went off and at first we didn't realize it was the fire alarm that went off,'' he said. When they saw smoke coming from the press area, Anderson said he, news editor Jim Atkins and editorial page editor Joe Monchecurt left the building. After the fire was under control, Anderson said the staff was able to salvage most of Sunday's edition, which had already been typeset. The paper was taken to the Main Line Times office in Ardmore to be printed. ``We just picked up the paper and put things in a basket and put them in cars. Have paper, will travel,'' he said. Anderson said management officials expected the newspaper to be in the stands on schedule, but they are uncertain when they will be able to return to normal operations at their office. ``We're playing it as it comes,'' he said. The Daily Times is published daily, except Saturday, by Central States Publishing Inc. It has a weekday circulation of 65,000 and 55,000 on Sundays.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Woman Who Held Baby at Knifepoint Incompetent for Trial
DOC.TEXT: A woman charged with holding her infant son at knifepoint during a 14-hour standoff with police is incompetent to stand trial, a jury has ruled. The state District Court jury ruled Friday that Tracy Diane Levis, 24, of Houston cannot be tried on aggravated assault charges because of mental incompetence. Judge Charles Hearn ordered Ms. Levis transferred to Vernon State Hospital. After a few months, psychiatrists will inform Hearn whether Ms. Levis has regained competence to point of understanding legal proceedings against her. A report by Harris County psychiatrist Jaime Ganc said Ms. Levis has been in about a dozen mental hospitals in the past five years and suffers from delusions and paranoia. The report said she hears ``voices of derogatory content'' and later identifies the ``voices'' as belonging to the devil. Ms. Levis had been traveling in a car with her mother, Barbara Levis, and her 1-year-old son, Brandon Duke, on Nov. 3, 1989, when she pulled a hunting knife on her mother, who was driving the car. When Mrs. Levis fled the car, her daughter reportedly chased her and then locked herself inside the car with the baby. Ms. Levis, her face caked with white makeup, was holding the knife to her son's throat when police arrived. She continued to do so for 14 hours, despite kissing and patting the child in her lap during the lengthy ordeal. The confrontation ended when police exploded a percussion grenade near the car, distracting the woman while officers rushed the car and broke out a window to free the boy and arrest Ms. Levis. The boy remains in the care of relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Salvadoran Politician Found Dead In Guatemala
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Salvadoran guerrillas blaming Cristiani gov't, threatening to call off talks, adds background, details. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `The slayings...'
DOC.TEXT: A prominent leftist Salvadoran politician who fled his nation because of threats on his life was found shot to death near the Guatemala-El Salvador border after he was reported kidnapped, officials said Saturday. A Guatemalan politician and lawyer who was with the Salvadoran when he reportedly was abducted also was found dead, officials said. No one claimed responsibility for the slayings. Salvadoran and Guatemalan politicians blamed right-wing paramilitary groups that operate in both countries, but El Salvador's leftist guerrillas blamed Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist Republican Nationalist Alliance party and its founder, Roberto d'Aubuisson. The guerrillas, who last week said they were willing to renew peace talks with the Cristiani government, said they now are having second thoughts. Guatemalan police confirmed the deaths but would not comment further. The body of Hector Oqueli Colindres, 45, deputy secretary-general of the National Revolutionary Movement in El Salvador, was discovered Friday night in Jalpatagua, a city 60 miles east of Guatemala City, officials said. Oqueli had been shot in the head, a spokesman for the leftist National Revolutionary Movement said in El Salvador. The other victim was identified as Gilda Flores, a Guatemalan who was driving Oqueli to the airport in Guatemala City when they disappeared early Friday. Party officials said both were kidnapped by armed men. ``We are not interested in helping the fascist regime wash its face to seek U.S. military aid and further its plan of annihilating all types of opposition,'' said the Salvadoran rebels, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, in a statement made public in Mexico City. The statement referred to Cristiani's scheduled visit to Washington this week. El Salvador depends heavily on U.S. economic and military assistance. The FMLN said it doubted justice will be done in Oqueli's slaying or the killing of six Jesuit priests Nov. 16, and this ``leads us to revise our offer for a dialogue.'' With his U.S. visit about to start, Cristiani on Saturday identified four officers and five enlisted men as the prime suspects in the Jesuit killings. The FMLN had proposed a meeting within 30 days to renew cease-fire talks and the government accepted the offer. It was one of several unsuccessful meetings that government representatives and guerrilla leaders have held since 1984. Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo said in a news release his administration ``severely condemns the assassination'' of both Oqueli and Flores ``and pledges to clarify the slayings so that such a grave act of violence does not go unpunished.'' Cerezo also extended ``condolences to Latin American leaders of the Socialist International'' currently meeting in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital. Oqueli's party was part of the Socialist International and he was its secretary for Latin America. The organization groups moderate, leftist non-communist parties, including major European parties like West Germany's Social Democrats. Mario Solorzano Martinez, secretary-general of Guatemala's Social Democratic Party, to which Ms. Flores belonged, said the slayings were ``a combined action of Guatemalan and Salvadoran paramilitary forces.'' He said the victims' bodies were found along the highway from Guatemala to the Salvadoran border. The slayings come at a time of increasing political violence in El Salvador and Guatemala, where rightist factions have longstanding ties. The governing rightist party in El Salvador, known by the Spanish acronym Arena, was founded in Guatemala in the 1970s. The Salvadoran politician was reportedly on his way to Managua, where he was to help monitor preparations for the Nicaraguan election Feb. 25. Oqueli, who arrived Thursday in Guatemala, also was reportedly planning to attend a meeting of Latin American socialist leaders in Ecuador. The leader of the National Revolutionary Movement, Guillermo Ungo, was the presidential candidate of a leftist coalition in the March elections in El Salvador. Ungo blamed both the Guatemalan and Salvadoran governments for the killings. ``This crime helps the Salvadoran right wing to impede the development of democracy in El Salvador,'' Ungo said in an interview with The Associated Press in Managua. In London, visiting leftist leader Ruben Zamora of El Salvador said Saturday he believed right-wing death squads were responsible for killing Oqueli. He did not specifically accuse any group of the killing, but he claimed that Roberto d'Aubuisson, the founder of Arena, was working with Guatemalans to kill government opponents. Zamora added that in early November ``there was information Mr. d'Aubuisson was in Guatemala working with his right-wing associates from there, and the minister of defense of Guatemala has information that Mr. d'Aubuisson was proposing to take the opportunity and to kill all the political opponents of the government.'' D'Aubuisson has been linked to death squads that killed tens of thousands of people over the past decade. Oqueli was a deputy foreign minister in El Salvador from October 1979 until March 1980, when a military coup overthrew the government. Like many other leftists, he fled El Salvador after the coup, but he returned in 1987 to participate in politics. He left again in November, as did many Salvadoran leftists, under protection of the Venezuelan Embassy, after he was threatened during a major offensive by the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas. He had reportedly planned to return Jan. 20. He is survived by a wife and two children.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Editor of Centre Daily Times Dies After Suffering Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Jerome Weinstein, the former longtime editor of the Centre Daily Times whose journalism career spanned more than 50 years, has died after suffering a heart attack. He was 73. Weinstein, who died Friday, was editor of the newspaper from 1945 until his retirement in 1980. He had suffered a heart attack at his home in State College on Jan. 2. Weinstein became sports editor of the Times in 1937, a year before he graduated from Penn State. In 1940, he was named city editor-managing editor. The following year, he joined The Associated Press and served as news editor in Philadelphia and Harrisburg. He rejoined the Times in 1945, after editing a newspaper distributed from Miami Beach, Fla., throughout the Caribbean. During his tenure, the Centre Daily Times grew from a six-page newspaper with a circulation of 1,800 to a 40-page newspaper with a circulation of more than 20,000. The staff increased in size from three to 30. Weinstein directed the editorial efforts of the newspaper for 24 years, longer than any other editor of the Times or its weekly predecessor, The State College Times. ``Jerry was the personification of the Centre Daily Times for more years than most of its readers have been alive,'' said the newspaper's editor since Weinstein's retirement, Robert Ashley. ``He was instrumental in shaping the nucleus of this end of the paper, and he maintained his passion for it up until the end.'' Weinstein was president of the Pennsylvania Society of Newspaper Editors in 1953 and of the Associated Press Managing Editors in 1958. He was a retired member of Sigma Delta Chi, the journalism honorary society, the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the National Conference of Editorial Writers. Under his direction, the newspaper staff garnered more than 100 professional awards, including five Sweepstakes Awards, the highest honor of the Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association and the Pennsylvania Society of Newspaper Editors. Weinstein is survived by his wife, Thomazine Curtin Weinstein, and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Pray at Iowa Statehouse in Abortion Demonstrations Around U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of anti-abortion demonstrators prayed Saturday at Iowa's Statehouse in one of several protests around the country. Police arrested at least 77 people, including 10 in Utica, N.Y., who shackled themselves to an anvil. In Boston, an estimated 300 anti-abortion protesters trying to blockade a downtown clinic were confronted by about 200 abortion rights advocates, according to police Lt. Herbert Nolan. About 100 anti-abortion demonstrators also turned out at a clinic in the Boston suburb of Brookline; 40 to 50 people protested in Utica, officials said. A crowd of demonstrators from around Iowa police estimated at 6,000 to 7,000 gathered on the Iowa Statehouse steps in Des Moines for the morning demonstration that was as much a religious revival as it was a political protest. About 100 counterdemonstrators gathered across the street. A few wandered near the fringes of the crowd carrying signs and coat hangers, but state troopers kept both groups apart. Roman Catholic and protestant clergy and other speakers led demonstrators in prayers and hymns, and urged them to let their voices be heard on what one speaker called ``the No. 1 issue facing America today.'' ``We've got to come out of our stained-glass cathedrals. We've got to come out of our homes. We need to speak out at our work places and say, `Enough is enough,''' said the Rev. Keith Tucci of Pittsburgh. Demonstrators waved flags and held signs, including one depicting a baby seal carrying a sign reading, ``Save the baby humans.'' There were no arrests there, but at a family-planning clinic about 2{ miles away 39 protesters, including four juveniles, were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest, according to police Sgt. Thomas Van Baale. Later, about 3,000 anti-abortion activists marched for an hour outside the clinic, Planned Parenthood of Mid-Iowa. In Boston, anti-abortion activists blocked the clinic entrance, making it difficult for workers to enter without help from police. Police arrested at least 10 people on charges of assault and battery and disorderly conduct, Nolan said. All were believed to be from the anti-abortion side. Nearly 70 police officers erected barricades at the entrance. Demonstrators on both sides pushed, shoved and shouted, especially when women tried to enter the clinic. Patients who arrived at the clinic had to climb over a police barrier, with officers helping carry them, she said. A few patients called to reschedule their appointments. In the Brookline protest, police arrested four people, said police Officer Ronald Pateron. Two anti-abortion demonstrators were charged with trespassing and two counterprotesters were charged with assault and battery, said a dispatcher who did not give his name. In Utica in north-central New York state, police arrested 24 people who blocked the entrances to an abortion clinic, including the 10 who shackled themselves together with bars chained to a 100-pound anvil. The protesters said they were members of Operation Rescue. Twenty-three of those arrested were charged with trespassing and disorderly conduct, and one was charged with those violations and resisting arrest, said police Patrolman Charles E. Janucik II.

Federal authorities used a Stinger to lure four suspected Irish Republican Army guerrillas into a sting operation in which they offered $50,000 for the missile that can shoot an airliner out of the sky. The four men were arrested Friday after going to a warehouse in the West Palm Beach area to buy the heat-seeking missile from agents posing as arms dealers who told the suspects the weaponry was stolen from the U.S. military, said William Gavin, who heads the FBI in south Florida. ``They made it very clear they were interested in procuring Stinger missiles and high explosives _ and they intended to ship them out of the country,'' Gavin said at a news conference. Kevin Joseph McKinley, 33, Seamus Moley, 30, and Joseph McColgan, 39, all Irish nationals, and Sean John McCann, 34, of Canada, are believed to be members of the Provisional IRA, or ``Provos,'' the guerrilla arm of the nationalist group fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland.

The Energy Department, under pressure from environmental critics, will give the public a chance to review how its plans to clean up and rebuild the nation's nuclear weapons complex will affect the environment. The announcement Friday by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins came nearly seven months after 22 environmental and arms control groups sued the department to force such a review. ``The significance of it is that it would be the first comprehensive and public analysis of the whole weapons program,'' said Dan Reicher, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the environmental groups that sued. Reicher said allowing the public to participate in the planning could lead to significant changes in the future emphasis of the multi-billion dollar weapons program.

The Internal Revenue Service is toughening rules of conduct for senior employees following highly publicized allegations of misconduct by some field managers. The aim, said IRS Commissioner Fred Goldberg, is to protect ``what is the bedrock of our tax system, and that is the real and perceived integrity of this institution.'' ``What we need is ongoing attention and adherence to the kinds of issues of conduct, ethics and appearance that are essential to tax administration,'' Goldberg said Friday in announcing the ethics initiative. Goldberg acted after congressional hearings last summer in which managers and other top officials of some field offices were accused of abusing power, favoring friends and operating almost independently of directives from the agency's Washington headquarters.

President Bush, described as ``pretty broken up'' by a meeting with the family of a soldier slain in Panama, is using the invasion to argue that the United States must keep a high state of military readiness. ``This is not a time when we should naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture,'' Bush said Friday in a speech aimed at Congress, which reconvenes Jan. 23 after its winter recess. Bush cautioned that despite a relaxation of military tensions in Eastern Europe, lawmakers should not expect a ``peace dividend'' in which defense savings could be funnelled into domestic programs. ``Unfortunately, what is being packaged as a `dividend' is not money in the bank. It is more like a possible future inheritance,'' Bush said in his speech to the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce.
